taxonomicNotes: Fernando de Buén described Hubbsina turneri after specimens he collected in August 1940 in the Presa Cointzio, Río Grande de Morelia drainage. In 1983, Uyeno et al. published studies on the Karyotypes of Goodeids and A. Radda attached importance to these results, According to identical Karyotypes, he transfered 1984 this species into the genus Girardinichthys. Though phylogenetic results since the early 2000's (Doadrio and Domínguez, 2004) supported the individuality of the genus Hubbsina, Radda held onto his system, in 2004 raising the stock from the Lago Zacapú to species rank describing it as Girardinichthys ireneae. This stock is now regarded as subpopulation of Hubbsina turneri. According to its affiliation to three drainages, three subpopulations are distinguished: The Río Grande de Morelia subpopulation (type subpopulation), the Laguna Yuriría subpopulation and the Río Angulo subpopulation. The first two subpopulations are regarded Extinct. This species is here considered valid in the genus Hubbsina de Buen, 1940 following Ramírez-Herrejón et al. (2010). This differs from Eschmeyer et al. (2018) which consider it meanwhile valid in the genus Girardinichthys Bleeker, 1860.

The male Holotype of this species was collected together with the female Allotype and 198 Paratopotypes by Robert R. Miller and James T. Greenbank in March 1955 from the Río Teuchitlán, near the road between HW 70 and Etzatlán. Nine Paratypes were collected by Arthur A. Alcorn from a tributary to the Presa La Vega in February 1949 about 2km ESE of Teuchitlán and ten more by James A. Peters and William B. McIntosh in April of the same year from the Río Ameca about 12km E of the town of Ameca. In recent years (2006), the species has been additionally reported from the Balneario Almoloya, endorheic Laguna Magdalena basin, and the El Molino pond near Cuyacapán, endorheic Laguna de Sayula basin. Affiliated to three distinct drainages, three subpopulations can be inferred. The Río Ameca subpopulation (type subpopulation), the Laguna Magdalena subpopulation and the Laguna de Sayula subpopulation. The last one disappeared from the wild a few years after it had been discovered and is regarded Extinct.
This species is very similar in appearance to the sympatric Villosa choctawensis Athearn, 1964, so that the taxonomic status of this species requires verification (NatureServe 2010).

Lepus castroviejoi was described relatively recently, being separated from L. granatensis, a split supported by genetic evidence. While the range of L. castroviejoi partially overlaps that of L. granatensis and L. europaeus on the Iberian Peninsula, no hybridization has been detected with these forms. Recent studies have shown that instead, based on ecological, molecular and morphological characteristics, it is most closely related to L. corsicanus; some believe these two are conspecific (Alves et al. 2008, Acevedo et al. 2014, Ballesteros 2018). Additionally, two different occurrences of introgression of mtDNA from L. timidus into L. castroviejoi have been documented – indicating that these two forms have come into contact and hybridized two different times in the past, most recently during the last deglaciation (Melo-Ferreira et al. 2005, 2012; Ballesteros 2018). No subspecies or geographic variation in L. castroviejoi have been described (Flux and Angermann 1990, Hoffmann and Smith 2005, Ballesteros 2018).

Seven subspecies are generally accepted (TTWG 2017):

Malaclemys terrapin terrapin (Schoepff, 1793) - Northern Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin centrata (Latreille in Sonnini and Latreille, 1801) - Carolina Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin littoralis Hay, 1905 - Texas Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin macrospilota Hay, 1905 - Ornate Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin pileata (Wied, 1865) - Mississippi Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin rhizophorarum Fowler, 1906 - Mangrove Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin tequesta Schwartz, 1955 - Eastern Florida Diamondback Terrapin

These subspecific designations of terrapins were based on morphological characteristics (Carr 1952). However, molecular studies indicate that the morphological subspecific designations do not match well with the range-wide genetic differentiation, suggesting fewer independent lineages. Lamb and Avise (1992) first suggested two subpopulations that diverged near Jacksonville, Florida. More recent work using microsatellites suggested that five genetically distinct terrapin management units exist throughout the range (Hart et al. 2014). One unfortunate consequence of the previous heavy trade and farming of terrapins was the transport of individuals among populations, and the genetic signature of those translocations can still be detected today (Hauswaldt and Glen 2005; Converse et al. 2017; Converse and Kuchta 2018). A more thorough range-wide molecular study using more populations and loci is sorely needed to resolve the phylogenetic relationships and update the taxonomy of Malaclemys.

Lindholm (1929) recognized Testudo tornieri Siebenrock, 1903 as the type of a new genus, for which he established the name Malacochersus. The genus is monotypic, with only one species currently recognized. Genetic studies have demonstrated that Malacochersus is most closely related to Asian Indotestudo and Eurasian Testudo (Le et al. 2006; Parham et al. 2006; Fritz and Bininda-Emonds 2007). Phylogeographic studies of the species have not yet been realized, but are clearly needed in view of its disjunct distribution. Vernacular names used for the species in East African Kiswahili are Kobe ya Mawe and Kobe kama Chapati.
There is currently a publication in review on the species delineation of Menidia conchorum and Menidia peninsulae (S. O'Leary pers. comm. 2013).

This is the only surviving species of an ancient lineage from the early evolutionary history of the endemic family Mantellidae. It is therefore evolutionarily distinct and should be a high priority for efforts preserving Malagasy amphibian biodiversity.

Telmatobius punctatus was previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius brevirostris; it was elevated to specific status by Lehr (2005) based on differences in morphological features and colour patterns.

Oreobates lehri was initially ascribed to two distant populations, one in Cordillera Vilcabamba, which is now considered typical O. lehri, and one in the Andean hills of the Kosñipata Valley, to which is now assigned to O. gemcare (Padial et al. 2012). This is a restricted concept of O. lehri following the split of the broader concept into this and O. gemcare (Padial et al. 2012).
Identified as a new species by genetic analyses, this species combines morphological features of both P. austriacus and P. auritus.

This taxon has in the past sometimes been included as a subspecies of Pipistrellus tenuis (Koopman 1973, 1993), but its status has been confirmed by genetic and morphological assessment, which revealed it was a full species endemic to Christmas Island (Helgen et al. 2009).

According to Cook (2002), Cryptocanthon is a genus with wide occurrence in the New World tropics. They inhabit the litter of wet forests, both lowland rain forests and higher elevation montane and cloud forests, and occur from Brazil to Mexico. Some species are flightless.

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia. Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus may change.

A review of Canthon lamproderes by Fernando Vaz-de-Mello will soon be published which places some specimens previously identified as Canthon lamproderes within Canthon corpulentus - this has been taken into account in this assessment.


Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically relatively well known.
The genus Pachysoma Macleay 1821 comprises thirteen flightless species with a combined range extending along the dry to arid coastal region in the southwest of Africa (ScarabNet 2009).
The genus Pachysoma Macleay 1821 comprises thirteen flightless species with a combined range extending along the dry to arid coastal region in the southwest of Africa (ScarabNet 2009).
This species is one of only three described for the genus Platyonitis, one occurring in southwest Africa and the other two in northeast Africa.
The endemic Australian genus Aulacopris White, 1859 comprises three species. Aulacopris matthewsi is the only flightless species of the genus known.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically relatively well known.

The genus Ontherus was revised by Génier (1996). Its consists approximately of 60 species that are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in southeastem Brazil and the Andes (Génier 1996). The species that compose the genus are divided into three subgenera: Caelontherus, Planontherus and Ontherus.

Ateuchus is a diverse genus, with over 90 species, distributed from the United States to Argentina and Lesser Antilles. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy of identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

This species has been recently transferred from Drepanocerus Kirby, 1828 to a newly described genus Clypeodrepanus Krikken, 2009. It is represented only in the Afrotropical region by three species that are currently considered valid.
The genus Endroedyolus Scholtz & Howden 1987 comprises a single species with an extremely restricted distribution in eastern South Africa (ScarabNet 2009).

This Glaphyrocanthon belongs to the viridis group, very near to  C. (Gl.) meridionalis . The overlap in the distribution of several subspecies was the criterion used by Rivera-Cervantes and Halffter (1999) to reclassify C. zuninoi as a new species.

The genus Pachysoma Macleay 1821 comprises thirteen flightless species with a combined range extending along the dry to arid coastal region in the southwest of Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species is extremely closely related to Pachysoma hippocrates Macleay. Morphologically, the two species are virtually indistinguishable except by comparison of the aedeagi.

Canthonella was described by Chapin in 1930. Halffter and Martínez (1977) synonymized Ipselissus under Canthonella. There are currently very few species described from South America, but there are likely to be many more to be described.

Ateuchus is a diverse genus, with approximately 70 species, distributed from the United States to Argentina and Lesser Antilles. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy of identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

According to Cook (2002), Cryptocanthon is a genus with wide occurrence in the New World tropics. They inhabit the litter of wet forests, both lowland rain forests and higher elevation montane and cloud forests, and occur from Brazil to Mexico. Some species are flightless.

The genus Onoreidium was described and positioned in the subtribe Scatimina (Coleoptera: Scarabaeinae: Ateuchini) by Vaz-de-Mello (2008). Its present four species that are distributed throughout Ecuador, northern Peru, and Panama, comprising the Arid Ecuador and Tumbes-Piura in the Northwerstern South American dominion, and Eastern Central America. The species that compose the genus were originally described in Trichillum or Pedaridium.
This species has two subspecies, O. undulans undulans and O. undulans oaxacanus (according to Zunino and Hallfter 1988).

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia. Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus may change.

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992).

According to Vaz-de-Mello (2008), the genus Pedaridium is monotypic. However, it contains at least one undescribed species currently under study, in addition to the type species. It is present only in the Eastern Parana subregion, in the Parana Forest and Araucaria angustifolia Forest provinces.

According to Cook (2002), Cryptocanthon is a genus with wide occurrence in the New World tropics. They inhabit the litter of wet forests, both lowland rain forests and higher elevation montane and cloud forests, and occur from Brazil to Mexico. Some species are flightless.

There is marked genetic differentiation between populations on central and eastern islands in the archipelago, indicating that they have evolved in relative isolation for a long time (Salgueiro et al. 2004).

Marceniuk (2005) placed this species in Aspistor, but it is now generally agreed that the appropriate name is Sciades parkeri. A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.

The holotype of this species was originally identified as Cirroteuthis umbellata. Grimpe recognised it as a new species and erected Cirroteuthopsis massyae to accommodate it. Villanueva et al. (2002) placed it in Opisthoteuthis.

This species was described as Cirroctopus hochbergi O'Shea 1999 from off New Zealand (Type locality 39 58.9'S, 178 14.27'E, 800-1070 m). It is most similar to Cirroctopus mawsoni, but a few characters separate it and it is 'strongly allopatric' (O'Shea 1999).

Although Leguminaia is here treated as a unionid genus, other authors (e.g. Modell ,1964) placed it among the Margaritiferidae. Molecular studies are still needed for better clarification. The study of a living population with the aid of molecular characterization would greatly enhance our understanding of this poorly known and rare species.

The classification of the family margaritiferidae is contentious (Graf and Cummings 2007) having been recently treated from three different perspectives: a) Smith (2001) divided the species of the family among Margaritifera, Margaritanopsis and Pseudunio based mainly on hinge and ctenidia morphology, and placing this species in genus Pseudunio; b) Bogatov et al. (2003) based on the comparatory, tipological method and c) Huff et al. (2004) based on a molecular phylogenetic analysis.

Over the last century several subsequent studies (Modell 1964, Haas 1969, Schutt 1983, Kinzelbach and Roth 1984, Kinzelbach 1987, Schutt 1987, Nesemann 1993, Falkner 1994) have variously considered M. homsensis to be a Potomida (Unionidae), Pseudunio, Margaritana, or Margaritifera (Margaritiferidae). However the presence of mantle-attachment scars on the inner surface of the shell are identical in morphology to those of other margaritiferid species and indicates that M. homsensis sensu lato is properly assigned to the Margaritiferidae (Smith et al. 2001). Additionally and although Huff et al. 2004 had not analysed this species, he suggested that simply assigning all Margaritiferidae to the Margaritifera genus might be a reasonable solution. The discovery and study of a living population of M. homsensis with the aid of molecular characterization would greatly enhance our understanding of this poorly known and rare species.

<span lang="EN-US">The genus of the species has changed from Gabillotia to Anodonta over the past decades depending on the author (e.g. Modell 1951; Falkner 1994) but most recent authors consider the species as belonging to the genus Anodonta (Graf, 2007; Bogan 2010). Further molecular studies are needed to enlighten the phylogenetic relationships of this species
Schütt (1991) considered this species to be in the genus Semisalsa rather than Heleobia.
This species looks superficially similar to Stagnicola corvus, however, there are anatomical differences between the two species (Gloer and Yildrim 2006).

Silfvergrip (2009) described the diagnostic features of A. japonica greater than 200 mm total length (TL). These include a plain colouration, with no distinct markings, and a total number of vertebrae between 112–119. Dorsal fin anterior margin is 8.5–9.5% of TL, in advance of anus. The mouth is small, about one fourth of head length, and distance from anus to end of tail is 5.6–6.0 times longer than distance from anus to dorsal fin insertion.
High altitude species in the wild misidentified as S. attenuata but recently reclassified as S. burchi after molecular analysis (O'Foighil pers. comm.)

Gymnostomus horai was described as Crossocheilus horai by Bănărescu (1986) from Inle Lake in central Myanmar. The species was considered to belong to the genus Cirrhinus by Roberts (1997) and as the name Cirrhinus horai has already been used by Lakshmanan (1966), Roberts (1997) proposed Cirrhinus lu as a replacement name for this species. However, Kottelat (2003) showed that the definition of Cirrhinus as used by Roberts (1997) is erroneous and the species that Roberts (1997) assign to Cirrhinus is congeneric with species of Henicorhynchus Smith, 1945. Furthermore, Kottelat (2003) indicated that the correct generic name for this genus should be Gymnostomus Heckel, 1843.
The species was recently redescribed (Gómez-González et al. 2018).

Seth E. Meek collected the types of this species together with Frank E. Lutz in 1901 from the Pátzcuaro lake, other specimens from the Zirahuén lake (now regarded as a separate species, Allotoca meeki). Meek's collection of Zoogoneticus miniatus from the Lago de Chalco, Valle de México, had been identified as diazi with the reason for Meek describing it as a separate species originating in a mistake with the location (Álvarez del Villar and Narrasco 1957). Finally fish collected from the vicinity of Uruapán and regarded as diazi by Hubbs and Turner (1939), have later on been identified as separate species and described as Allotoca catarinae. The Pátzcuaro Allotoca is therefore restricted to the endorheic Lago de Pátzcuaro basin with no recognized subpopulations.

The Holotype of this species was taken by Miller and Greenbank in 1955 from the area east of Teuchitlán, Río Teuchitlán, but regarded as Zoogoneticus quitzeoensis. Two female Paratypes go back to this collection as well. Other Paratypes were several aquarium-reared descendants of wild caught fish collected by Lambert et al. in 1990, who named the fish provisorily Zoogoneticus sp. Finally in 1998, Webb and Miller described the species as Zoogoneticus tequila. As known only from the type location, the Río Teuchitlán, no subpopulations are distinguished.

Acanthopagrus vagus was previously confused with A. berda (Forsskål 1775) in South Africa (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). This species was recently separated as a separate species from A. berda (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2010).

This may be a subpopulation of Acanthopagrus schlegelli (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2009). Mitochondrial DNA analyses based on cytochrome b gene sequences did not distinguish individuals of A. schlegelii and A. sivicolus, reflecting either historical introgression or recent speciation and incomplete sorting of their mitochondrial lineages (Hsu et al. 2011). Pending further taxonomic work, A. sivicolus is here regarded as a distinct species.

Genetic analysis of the geographical partitioning revealed that this species showed an Atlantic-Mediterranean partitioning (Patarnello et al. 2007) indicating that exchanges between subpopulations are reduced and may limit rescue effects from migration and dispersal from other subpopulations to compensate for impacts of direct exploitation.
The taxonomy of sea lions in New Zealand (Phocarctos) and Australia (Neophoca) was confused until it was resolved in a paper by King (1960).

In the past, specimens of softshell turtles collected from New Guinea were all originally assigned to what was considered to be a widespread Australasian species, Pelochelys bibroni (Owen 1853), until Rhodin et al. (1993) and Webb (1995) defined P. bibroni as being restricted to southern New Guinea, and separate from the previously described P. cantorii (Gray 1864) in the rest of Asia and northern New Guinea. Subsequently, Webb (2003) described the northern New Guinea softshell as the new species Pelochelys signifera. This taxonomy has been accepted since then (TTWG 2017). Pelochelys signifera was described largely based on characteristics of a juvenile specimen and coloration and texturing of the carapace to distinguish it from P. cantorii. No geographic variation has been reported within the species' range and no subspecies have been named. Phylogenetic relationships with P. cantorii and P. bibroni warrant further investigation.
Confirmation of the taxonomic status of this species with respect to other Zonites is required.

Charpentieria spezialensis belongs to the group 1a nobilis-calcarae as listed by Nordsieck (2002:34). As Nordsieck stated, the species has been probably already collected in the same locality and Erhmann recognised it as a new species and named it Delima (Priodelima) specialensis but never described it.
There is some ongoing debate as to whether to regard this species as valid, or as part of a species complex (Kornilios et al. 2009).
According to Nordsieck (2016: Checklist of recent Clausiliidae) vrondamassa is assigned to the genus Isabellaria and is a subspecies of Isabellaria butoti.
Oxychilus fuscosus is currently assigned to the subgenus Oxychilus, but more taxonomical research is needed to assess its systematic position within the family Oxychilidae.
The date of description of this species is sometimes cited as 1972, however Brandt published the species description in 1962 (Brandt 1962).
The genus Vermetum was moved from Gastrodontidae to Pristilomatidae (Holyoak et al. 2014).
Charpentieria grohmanniana belongs to group 2 of the Charpentieria (Siciliaria) as stated by Nordsieck (2002).
The taxonomy of Succineidae is not resolved. Much more research is necessary to understand the morphological and geographic boundaries of the nominal species.

This species is very difficult to distinguish from the closely related A. subfuscus (Draparnaud, 1805); A. fuscus (O. F. Muller, 1774); A. lizzarrustii Garrido, Castillejo and Iglesias, 1995; and A. molinae Garrido, Castillejo and Iglesias, 1995. Even behavioural observation and dissection may be insufficient. Genetic data have been used to determine certain populations in Wales, UK as belong to "Arion cf. iratii" rather than to A. subfuscus (Rowson et al. 2014). More research on the three Garrido et al. (1995) species is required to clarify their distinctness, and their Red List statuses should arguably be considered provisional until then.
This species may be only a strange form of Vitrea kutschigi and further research is required.
There is some ongoing debate as to whether to regard this species as valid, or as part of a species complex (Kornilios et al. 2009).
Waldén (1983: 268, note 27) commented that two forms are found: a  larger and a smaller (normal) that do not seem to intergrade.
Welter-Schultes (2012) considers this species as probably a synonym of P. pseudofallax.
There is some ongoing debate as to whether to regard this species as valid, or as part of a species complex (Kornilios et al. 2009).
This species belongs to the subgenus Kimakowiczia.

The species has been described as a fossil (Esu, 1978) from Nuraghe su Casteddu (eastern Sardinia). It was later found alive in a nearby area (Cala Gonone) (Manganelli et al., 1995; Welter-Schultes, 2012). The anatomy of the species is still unknown thus the generic belonging to Hypnophila is only provisional, waiting for a taxonomical review.

Charpentieria eminens was originally described by Schmidt (1868) as a subspecies of Charpentieria cressicostata. The species has been overlooked by Favilli et al. (1995). Nevertheless recently recognized as a valid species (Beckmann, 2004), its systematic and taxonomic status must be further evaluated.

In Nordsieck (2002) Charpentieria leucophryna sensu Pfeiffer (1862) is considered as an intermediate form between C. tiberi and C. grohmanniana and is considered only provisionally as a valid species, thus in need of further taxonomic research. C. leucophryna sensu Boettger (1879) is closely related to C. crassicostata and probably refers to what Schmidt (1868) described as Clausilia eminens. Nordsieck (2002) selects and depicts a lectotype for both species in order to avoid taxonomic ambiguities. Charpentieria leucophryna belongs to group 1b as listed by Nordsieck (2002: 34).

Altonaga (1988) and Altonaga and Puente (1991) considered O. farinesianus a junior synonym of O. cellarius. All localities assigned to Zonites farinesianus or Hyalina farinesiana in Spain by different authors, such as Hidalgo, Servain and Fagot (among others) belong to the species O. cellarius. Welter-Schultes et al. (2011) considered O. farinesianusa variety of O. draparnaudi, but Falkner et al. (2002) recognized it as a valid species.

In respect to other Tyrrhenian Oxychilus, O. pilula is well characterized by its Retinella-like shell. Anatomically it shares characters with Oxychilus s.str.: penis with flagellum and internal ornamentation of penis consisting of pleats and rows of papillae. Its nearest species is O. cellarius, but it differs from it by virtue of the 10-12 rows of polygonal papillae in the inner penial complex.
Sysoev and Schileyko (2009) consider this species to be a synonym of L. jaroslaviae.

Charpentieria ferrox is considered by Nordsieck (2002: 34) only "provisionally" as a valid species as more taxonomical research is needed. The species is not listed within both of the two morphological groups he introduced (2002:34) as its shell presents different features that discriminate it from all the remaining species in the genus.
Wiktor (1987) considered that this species may be conspecific with T. totevi, however there is no relationship between both species (E. Neubert pers. comm. 2017).
Charpentiera nobilis episoma Brandt, 1961 is now considered a junior synonym of the nominal subspecies by Nordsieck (2004) and Bank (2013).
Nordsieck (2016) considers this species to be a subspecies of I. bicristata (Rossmässler, 1839).

The taxonomic identity of O. amblyopus, which was never illustrated, is a mystery (Falkner et al. 2002). Mabille described Zonites amblyopus from Corsica (without further precision) in 1869 and Locard, based on a sample label and manuscript by Bourguignat, described Hyalina amblyopa from Brest in 1894. Both species seem to have been described based on the same specimen (Falkner et al. 2002). Later Germain (1931), considered H. amblyopa Locard, a junior synonym of O. allarius, and Z. amblyopus Mabille a synonym of O. blauneri. Finally, a sample of Oxychilus sp., composed of six specimens and collected by Réal and Réal-Testud (1988) in Aleria (Corsica) was assigned to O. amblyopus by Falkner et al. (2012).

Charpentieria (Siciliaria) crassicostata belongs to the group 1 nobilis-calcarae sensu Nordsieck (2002) and, in particular to group 1a, characterized by the palatal edge of the clausilium plate not upbent. This grouping has been accepted also by Beckmann (2004).
The validity of Ruthenica gallinae is questionable. Lengyel and Páll-Gergely (2010) reported large variability of specimens in terms of shell size ranging from typical R. filograna to R. gallinae.
Accepted as Rhampholeon acuminatus in Mariaux and Tilbury (2006).
Accepted as Kinyongia vosseleri in Mariaux et al. (2008).
Accepted as Rhampholeon temporalis in Tilbury et al. (2006).
Accepted as Nadzikambia mlanjensis in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007). Populations of chameleons on nearby mountains in Mozambique do not represent this taxon (Branch and Tolley 2010).

Accepted as Rhampholeon platyceps (Tilbury 2010). Populations of Rhampholeon on Mt. Chiperone, Mabu and Namuli are separate taxa and should not be confused with R. platyceps (Branch et al. 2014). In addition, molecular phylogenetic analysis shows that the sub-species, R. platyceps carri is not valid (Branch et al. 2014).

authority: Menegon, Tolley, Jones, Rovero, Marshall & Tilbury, 2009
taxonomicNotes: Accepted as Kinyongia magomberae in Menegon et al. (2009).
Accepted as Kinyongia matschiei in Mariaux et al. (2008). Populations occur in the East Usambara Mountains, and these were formerly confused with K. fischeri.
Accepted as Rhampholeon beraduccii in Mariaux and Tilbury (2006).
Accepted as Kinyongia tenuis in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). The status of the Shimba Hills population as belonging to this taxon needs to be confirmed.

There are several localities in Mozambique (Mt. Namuli, Mt. Mabu) which were originally suspected to contain populations of Rhampholeon chapmanorum (Tilbury 2010). However, molecular phylogenetic analysis confirms that R. chapmanorum is endemic to remaining forest fragments in Malawi Hill, and the Mozambican localities are home to separate species of Rhampholeon (Branch et al. 2014).
Accepted as Kinyongia excubitor in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007).

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank. Two morphologically distinct subspecies, corresponding to a northern and southern distribution within the Cameroon mountain chain, are traditionally recognized, the southern T. q. quadricornis (Mertens 1968) and northern T. q. gracilior (Barej et al. 2010). Molecular data supports this division, although suggests a very recent split between these taxa (Barej et al. 2010). Klaver and Böhme (1992) suggest that the assignment of Mt Kupe specimens to T. q. quadricornis requires verification, and that these records may in fact represent a separate, isolated lineage. Barej et al. (2010) also supported the finding by Pook and Wild (1997) that the morphologically divergent and geographically disjunct Eisentraut's chameleon (T. eisentrauti) should be treated as a subspecies of T. quadricornis on molecular grounds, and formally made this change. Accepted as Trioceros quadricornis in Tolley and Herrel (2014) and Glaw (2015). Glaw (2015) recognizes three subspecies: Trioceros quadricornis quadricornis, Trioceros quadricornis eisentrauti, and Trioceros quadricornis gracilior.
The subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) was elevated to generic rank by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Accepted as Trioceros pfefferi in Tilbury and Tolley (2009), Tolley and Herrel (2014), and Glaw (2015).
Accepted as Kinyongia multituberculata in Mariaux et al. (2008) and Tilbury (2010).

Cnemaspis indraneildasii was described from Gund, North Kanara, Karnataka (Bauer 2002). The forms belonging to Cnemaspis kandiana (Kelaart 1852) (in part) from northern Western Ghats as reported by Smith (1935) are now included under Cnemaspis indraneildasii Bauer, 2002 following Das (2003).  Species boundaries in the C. kandiana complex generally need to be critically re-evaluated.

Mabuya clivicola was described based on three specimens collected from Ponmudi, Thiruvananthapuram District, Kerala (Inger et al. 1984). Following revision of the genus Mabuya by Mausfeld et al. (2002) this taxon is presently included within Eutropis Fitzinger 1843.
Oligodon brevicauda was described by Günther in 1862 based on specimens collected from Anaimalai Hills, Western Ghats in Coimbatore District, Tamil Nadu (Smith 1943).
Melanophidium bilineatum was described by Beddome in 1870 based on specimens collected from Waynaad, Kerala (Smith 1943).

Uropeltis phipsonii was described as Silybura phipsonii by Mason in 1888 based on type series collected from the Bombay Ghats between Bombay (=Mumbai) and Pune, Maharashtra, India (Boulenger 1890, Smith 1943). The specific epithet is sometimes erroneously listed as 'phipsoni'. Uropeltis phipsonii has been treated as a synonym of Uropeltis rubrolineatus (Günther,1875) by Gans (1966) and revalidated by Rajendran (1985).

Dasia subcaerulea was described by Boulenger in 1891 as Lygosoma subcaeruleum based on a specimen collected from Bodanai-Kannur, Travancore (presently Bodinayakanur in Theni district of Tamil Nadu), India (Smith 1935). Joshua and Sekar (1984) assigned Indian specimens they collected to the Sri Lankan endemic D. haliana, and a number of additional records of this species have since been reported from India (see Wickramasinghe et al. 2011). Examined material of Indian "D. haliana" has recently been found to represent D. subcaerulea (Wickramasinghe et al. 2011, using the incorrect nomina Dasia halianus and D. subcaeruleum). The specimens collected by Joshua and Sekar (1984) were apparently not preserved and so cannot be examined, and in the absence of evidence to the contrary all records of D. haliana from India are considered to belong instead to D. subcaerulea (Wickramasinghe et al. 2011).

Cnemaspis jerdonii was described by Theobald in1868, however, no type locality was mentioned in the type description (Smith 1935, Das and Bauer 2000). The taxon scalpensis, which was described from Sri Lanka (Ferguson 1877) and long considered a subspecies of Cnemaspis jerdonii, has been elevated to species level (Wickramasinghe and Munindradasa 2007).  As with the other members of the genus Cnemaspis, populations north and south of the Palghat Gap need taxonomic revalidation.  Species boundaries in the C. kandiana complex generally need to be critically re-evaluated.
Cnemaspis goaensis was described from Ponguinim, Canocona Taluka, South Goa, Goa (Sharma 1976).
Cnemaspis wynadensis was described by Beddome in 1870 based on specimens collected from Wayanad.

Ahaetulla perroteti was described by Duméril, Bibron and Duméril in in 1854 as Psammophis perroteti based on specimens collected from India (Smith 1943). No specific type locality has been assigned so far.

Cnemaspis indica was described as Goniodactylus indicus by Gray in 1846 based on specimens collected from Madras Presidency (Smith 1935), now mostly in Tamil Nadu, India (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007).  The populations north and south of Palghat Gap should be re-evaluated.  However, for the purposes of this assessment the known distributions are considered to represent C. indica. The record from Nadukani (~300 m asl) in Thrissur Distrct, Kerala (Das and Whitaker 1990) needs validation as it was based on a juvenile specimen from outside the known elevational range of the species.

Rhinophis travancoricus was described by Boulenger in 1892 based on specimens from Vembayam in Thiruvananthapuram district, Kerala, India  (Boulenger 1892, Smith 1943). The common name Tamil Nadu Earth Snake is a misnomer, as this species has been reported from Kerala and the specific epithet 'travancoricus' refers to 'Travancore' as the region where the type locality is present. However, the erstwhile kingdom of Travancore included most of southern Kerala, the Kanyakumari district and some parts of the present day southwestern Tamil Nadu (C. Srinivasulu pers. comm.2011).

Eurylepis poonaensis was described by Sharma (1970) as Eumeces poonaensis based on a specimen collected from Katraj Ghat, Poona (now Pune District), Maharashtra, India. Griffith et al. (2000) and Schmitz et al. (2004) opin that Eurylepis poonaensis (Sharma 1970) belongs to Eurylepis taeniolatus group.  Further molecular work is needed to establish the relationship between this species and E. taeniolatus (Griffith et al. 2000, M.S. Khan pers. comm.)
Research is needed to clarify whether records from the two known localities represent the same species (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011).
Otocryptis beddomii was first described by Boulenger in 1885 basing on specimens collected from Sivagiri Ghats in Cardamom Hills in Southern Kerala (Smith 1935).
Unidentified Pipistrellus bats found in the Azores have recently been proposed to belong to this species, but this awaits confirmation.

Prior to analysis by Keogh et al. (2008), all the banded iguanas were lumped as a single species. The Fiji Banded Iguana (Brachylophus bulabula) is now recognized as distinct from the Lau Banded Iguana (Brachylophus fasciatus). Most previous references pertaining to iguanas in central Fiji are now attributed to B. bulabula.

Morphological data from recent surveys suggest there may be more than one taxa within the bulabula group. On two islands north of Vanua Levu (Mali and Cikobia), iguanas show marked variation in adult body size and some scale counts when compared to southern populations, for example, Makodroga and Kadavu. However, more samples and DNA analysis is needed to develop detailed comparisons (R. Fisher and P. Harlow pers. comm. 2011).

Conolophus marthae was recently described. No prior reference exists in the taxonomic literature as the species was not known before its description (Gentile and Snell 2009). The description was based on morphological, genetic, and behavioural diagnostic traits. The holotype is a free-living adult male tagged with a subcutaneous electronic marker, branded, and released. Further genetic evidence supporting separate taxonomic status of the Galápagos Pink Land Iguana prior to the species description is found in Gentile et al. 2009 and Tzika et al. 2008. Gentile et al. (2009) disclaims the name ‘‘rosada’’ for nomenclatural purposes (Articles 8.2 and 8.3, International Code of Zoological Nomenclature 1999).

There has been considerable debate of the specific states of the San Esteban Spiny-tailed Iguana, and it is often referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura hemilopha hemilopha (part, Lowe and Norris 1955) or Ctenosaura hemilopha conspicuosa (Lowe and Norris 1955).

There has been considerable debate over the species status of the Nolasco Spiny-tailed Iguana, and it is often referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura hemilopha hemilopha (Lowe and Norris 1955) or Ctenosaura hemilopha nolascensis (Smith 1972). The iguana was most recently recognized at the species level by Grismer (1999a). Genetic components of two lineages have been detected within the island (Cryder 1999, Davy et al. 2010, Reynoso et al. 2010).

Morphological data places Sauromalus klauberi as sister to S. slevini, with that clade being sister to S. ater (Hollingsworth 1998), while molecular data places it with peninsular S. ater (Petren and Case 2002). Sauromalus klauberi was designated as a subspecies of S. ater by Soulé and Sloan (1966) without comment until Murphy (1983) elevated it back to species status. The species has been taxonomically supported since its description (Hollingsworth 1998).

The species has been taxonomically supported since its description (Hollingsworth 1998). Morphological data places Sauromalus varius as sister to all other Sauromalus (Hollingsworth 1998), while molecular data groups S. varius in a clade with S. hispidus (Petren and Case 1997, 2002).

Prior to its description this species was considered to belong to a widespread form, Callulina kreffti (Loader et al. 2009). C. kreffti as now understood is a restricted-range species that may be endemic to the East Usambara Mountains (Loader et al. 2010, 2014).

The taxonomic status of the species has been confirmed by Spitzenberger et al. (2006). Here we refer to P. teneriffae as the population on the Canaries. Northwest African populations previously assigned to teneriffae are currently included in kolombatovici, and Balkan populations are assigned to austriacus.

There are no significant genetic differences between populations on the different islands (Justeet al. 2004).
This species was described in 2002 by Villanueva, Collins, Sanchez and Voss.  Many specimens from the Eastern Atlantic were previously attributed to Opisthoteuthis agassizii.

Bogan and Pierson (1993) recommended that Pleurocera prasinata, P. vestita, P. foremani, P. showalteri and P. annuliferum should be compared to see if these species are actually clinal variants of the same species. However, this has not been peer reviewed. Based on unpublished molecular data, P. foremani should be recognized as Elimia foremani. For this assessment, we follow the current taxonomy of P. foremani as a valid species.
Because of the wide distribution of this species, many herpetologists believe that this is a species complex (R. Inger pers. comm.).

Jackiewicz (1998) states that there are several problems concerning the nomenclature of the family Lymnaeidae, and that there is probably no other snail group in such taxonomical disarray. Stagnicola has been used as a synonym for Lymnaea by various authors, and as a subgenus of Lymnaea by others (Ponder and Waterhouse 1997, Vinarski 2003, NatureServe 2009). Hovingh (1993) lists this species as Lymnaea (Stagnicola) pilsbryi, whereas NatureServe (2009) name it Stagnicola pilsbryi. Dillon (2009) suggests that Lymnaea pilsbryi is a synonym of Lymnaea humilis, but this is neither supported or denied in other literature. Stagnicola is used by Turgeon et al. (1998) in the most recent list. However, Hubendick (1951) used Lymnaea. For the purpose of this assessment, we follow the taxonomy used by NatureServe.

Placostylus koroensis is one of two Placostylus species recorded from Koro Island in the Lomaiviti Province of the Fiji Islands, the other being Placostylus morosus (Gould 1846) which is more widely distributed occurring on other islands. A colour photograph of the syntypes can be found in Abbott (1989). The original description of Garrett (1872) also has a colour plate.

Acanthurus chronixis is a close relative of Acanthurus pyroferus, sharing the count of VIII dorsal spines and the same morphology, in particular the protruding snout (Randall 2001a).  Its taxonomic status is uncertain due to limited number of specimens. There is taxonomic work underway to determine the status of this species. We accept current taxonomy that this species is valid (Eschmeyer 2011, J.E. Randall pers comm. 2011).

Genetic studies by Vargas-Ramirez et al. (2006, 2007a, 2012) and Restrepo (2008) have shown that P. lewyana has low levels of genetic variability and no evidence of genetic population structure on a micro or macro-geographic scale, in addition to some level of inbreeding on a local scale.
A sibling species is known from Langebaan, but has yet to be named and published (W. Holleman pers. comm. 2010).
This species was known as Stichopus variegatus (Rasolofonirina pers comm. 2010), which is now synonomized under S. horrens.
Holothuria scabra and H. scabra var. versicolor (now H. lessoni) have recently been properly identified as distinctive species (Uthicke et al. 2005).
Previously known as Holothuria scabra var. versicolor.
Uthicke et al. (2004) by genetic analysis differentiated H. whitmaei, H. fuscogilva and H. nobilis, which were previously confused.
There are a few different morphs in the Africa and Indian Ocean region (Conand 2008) which may make correct identification of the species difficult.
This species may also be known as Mertensiothuria platei (Deichman 1958). There have been no specimens collected after 1958. This species is in need of a taxonomic review.
This species is recognized as Parastichopus parvimensis or Apostichopus parvimensis.
This species may be the same as Stichopus fuscus. This species was confused with I. badionotus.
Apostichopus japonicus was formerly known as Stichopus japonicus.
Uthicke et al. (2004), by genetic analysis, differentiated H. whitmaei, H. fuscogilva and H. nobilis, which were previously confused.

This species was described from Tioman Island off the eastern coast of Peninsular Malaysia (Ng et al. 1999), where it is endemic. It had been misidentified as C. nieuhofii (e.g. Alfred 1966) prior to its recognition as a distinct species.
Roberts (1998) described three trophic morphs assigned to this species. Kottelat (2000) named two of the trophic morphs to other species: P. rasorius and P. laticeps.
Originally described as Danio apopyris, transferred to genus Devario by Fang (2003).
Two subspecies of Pachydrobia zilchi are known: P. z. zilchi and P. z. reducta. These two subspecies differ by size and bosses.

The species was described by Brandt (1968) as a subspecies of Brotia binodosa, and mentioned that intermediate morphs can be found between both taxa. Glaubrecht and Köhler (2004) could not identify such morphs among the studied material, and considered B. subgloriosa as distinct species from B. binodosa.
The species limits are poorly defined with respect to other described taxa in this family, and they are in need of revision.

Brotia paludiformis was revised by Köhler and Glaubrecht (2006), who showed that B. paludiformis Solem, 1966 is not conspecific with Semisulcospira paludiformis Yen, 1939.

Brandt (1974) described a subspecies of B. paludiformis (P. p. dubiosa) which shows a similar shell morphology to Brotia armata and is so considered by Glaubrecht and Köhler (2004) to be a synonym of this species.

Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera: Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus redimiculus (Taylor and Akins 2007).
This species is easily confused with Coryphopterus glaucofraenum and C. venezuelae.

This species is often confused with C. glaucofraenum and C. tortugae. Although genetically distinct, C. glaucofraenum and C. venezuelae are extremely similar (Baldwin et al. 2009). There are some unresolved taxonomic issues surrounding the synonimization of Coryphopterus bol (described from Puerto Rico in 2008) under C. venezuelae (Collette and Smith-Vaniz 2013).
This species is easily confused with Coryphopterus hyalinus. Coryphopterus hyalinus and C. personatus are genetically distinct (Baldwin et al. 2009).
Older records of Coryphopterus in the western Atlantic may need to be verified as the genus has recently been revised (Baldwin et al. 2009).
This species was described in 2009.
The species has long been misidentified as Botia sidthimunki or Y. sidthimunki.
Tricula conica is considered nomen dubium by S. Attwood (pers. comm. 2010).
The species description by Davis has not been published.

This species was originally listed in the assessment as Valvata kizakikoensis though originally described as Cincinna kizakikoensis. But Cincinna is a genus created according to the Comparatory Method used by Russian taxonomists (and by extension Korean and Japanese ones) but is not recognized in Western taxonomy as a distinct genus according to the taxonomic criteria of the Biological Species Concept (BSP). Since the IUCN generally uses the BSP-criteria in their assessments, the name Cincinna should be replaced by Valvata otherwise e.g. the common European Valvata piscinalis also needs to be referred to as Cincinna piscinalis as is done in Russian literature.      .

The valvatid species that occurs in lakes on Iturup Island (South Kurile Islands, Russia) was originally (wrongly) identified as C. kizakikoensis but has subsequently been recognized as a distinct, endemic species, namely Cincinna chisimana Prozorova & Starobogatov, 1999, i.e. Valvata chisimana (Prozorova & Starobogatov 1999) (see Kantor et al. 2009).  Valvata kizakikoensis sensu stricto is hence only known from its original  type locality, namely Lake Kizaki and Lake Nakatsuna, Nagano Prefecture, Honshu, Japan and does not occur in the Kuriles.

According to Clarke (1981), Alasmidonta triangulata is a synonym of Alasmidonta undulata. It is treated as a distinct species by Johnson (1970), Clench and Turner (1956), Brim Box and Williams (2000) and retained in the 1998 American Fisheries Society Publication (Turgeon et al. 1998); the species is in need of genetic determination.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of uncertainty. This research is in progress and will result in the recognition of numerous additional taxa in this genus. Johnson (1970) considered Elliptio roanokensis a synonym of Elliptio complanata. E. roanokensis is a distinct, large freshwater mussel with branched papillae. NC Wildlife Resources Commission (NCWRC) field experience indicates that what had been called Elliptio judithae from the Neuse drainage is a synonym of Elliptio roanokensis. This view has been tentatively supported by other malacologists (Art Bogan, North Carolina State Museum; John Alderman, North Carolina Resource Commission) based on conchological and soft-tissue features. Clarke (1986) described Elliptio judithae from the Neuse River, but his description of the species matched that of smaller individuals of Elliptio roanokensis (Adams et al. 1990).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The genus Marstonia formerly was relegated to synonymy with Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987). But Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia (J. Cordeiro pers. comm. 2010).

This species' taxonomic validity is questionable (it is unknown whether it is separate from E. cochlaris). In an unpublished study of molecular systematics, Campbell and Harris (2006) found this species relatively close to two Elimia annettae used in the study and to Elimia bullula; however, it may be a distinct species.

Despite the long-standing recognition of this taxon as a valid species, it has been suggested that multiple existing taxa (montanensis, idahoensis and apicina) are synonyms of Stagnicola catascopium. In particular, this taxon appears to be closely allied with S. apicina (Stagliano et al. 2007). For the purpose of this assessment, we follow the general acceptance of S. idahoensis as a valid species.

Hubendick (1951, in NatureServe 2010) includes this species as a form of S. emarginata.
The validity of this species is unclear, but this was not addressed in the latest taxonomic assessment of Juga (Strong and Frest, 2007).

Quadrula intermedia has been synonymized in the past with Quadrula tuberosa and Quadrula sparsa (Ortmann 1918, Williams et al. 2008). The relationship to Quadrula tuberosa, Quadrula intermedia, and Quadrula sparsa is questionable; however, both Q. tuberosa and Q. sparsa have been found historically within the range of Q. intermedia and no intergrade specimens have been found (USFWS 1984). Q. tuberosa may be the form of Q. intermedia occurring in big rivers, where a more obese form typically occurs in many unionid species. Quadrula sparsa is currently recognized by Turgeon et al. (1998). Distributional records became confused when Ortmann (1914, 1918) lumped Quadrula sparsa and Quadrula tuberosa under Quadrula intermedia (Bogan and Parmalee 1983, Parmalee and Bogan 1998). Historical records for Q. tuberosa from the Cumberland River are therefore also included with historical records for Q. sparsa (USFWS 1984) but if these are distinct species, then Q. sparsa was not present in the headwaters of the Cumberland River (Parmalee and Bogan 1998).

This species is listed in Graf and Cummings (2007) under the genus Theliderma. However, it is thought by some that further justification is needed before this change can be confirmed.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
This species was placed in the genus Stenophysa by Taylor (2003), but subsequent molecular analyses included it within the family Physidae and genus Physa (Wethington and Lydeard 2007).

The genus Marstonia formerly was relegated to synonymy with Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987). But Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species and assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia (J. Cordeiro pers. comm. 2010).
Fusconaia mitchelli is also known as Quadrula mitchelli (Simpson, 1895). This species is commonly known as the False Spike.
Previously placed in the genus Trionyx, euphraticus was placed in the resurrected genus Rafetus by Meylan (1987), and this has been widely accepted as such (Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2014).

Myers (1991) provisionally included this species within Colosthethus chocoensis. It was recognized as a distinct species by Grant et al. (1997), but was not formally described; and was finally described by Myers and Grant (2009).

This species was treated as belonging to Arthroleptis adolfifriederici prior to its formal description (Perret, 1966; Amiet, 1975). Confusion may also have occurred with A. variabilis (Blackburn et al. 2009).

This species was previously considered as belonging to an indeterminate subspecies of Bufo verrucosissimus (Litvinchuk et al. 2008). Historical records in Iran assigned to Bufo bufo may also represent this species (Litvinchuk et al. 2008). Iranian records are included in this assessment on the basis that their affinities are uncertain, but probably don't represent true Bufo bufo (Litvinchuk et al. 2008).

This species was previously described as Odorrana chapaensis by Ngo et al. 2006 and Che et al. 2007, Amolops chapaensis by Bain and Nguyen, 2004 and Rana sp. ‘‘Cao Bang’’ (ROM 26476) by Chen et al. 2005.
This is a split from the broader concept of Rhaebo haematiticus (Mueses-Cisneros 2009).

authority: Pérez-Rodríguez, Pérez-Ponce de León, Domínguez-Domínguez & Doadrio, 2009

taxonomicNotes: Algansea Monticola was originally separated into the subspecies A. m. monticola and A. m. avia (Barbour and Miller 1978). More recent genetic evidence validates A. avia as a distinct species, which coinhabits the Santiago River with A. monticola. (Perez-Rodriguez et al. 2009)

The Holotype of the Whitepatched Splitfin was collected by R.R. Miller and J.T. Greenbank in 1955 from the Arroyo San José de Tule (Río La Trampa), Río El Tule drainage at the HW 110 bridge at El Pozo Santo (Crucero del Tule). Paratypes were collected from three more sites including the Río El Terrero W of the town of 21. de Noviembre in 1970, also Río El Tule drainage, and the upper Río Tuxpán at San Rafael and a nameless creek 1km E of La Garita, a Río Tamazula tributary, both Río Tuxpán drainage and both collected in 1955. From the affiliation to two different drainages, two subpopulations can be inferred: the Río El Tule subpopulation (type subpopulation) and the Río Tuxpán subpopulation. Both are separated by approximately 120 river kilometres and in need of further studies including phylogenetics to clear their relationship.

The Holotype of the Finescale Spitfin (Allodontichthys polylepis) was collected by Robert Rush Miller in 1976 from the Río Potrero Grande (Arroyo Grande), Río Ameca drainage, whereas the Paratypes included in the original description originate from collections he made in 1957 and 1970 from the Arroyo Estanzuela (Río de las Bolas or de la Pola), Río Atenguillo drainage. From the affiliation to different drainages, two subpopulations can be inferred: the (now possibly Extinct in the Wild) Río Potrero Grande subpopulation and the Río de las Bolas subpopulation. Both display plainly divergent colour patterns though they are anatomically similar, so further studies including phylogenetics to clear the relationship are recommended.

Holotype and Paratypes of this species were taken by Clarence L. Turner from the Río Tamazula in Jalisco, just above the town of Tamazula de Giordano in April 1939. In the following years, this species was found to inhabit the Río Tamazula/ Tuxpán system downstream to about the town of San Marcos, 12km SE of Tuxpán, upper Río Coahuayana sections. Furthermore, it was collected in the Río El Tule drainage above El Pihuamo, an affluent of the middle Río Coahuayana section (named Río Naranjo). From the distribution in two distinct river systems, two subpopulations, the Río Tuxpán subpopulation (type subpopulation) and the Río El Tule subpopulation, can be inferred.

Holotype and Paratype used by Clark L. Hubbs for the description of the Bandfin Splitfin in 1922 were collected by G. Glückert in 1913 in the vicinity of Colima, probably from the Río Colima, Río Armería drainage. To the same drainage belong almost all creeks and rivers where this species has been found in the following decades, only few collection sites are known from headwaters of the neighbouring Río Salado, middle Río Coahuayana drainage. According to the affiliation to two distinct rivers systems, two subpopulations, the Río Armería subpopulation (type subpopulation) and the Río Salado subpopulation can be distinguished.
Can be confused with the sympatric and shell-wise very similar Sulcospira collyra.

Bean's Holotype of the Bulldog Splitfin was collected by Alfredo Dugès in 1891 in the Pátzcuaro lake (Hubbs and Turner, 1939), but soon thereafter, it was also known from some locations in Guanajuato and several other large lakes (lagos Cuitzeo, Chapala and Zirahuén). Descibed as Fundulus robustus, it was transfered into the genus Zoogoneticus by Meek in 1902 and later into the new monotypic genus Alloophorus by Turner (1937). Taking in consideration its affiliation to different separate river drainages respectively endorheic basins and phylogenetic results, ten subpopulations in two lineages can be inferred: The Lago de Pátzcuaro subpopulation (type subpopulation), the adjacent Río Grande de Morelia subpopulation (including the Lago Cuitzeo), the Río Angulo subpopulation (including the Lago Zacapú) and the possibly Extinct lagunas de Zirahuén and Yuriría and Middle Río Lerma subpopulations, the last one encompassing several rivers in Guanajuato (like the ríos Turbío, Guanajuato and Laja). Representatives from these six drainages belong phylogenetically to one lineage with respect to the following four ones, which again form a distinct lineage and probably even a separate to be described species: The Río Duero subpopulation (lower Río Lerma basin), the Cotija subpopulation (upper Río Balsas drainage), the Río Cupatitzio subpopulation, also in the Río Balsas headwaters in and south of Uruapán and the Lago de Chapala-Río Grande de Santiago subpopulation, now possibly Extinct except for the isolated Lagos Los Negritos about 10 km east of Sahuayo. Further studies to reveal the phylogenetic relationship within this species are required.

The types that Tarleton H. Bean used to describe Fundulus dugesii in 1887 were collected by Alfredo Dugès (probably) somewhere in Guanajuato; the year of collection is unknown. In 1896, Jordan and Evermann transfered this species into the genus Adinia, Meek in 1902 into the genus Zoogoneticus. Hubbs and Turner (in Turner, 1937) finally placed it as type in the genus Allotoca. Allotoca vivipara, decribed from the Pátzcuaro lake be Fernando de Buén in 1940 is Allotoca dugesii. Eight subpopulations according to separate drainages can be distinguished: The Río Grande de Morelia subpopulation, the Lago de Pátzcuaro subpopulation, the lagunas de Zirahuén and Yuriría subpopulations, the Middle Río Lerma subpopulation (type subpopulation), the Río Duero subpopulation, the Lago de Chapala/Río Grande de Santiago subpopulation and the Río Verde subpopulation. Samplings throughout the last two decades suggest, that many of these subpopulations have disappeared and probably only the Río Grande de Morelia, the Lago de Pátzcuaro and the Río Duero subpopulations are still extant.

The Holotype of this species was collected together with Paratopotypes by Robert Miller and others in February 1976 from the Río (Potrero) Grande, about 9.6km W of the town of Ameca. Several Paratypes go back to collections from the type location in 1957 and 1971, one single male to a collection of R. Vrijenhoek and M. Douglas from a bridge over the Río Ameca (precisely: Río Cuisillos), 1km E of the estación Pacana, SE of the Presa La Vega, in 1981. No subpopulations are distinguished.

The first individuals of this species have been collected by Seth E. Meek in 1902, but identified as Zoogoneticus diazi (now: Allotoca diazi), a new species he described from the Pátzcuaro lake. It lastet until 1959, when Álvarez del Villar recognized individuals from the Laguna de Zirahuén as separate species and described it from a male Holotype, collected by Aurelio Solórzano in 1957, and Paratypes collected Juan Pizá and José Guerra in 1958. No subpopulations are distinguished.

The types Álvarez del Villar used to describe Neoophorus regalis were collected by P. Francke in 1958 in the vicinity of Los Reyes de Salgado. He later transfered the species in the genus Alloophorus comparing it with Alloophorus robustus (1970). When it was rediscovered in 1993 and it became clear, that this species is no Alloophorus, it consequently had been transfered back in the genus where it belonged before, now Neoophorus regarded as synonym of Allotoca (Espinosa-Perez et al. 1993). In 2001, this species was excluded from Allotoca by some morphological differences and transferred back into its original genus Neoophorus (Meyer et al. 2001). This species is here considered valid in the genus Neoophorus Hubbs and Turner, 1939 following Meyer at al. (2001). This is different to Eschmeyer et al. (2018) which considers the species valid in the genus Allotoca Hubbs and Turner, 1939. Affiliated from three river drainages, three subpopulations can be inferred: The endorheic Río Quitupán subpopulation, the Río Grande subpopulation (type subpopulation), both Cotija region, Upper Río Balsas drainage, and the Canal Tarecuato subpopulation, Laguna Chapala drainage.

The Holotype of the Zacapú Allotoca was collected by Manfred K. Meyer, Alfred Radda and C. E. Rivas-Benítez in February 2001 from the Laguna Zacapú. Paratypes go back to several collections from the Zacapú lagoon by different collectors between 1990 and 2001. No subpopulations are distinguished.

The types of this species were collected in December 1898 by J. O. Snyder from the Chapala lake near Ocotlán. Described by Jordan and Snyder as Characodon encaustus in 1900, Meek transfered the species to the genus Chapalichthys in 1903. According to the affiliation to two river drainages, two subpopulations (the Laguna de Chapala and the Lower Río Lerma subpopulation) can be distinguished.

The types of this species were collected by José Álvarez del Villar in 1961 from the Balneario Tocumbo and described by him as Chapalichthys pardalis in 1963. On the next page, he described Chapalichthys peraticus from a Holotype collected by J. Barrera in 1963, an Allotype the author collected in 1962 and several Paratypes, all from the Presa San Juanico. For many years, the San Juaníco stock was partly considered a separate species (e.g., Domínguez-Domínguez et al. 2005), but recent genetic and morphological analyses (Miller 2005, K. Piller pers. comm. 2018) indicate, that there are insufficient differences between the two stocks to warrant separate species status. Recent (Piller 2016, unpublished) phylogenetical tests revealed finally, that both belong to the same species and have to be named Chapalichthys pardalis. Following the original description of pardalis and peraticus by Álvarez del Villar, both are barely distinguishable. As the habitats are separated by only 20 km distance beeline and connected via a channel, no subpopulations are distinguished.

The types Tarleton Bean used to describe Characodon bilineatus (1887) go back to fish Álfredo Dugès collected (probably) in Guanajuato before 1887. It was transfered into the genus Skiffia by S. Meek in 1902 and into Goodea by Regan in 1907. Hubbs and Turner (in Turner, 1937) erected the genus Neotoca for this species and placed it herein (1939). Miller and Fitzsimons proposed in 1971 to transfer this species back into Skiffia where it stayed for several decades. Already by the late 1990`s (Webb, 1998) became more and more clear, that the Twoline Skiffia is not closely related with the other representatives of the genus, so Doadrio and Domínguez-Domínguez placed it in Neotoca again (2004). This species is here considered valid in the genus Neotoca Hubbs and Turner, 1939. This differs from Eschmeyer et al. (2018) where it is considered valid in the genus Skiffia Meek, 1902. Affiliated to different drainages, five subpopulations can be inferred: The Middle Río Lerma subpopulation (type subpopulation), the Río Grande de Morelia subpopulation, the Laguna Yuriría subpopulation, the Río Grande de Santiago/ Laguna Chapala subpopulation, and - inferred from the range of the species, but not documented with Vouchers - the Lower Río Lerma subpopulation. The last three subpopulations are regarded Extinct.

The types of Skiffia lermae were collected by S. Meek and F. Lutz in 1901 from the Pátzcuaro lake, the types of Skiffia variegata from the Zirahuén lake. Regan in 1907 synonymized both species as Goodea lermae. The second species was re-established by Hubbs and Turner in 1939, but again synonymized by Miller and Fitzsimons in 1971. According to different drainages, seven subpopulations are distinguished: The Lago de Pátzcuaro subpopulation (type subpopulation), the Río Grande de Morelia subpopulation, the Río Angulo subpopulation, the Middle Río Lerma subpopulation, the Río San Juán subpopulation, the Laguna Yuriría subpopulation and the Laguna de Zirahuén subpopulation. The last four subpopulations are regarded Extinct.

Jacques Pellegrin received from M.L. Diguet specimens of this species from an area near Guadalajara before 1901 and described it as Xenendum multipunctatum (1901).  Regan placed it in 1907 in the genus Goodea as Goodea multipunctata, Hubbs and Turner in 1937 in Ollentodon. Again, Miller and Fitzsimons found the differences between Ollentodon and Skiffia not big enough to keep both genera valid and transfered the Splotched Skiffia into the genus Skiffia. Affiliated to three drainages, the Lower Río Lerma subpopulation (including the Río Duero), the Río Guascuaro and the Río Grande de Santiago/ Laguna Chapala subpopulation (type subpopulation) are distinguished. The type subpopulation is regarded Extinct, the Río Guascuaro subpopulation Data Deficient.

The types of the species C.L. Turner used to describe Xenotaenia resolanae were collected by himself in 1939 in the Río Resolana, a tributary of the Río Purificación. Affilated to two distinct river drainages, two subpopulations can be distinguished: The Río Purificación subpopulation (type subpopulation) and the Río Marabasco subpopulation.

The types of this species descibed by Cloudsley Rutter in 1896 as Characodon eiseni go back to collection of fish from Tepic by Gustav Eisen (1894). The species was synomyized with Characodon variatus by Regan in 1907 and finally transfered into the genus Xenotoca by Fitzsimons (1972). Specimens dedicated to this species from the Coahuayana drainage (as Xenotoca lyonsi) and the Laguna Magdalena basin respectively Río Ameca drainage (as Xenotoca doadrioi) have been split off the Redtail Splitfin recently by Domínguez-Domínguez et al. (2016). Affiliated to three river drainages, three subpopulations can be distinguished: The Río Mololoa subpopulation (type subpopulation), the Río Santa Rosa subpopulation and the Río Huicicila subpopulation. Xenotoca eiseni differs in many parametres from Xenotoca variata, the type species of the genus, means the Black Splitfin will be transfered in the future into a new to be erected genus.

The types Fitzsimons used in 1972 to describe Xenotoca melanosoma were collected by Miller and Huddle in the Río Tamazula (1968). Recent phylogenetic studies (Mar-Silva 2013) revealed, that populations from the Zapotlán lagoon north belong to a different and to be described species. From its affiliation to different drainages, eight subpopulations can be inferred: The Río Tuxpán subpopulation (type subpopulation), the Río El Terrero subpopulation and the Río Ayuquila subpopulation belong to X. melanosoma. The Laguna de Zapotlán subpopulation, the Laguna de Sayula subpopulation, the Laguna Atotonilco subpopulation, the Upper Río Ameca subpopulation and the Laguna de Magdalena subpopulation belong to this to be described species. Xenotoca melanosoma differs in many parametres from Xenotoca variata, the type species of the genus, means the Black Splitfin will be transfered in the future into a new to be erected genus.

The female Holotype of this species described as Platypoecilus quitzeoensis by Barton A. Bean (1898) was collected by E.W. Nelson in August 1892 from the Cuitzeo lake. Seth E. Meek, calling this species erronously Poecilia quitzeoensis, transfered it then into a by him for this species erected genus as Zoogoneticus quitzeoensis. The specimens from La Barca, Ocotlán (Chapala lake) he examined belong today to a different species (Zoogoneticus purhepechus), descibed in 2008. Affiliated to four different drainages, four subpopulations can be inferred: The Río Gande de Morelia subpopulation (type subpopulation), the Río Angulo subpopulation, the Laguna Yuriría subpopulation and the Middle Río Lerma subpopulation. The last two ones are Possibly Extinct.

This species was described based on a record from Phong Nha-Ke Bang misidentified as Trimeresurus kanburensis (Orlov et al. 2004). Grismer et al. (2008) suggested that the species should be transferred to Viridovipera on the basis of morphological evidence. This change is supported by the molecular analysis of Dawson et al. (2008), who specifically investigated the phylogenetic position of this species and provided more detailed justification for transferring the species to Viridovipera.
The species was described in 2004, although specimens are known since 1962 (Leong & Grismer 2004).

G. mukutense has been recently described and differs from all other species of the Gongylosoma genus in having a single, enlarged, posterior temporal; chinshields of equal size, and a thin nuchal band that contacts a vestigial vertebral stripe (Grismer et al. 2003).
This a species described from the highlands of Peninsular Malaysia (Vogel et al. 2004) from within the Trimeresurus popeorum complex.
This species was long recognized in the genus Trimeresurus. It has sometimes been confused with T. venustus and T. purpureomaculatus (see David et al. 2004; Malhotra and Thorpe 2004).
The species is known from the type series of six specimens and one doubtful record from Singapore (Grandison 1978). This uncertain record has not been included in the current assessment.

authority: Kuch, Kizirian, Truong, Lawson, Donnelly & Mebs, 2005

taxonomicNotes: This small reddish brown snake is the sole member of its genus.
The species was recently described to science (Slowinski and Wüster 2000).

Some populations along the eastern shores of S Vicente and along the south-western coast of the nearby island of Santa Luzia that were originally considered as C. murichae Röckel, Rolán & Monteiro, 1980, may need to be re-classified as C. lugubris (Monteiro et al 2004). However, this has not been confirmed and is not reflected in this assessment.

Determined by Filmer to be a valid species (Filmer 2001), but disputed by Tucker who considers this species to be a synonym of Conus anemone Lamarck, 1810 (Appeltans et al. 2011), also disputed by Morrison and Singleton who consider it as probably the northern form of C. anenome (H. Morrison pers comm 2011).
Conus dealbatus was listed as a synonym of this species in error; this has been removed from the synonym on this record (M. J. Tenorio pers. comm. 2011).

This species is part of a species complex including C. reductaspiralis and C. nielsenae.  It appears that this species is the eastern Australian member of the complex while the two species above are western Australian species.

Determined by Filmer and Singleton to be a valid species (Filmer 2001, Singleton 2009), but disputed by Tucker who considers this species to be a synonym of Conus nielsenae reductaspiralis Walls, 1979 (Appeltans et al. 2011).

Despite being in dispute this species is assessed as a valid species in terms of conservation.
There is uncertainty with the taxonomic name of this species.  Tucker considers its true name to be Conus bruguieri Kiener, 1848 (Appeltans et al 2011) from the WoRMS database.

There is a separate population on the Gorée Island at the southern tip of the Dakar peninsular, that is currently under review, as it may be a distinct form, and results of the molecular analysis may assist to determine the status of these populations (E. Monnier pers. comm, 2011).

Two subspecies are recognised: C. anabathrum anabathrum Crosse, 1865 and C. anabathrum burryae Clench, 1942 (Tucker, 2010).

Petuch and Sargent (2011) consider C. burryae to be a separate full species. Conus anabathrum tranthami, previously considered a synonym, has also now been shown to be a valid sub-species from the coral reefs of the Florida Keys.

Note: This species has been assessed as C. anabathrum without the range of C. burryae which will have a separate later assessment as a valid species.

This species has been recently classified into the subgenus Quasiconus (Tucker and Tenorio 2009), together with the closely related species Conus tuticorinensis which is found in Southern India, which suggests this may be a relictual species (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).

There is a population on another island (Maio) that is currently known as C. ateralbus, however, at present this has been discounted from the conservation assessment until better data is available on the status of the population (Manuel J Tenorio, pers. comm. 2011).
.
The closest relative of this species occurs in southeastern Australian waters (C. papiliferus), which suggests that this may be a relictual species (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).

Populations of Callulina from the Nguru Mountains were historically assigned to C. kreffti, as then understood a widespread East African montane species and the sole member of the genus. Menegon et al. (2008) recognized four distinct species among Nguru Mountains Callulina, two of which have since been formally described (Loader et al. 2010). One of these, C. kanga, appears to be restricted to the Kanga Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008, Loader et al. 2010). The remaining three species are confined to blocks within the Nguru South Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008, Loader et al. 2010). The name C. hanseni refers to "Callulina sp. 2" of these authors (Loader et al. 2010); the remaining populations are included within the Red List account for C. kreffti pending further research.

This species, first recorded in 2004, was first reported in the literature by Menegon et al. (2008), who listed it as "Callulina sp. 4"; it was also referred to as such, referencing this then-unpublished paper, in the technical report by Doggart and Loserian (2007).  Populations of Callulina from the nearby Nguru South Forest Reserve, now found to represent three distinct species, were originally included within the presumed widespread, monotypic C. kreffti (Loader et al. 2010). In contrast, the Kanga Forest Reserve form appears never to have been explicitly included within this species concept, having only been discovered after doubts arose concerning the monophyly of C. kreffti (de Sá et al. 2004).
This species was previously included within Callulina kreffti, formerly considered to be a monotypic species widespread throughout the Eastern Arc Mountains. (Loader et al. 2010).
This species was previously included within Callulina kreffti, formerly considered to be a monotypic species widespread throughout the Eastern Arc Mountains. (Loader et al. 2010).
This species was previously included within Callulina kreffti, formerly considered to be a monotypic species widespread throughout the Eastern Arc Mountains. (Loader et al. 2010).

Several genetic experiments have suggested that Takifugu chinensis and T. rubripes are very closely related and can possibly be regarded as the same species (Reza et al. 2011). In China, T. chinensis is considered to be a junior synonym of Takifugu pseudommus. However, differences in the anal fin color of these two species makes it unlikely that they are the same species (Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). Skull structure of the two species is identical, however, and therefore further taxonomic studies are required. The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). We accept the taxonomic validity of T. chinensis.
This species was described in 2002, and little information exists about it.
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008)

This species was recently described based on southern Vietnamese records formerly attributed to Cryptelytrops macrops (Malhotra et al. 2011). The identity of a Vietnamese record from Phu Quoc of a viper in the C. macrops complex requires clarification, as this subpopulation may belong to either C. cardamomensis or C. rubeus. Although this record is not included in either this account or that for C. cardamomensis pending clarification, biogeographic affinities suggest this record is most likely to represent C. cardamomensis (B. Stuart and L. Grismer pers. comm. September 2011).
Cnemaspis otai was described based on specimens collected from Vellore, Tamil Nadu (Das and Bauer 2000).

Hemidactylus albofasciatus was described by Grandison and Soman in 1963 based on specimens collected from Dorle, Rajapur taluk, Ratnagiri district, Maharashtra, India (Grandison and Soman 1963).
