Hallgass (pers. com. 2011)has recently detected Helix pantanellii De Stefani, 1879 at its type locality Monte Fionchi (less than 20 km distant from the Monti Reatini) and found it similar to Monacha ruffoi in anatomical characters, but different in color and form of aperture. This opens the possibility that M. ruffoi might be a local summit form of M. pantanellii.
Originally described as Helix (Helicodon) arridens R.T. Lowe, 1831.

Prieto (1986) and Puente (1994) considered this a synonym of Helicella itala (Linnaeus 1758). Nevertheless, Gittenberger and Carr (2002) after the finding of a second population consider that H. valdeona is a valid species, differring from H. itala by conchological and anatomical characters.
This group was revised in Mordan and Martins (2001).

Gasull (1964) and other authors considered X. cardonae as a junior synonym of X. nyeli. However, Quintana and Vilella (2001) consider it is a valid species. Molecular studies are necessary to confirm this taxonomic situation.
The anatomical structure of the species is unknown, therefore the generic status of the species is questionable (Hausdorf 1996).
This species is considered a taxon separate from Acicula lallemanti (Bourguignat, 1864) (Boeters et al. 1989).

Gittenberger (2004) treated Arianta xatartii as a subspecies of Arianta arbustorum. But Bank et al. (2006) still consider it as a valid species. Gittenberger first (2001) considered it as a species, later as a subspecies (2004), but after having re-analyzed the data he now (2007) again considers it a species (personal communication to Ruud Bank, not published). The main reasoning is because of the the geological history.
F. Welter-Schultes question the validity of this species.
This is a replacement name for Helix canariensis Mousson, 1872 (see Seddon and Aparicio 1998).
The monotypic subgenus Polloneriella (Alzona & Alzona Bisacchi, 1940) has been elevated to the rank of a full genus (Giusti and Manganelli 1998).

In contrast to Zilch (1952), who divided the Sardinian Tacheocampylaea's in the polytypic species carotii with the subspecies carotii s. str. and T. carotii melonii and T. gennarii as distinct species, the Italian checklist (Manganelli et al. 1995) and Fauna Europaea treat all Sardinian populations as one species under the name T. carotii.

Morelet (1860) extended the range of L. azorica to Santa Maria as variety γ minor, which Backhuys (1975) elevated to subspecific level. van Riel et al. (2005), using molecular data, found evidence for specific separation of the populations from Santa Maria. Backhuys (1975) states the type locality as “Azores, Santa Maria, Ribeira Almagreira”; however, just after that statement, the author mentions the 2 specimens from Pico Alto as “paratypes”. Ribeiro, Almagreira is at the footsteps of Pico Alto; for that reason, although confusing, this locality imprecision is not worth correcting.

This species was described by Arrébola and Gómez (1998) as belonging to the genus Chondrina using shell and anatomic features. Morphological and genetic studies confirm that this species belongs to this genus (Kokshoorn and Gittenberger 2010) and not to the genus Rupestrella as indicated by other authors.

Fauna Europaea lists this taxon as a separate species. According to Fiorentino et al. (2010), it is a junger synonym of T. villicus. Earlier K. L. Pfeiffer (1946) proposed that T. sardonius should be treated as a subspecies of T. villicus. According to the assessors of this species, this view should be retained. However, as the taxon is listed as a species in its own rights in Fauna Europea, it is here assessed as such.

This is a polytypic species with two subspecies: T. romagnolii romagnolii (Dutailly, 1867), and T. r. deschampsiana (Hagenmüller, 1888).
T. romagnolii romagnolii: Hélice de Corte
T. romagnolii deschampsiana: Hélice de la Tartagine [note: the subspecies does not occur in the Tartagine valley as could be presumed from the common name].

This species has been treated as a variation of Canariella hispidula by Ibanez et al. (1995). However, currently this form is considered as a separate species (Bank et al. 2002). This species is polytypic and comprises the nominal subspecies and C. fortunata beata Wollaston, 1878.
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands have been treated by Valido et al. (1999).

This is a  polytypic species with two subspecies besides the nominotypical subspecies: T. acropachia pollonerae (Caziot, 1903) and T. acropachia garciai (Hagenmüller, 1888).
According to recent research (Falkner ined.) the populations in the north-west of the total distribution area adjacent to the Monte Cardo, which have been described as Helix (Campylaea) venacensis Caziot, 1903, form a well characterised distinct species which has wrongly been treated as a synonym of T. a. acropachia.
This species has been revalidated by Falkner et al. (2002). Its taxonomic validity needs to be fully investigated, especially at the molecular level.

Walden (1983) recognized a varietal name used by Wollaston, Caseolus commixtus var. pusilla, as meriting specific status, giving it the name baixoensis. Seddon (2008) reports difficulty separating Caseolus baixoensis Walden, 1983 and Caseolus compactus vigiae Walden, 1983, and in the absence of type material of the latter considered that these may be conspecific.
Theba impugnata was previously named Helix impugnata.
The authorship is cited as: (Fra' Piero [Arbanasich, P.], 1897) by Manganelli and Giusti (2005) and as ([Arbanasich, P.], 1897) by Giusti et al. (2011).

Arianta chamaeleon is a polytypic species. However, the taxonomic status of these subspecies is problematic. The currently accepted subspecies are: Arianta chamaeleon chamaeleon (L. Pfeiffer, 1868), A. chamaeleon carnica (Ehrmann, 1910), A. chamaeleon wiedemayri (Kobelt, 1903), A. chamaeleon subglobosa (Ehrmann, 1910) and A. chamaeleon tullina (Ehrmann, 1910).
The taxon has been defined by a Lectotype designation by Giannuzzi-Savelli et al. (1986).
Theba grasseti was previously named Helix grasseti.

According to Kokshoorn and Gittenberger (2010) there is one subspecies described: Rupestrella occulta gibilfunnensis (De Gregorio, 1895) (the type locality is the Gibilforni mountain, near Palermo, in Sicily, Italy). According to www.animalbase.org the species needs to be revised.
This species was formerly included within Podarcis erhardii.

authority: Lymberakis, Poulakakis, Kaliontzopoulou, Valakos and Mylonas, 2008

taxonomicNotes:
The Domestic Sheep and its wild ancestor the Urial are treated here as separate species (following inter alia Shackleton 1997), called Ovis aries and Ovis orientalis respectively. These taxa are sometimes considered to be conspecific, in which case the name Ovis orientalis has generally been used to refer to the wild species and its domesticated form, although some authors use the name Ovis aries for both the wild species and its domestic descendants (see Gentry et al. 1996, BZN 2003, Gentry et al. 2004 and Wilson and Reeder 2005).

"Wild sheep" and "wild goats" found on Mediterranean islands are generally recognized to have been introduced by humans (Shackleton 1997, Wilson and Reeder 2005), and genetic and archaeozoological studies suggest that they are feral populations of ancient domestic stocks (e.g., Groves 1989, Vigne 1994, Hiendleder et al. 1998, Manceau et al. 1999, Kahila bar-Gal et al. 2002). Consequently, such taxa should be included in the respective domestic species (Capra hircus, Ovis aries) and not as subspecies of the wild taxa (as proposed by Gentry et al. 1996, Gentry et al. 2004, and Gippoliti and Amori 2004).

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species,  but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.
According to Dolin (1988), this species is a synonym of  A. nigerrimus, but Lobl and Smetana (2007) regard  A. brunnicornis and A. nigerrimus as two separate species.
Leipaspis lauricola has two subspecies: L. l. lauricola Wollaston, 1862 and L. l. gomerensis Wollaston, 1862 (Plata-Negrache and Prendes-Ayala 1981).
In the Melanophryniscus moreirae group according to the original description (Maneyro et al. 2008).
Appeared in the IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006 under the generic name Paralabidochromis.

Diagnostic features include pelvic fin tips which do reach the first dorsal origin, angular pelvic, dorsal and caudal fins, and a upper lip arch which is semi-oval in shape. This species does not possess distinct ocelli or midback spines. This poorly known species is often misidentified as S. formosa, but in a revision of this genus Walsh and Ebert (2007) resolved some of the characteristics between these two species. Some of the confusion resulted from the original description of S. formosa which was partially based on three designated paratypes that were all in fact S. nebulosa.

authority: Barbosa du Bocage & de Brito Capello, 1864
taxonomicNotes: Scarcity of data for Centrophorus lusitanicus comes mainly from the taxonomic controversy of the genus Centrophorus and its probable confusion in many cases with other species in the area such as C. granulosus and C. uyato. Although some authors considered C. lusitanicus as synonymous with the two former species, recent morphometric and genetic studies confirm the validity of this species (White et al. 2013). Data from general books about the species must therefore be taken with caution.

It differs from the only other recognised member of the genus, P. sephen, in having a smaller adult size, more elongate disc and head, longer and more acute snout covered to its apex with enlarged denticles, more posteriorly located sting, longer and more slender ventral cutaneous fold, enlarged pearl-shaped nuchal thorns, and fewer pectoral-fin radials and vertebrae (Last et al. 2005).
Similarity of morphology among mobulids may account for common misidentifications of this ray.

This species needs additional material collected to critically compare it in greater detail to other angel sharks (Walsh and Ebert 2007). Diagnostic features include pelvic fin tips which do not reach the first dorsal origin, and distinct large ocelli on the pelvic fins (Walsh and Ebert 2007). Nasal barbels also appear particularly ornate compared to other Northwest and Western Central Pacific Squatinids (Walsh and Ebert 2007).
McEachran and Dunne (1998) moved this species from genus Raja to Amblyraja.

Diagnostic features include pelvic fin tips which do not reach the first dorsal origin, and spines along the midback line. This species like other regional Squatinids are poorly known taxonomically and are often misidentified. See Walsh and Ebert (2007) for recent revision of this genus in the western North Pacific.

The taxonomy of Lamiopsis has recently been resolved with White et al. (2010) resurrecting and redescribing Lamiopsis trephrodes from South-east Asia, and Akhilesh et al. (2016) redescribing Lamiopsis temminckii from the Arabian Sea. This species is potentially endemic to the Arabian Sea, however, further taxonomic work is required in the Bay of Bengal to determine if this species occurs there or if recorded specimens refer to L. tephrodes.

Until recently (Compagno et al. 2005), the species was classified as a species dubium in the genus Carcharhinus (Compagno 1988). Some have considered it to be a synonym of G. gangeticus but this is incorrect and it is a clearly distinct Glyphis species (L.J.V. Compagno pers. comm. 2007).

Sympatric to the Little Skate, immature specimens of the two species are often confused, especially females. However, chance of misidentification decreases as they mature. Disk is rounded, with many small dark spots on upper surface. Usually 1-4 ocelli are found on the upper surface on each side of disk, each with a dark brownish center and pale edge. Young have long middorsal row of large spines on disk and tail. Upper jaw has 72 rows of teeth. Lower surface is usually white but marked with irregular pale brownish blotches (although this colouration is found in several other species within range).

This species was previously referred to as a sub-population of H. regani (occurring off KwaZulu-Natal and southern Mozambique). A revision of the genus Holohalaelurus has shown that this species is in fact distinct from H. regani (Human 2006). Specimens of H. favus were first referred to and illustrated by Bass et al. (1975).

Previously considered a "Natal" form of Haploblepharus edwardsii (Schinz, 1822) by Bass et al. (1975) and subsequent authors, H. kistnasamyi has a colour pattern that superficially resembles, although is distinct from, that of H. edwardsii, and also differs in morphological features (Human and Compagno 2006). DNA Barcoding confirms that H. kistnasamyi is distinct from H. edwardsii and other Haploblepharus species (K. Geldhill, unpubl. data, 2018).
Ishihara et al. (2012) established the new genus Beringraja for the two species B. binoculata  (previously Raja binoculata Girard, 1855) and B. pulchra (previously Raja pulchra Liu 1932).
The revision of the genus Holohalaelurus showed that H. polystigma is a junior synonym of H. punctatus (Human 2006).

Judging from its original description (Day 1878), Hemigaleus balfouri is apparently a synonym of this species; unfortunately, the holotype is lost. Apparently this name has been used indiscriminately for the three species of hemigaleids in Indo-Pakistani waters other than Hemipristis elongatus (Compagno pers. comm.). This species is probably confused with Hemipristis elongata throughout its range.

This is a recently described species (described in 2005 by White, Last & Dharmadi). It probably gets confused with Atelomycterus marmoratus which is more widespread in the region and co-occurs off the island of Bali.
Paraphlebia may not belong to the family Megapodagrionidae, but may instead be related to the Costa Rican/Panamanian Thaumatoneura, which has been given its own family by some authors.
P. h. bella is the variety maintained in the breeding programme.
There are two subspecies: P. s. strigosa (Pfeiffer), P. t. vexillum (Pease).
Three subspecies are recognized by Crampton (1932) and Johnson, Murray and Clarke (1993): P. t. elongata (Pease), P. t. nucleola, and P. t. simulans. Only P. t. elongata is extant in the wild.
A subspecies, P. f. subangulata, now extinct, was previously found on the neighbouring island of Tahaa.
Reclassified by Crampton (1916) as Partula otaheitana affinis. Reinstated as Partula affinis by Johnson, Murray and Clarke (1986).

Has always been considered a distinct species but DNA analysis suggests that it may be a colour morph of Partula hyalina and as such remains a candidate for merging. Populations in one valley are genetically distinct.

This species was the only multi-island, multi-arhchipelago partulid species known in French Polynesia. It is now believed to be endemic to Tahiti and was likely transported to the other islands as part of shell trade. Partula clara may be a colour morph of this white species.
This species was proposed as Partula affinis nodosa (Kondo and Burch 1983) but has remained as Partula nodosa.

This species has controversial taxonomy made more confusing by widespread extinctions of varieties. It is likely that more than one species is involved. Eight subspecies are recognised by Crampton (1916); maybe two are extant in the wild.
This species was incorrectly identified as Partula garretti in the breeding programme.
This species was confused with Partula clarkei. P. turgida probably became extinct in the 1990s. The captive population was P. clarkei.
The status of this species has been disputed and Johnson, Murray and Clarke (1992) believed that it may have been a sinistral variety of P. affinis, however this similarity is only superficial.

This species was previously recorded as Elattoneura bigemmata Lieftinck, 1971 due to lack of type specimens and possible misidentication. E. bigematta is now a junior synonym (according to the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature) of the older, valid name E. oculata.

The original description was by J.A.L Watson, in Watson et al. (1991). The holotype was a male from Koongarra, 1252’S, 132 50’E, 15 km east Mount Cahill, Northern Territory, 6-10 March 1973, collected by Dr J.A.L. Watson. Larval description Hawking (1993).
Orr & Hämäläinen (2013) placed specimens from Brunei and Sarawak that had previously treated as P. triangularis into two new species, leaving only the holotype female under the name P. triangularis.

A poorly known species; the only published records are from a small area of west Java. G.T. Reels and this assessor (R. Dow) found what appears to be this species at Bako National Park in west Sarawak, Malaysia in 2005 (R. Dow pers. obs. 2008). Confirmation of the identity of material from Bako awaits detailed comparison against the type series, but agreement with the original description is good, except in size and for minor details of colouration; such differences might be expected given the distance between the populations.

Asahina (1981, 1985) recorded Bayadera longicauda from Doi Inthanon, based on a male missing the terminal segments of the abdomen (making certain identification impossible). Hämäläinen and Pinratana (1999) note that Asahina's material is probably B. hyalina, recorded on Doi Inthanon with some regularity.
This species was treated as Schmidtiphaea schmidi Asahina, 1978 until 2003 when Hämäläinen described Cryptophaea.

Libellago andamanensis was originally described as a good species by Fraser, it was later downgraded to a subspecies of L. lineata (Burmeister, 1839). Later Hämäläinen (2002) re-examined Libellago species from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, and restored amdananensis to full specific status.
This species was transferred to Sarasaeschna by Karube and Yeh in 2001. Although there is no dispute as to this placement, the genus Sarasaeschna has not been widely recognised as yet.

Prior to 2003 this species was treated as C. confusa Hagen in Sélys, 1859 (e.g. Asahina 1985, 1990; Hämäläinen and Pinratana 1999). In 2003 Hämäläinen described the population from northern Thailand as a separate species, C. angka.

A subspecies, P. k. satoi Asahina, 1997 has been described from north Viet Nam. However P. k. satoi was described from a single female; given the similarity of many species of Protosticta to one another, this female is as likely to belong to some other, unnamed, species as to a subspecies P. khaosoidaoensis. Until males are discovered, records from Viet Nam should be treated as unverified.
Part of the material published under the name of Procordulia irregularis (Martin, 1907), P. sambawana (Martin, 1907) or P. sambawana (Lieftinck, 1953) refers to this species (van Tol, 1997).

authority: Baran, Kumlutaş, Lanza, Sindaco, Ilgaz, Avci & Crucitti, 2005

taxonomicNotes: This taxon has previously been recognised as a subspecies of Phrynocephalus helioscopus.
This species has sometimes been included in Montivipera raddei.
We provisionally follow Melnikov et al. (2008) in considering Phrynocephalus horvathi to be distinct at the species level pending additional taxonomic studies.
This species was elevated to species status from Vipera ursinii anatolica by Nilson and Andrén (2001).

This species is one of many small Hydrobids that can be most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system, however these species are in urgent need of a review incorporating conchological characters, anatomical characters and molecular characters in order to understand the relationships with other taxa (Haase et al. 2007). The species was recently described based on shell characters and some reproductive anatomy, but requires molecular systematics to confirm relationships with other allied taxa.

Although some may consider that the nomenclature of the species is wrongly typed in the SIS and that kathrini should be the name, Glöer (pers. comm. 2010) notes that because it is named after Katrin (female) the name must be katrinae and a correction published in Mollusca 26(1):2.
The placement of this species in the genus Hauffenia is based on shell characters and requires further research (Eross and Petro 2008)

authority: Corbella, Alba, Tarruella Ruestes, Prate & Guillen Mestre, 2006
taxonomicNotes: This newly described species will require further studies to confirm relationships with other species from this complex genus, as currently it is only known from shells and although fresh shells were collected, no living specimens have been.

This species is a cryptic species as it was originally included within the variability of a closely related species Bythinella opaca, and was described as Bythinella opaca (Frauenfeld, 1857) not Bythinella opaca (Gallenstein 1848) (Haase et al. 2007). This is clearly a genus whose taxonomy can only be unravelled by an integrative approach combining morphology, anatomy, biogeography, and genetics (Haase et al. 2007).

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species, but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.

Although Fauna Europaea (Bank et al. 2006) lists the distribution as Balearic Islands (Mallorca Island, Menorca Island and Pityuses Islands) and Spain (mainland), Martinez-Orti (pers. comm. 2009) lists the range as mainland only and restricts the range to Andalucia. According to Martinez-Orti (pers. comm., 2009) it is now only known from Rio Guadalquivir at the junction with the tributaries near Sevilla. The records from other regions, Murcia and Valencia, are considered to be potentially different species.
Brown is happy that there are three taxa in this genus, though recommends a revision of the taxonomy.
Glyptothorax poonaensis was described by Hora (1938) as Glyptothorax conirostre poonaensis.

Schismatorhynchos nukta was originally described as Cyprinus nukta by Sykes (1839) from Indrayani river near Mahalunge, Maharashtra, India. Day (1872) changed the generic status of the fish to Labeo, while Hora (1942) changed the generic status of the fish to Schismatorhynchos.
The other names are as follows: Margarya melanioides var. Mansuyi .
Botia rostrata which was earlier considered a junior synonym of B. almorhae has been treated valid by Ng (2007) thereby replacing the so far known B. almorhae from the Brahmaputra basin.

Sen and Nalbant in Singh et al. (1982) described Physoschistura elongata from Barapani near Shillong, Meghalaya (Brahmaputra basin), India.  It is considered as a valid species by Kottelat et al. 2007.
Hora (1921) described Nemachilus prashadi from Thoubal and Sikmai streams, Manipur, India. Kottelat (1990) considers this species under the genus Schistura.
Barman (1983) described Danio horai from Namdapha National park. Fang (2001) treated it under the genus Devario.
McClelland (1839) described Cobitis pavonacea from Assam. Grant (2007) placed the species under Nemacheilus.
Tilak and Hussain (1990) described Barilius dimocurphis from Rajaji National Park, Eastern Doon Valley, Uttarakhand, India.

The species was described from Namdapha wildlife sanctuary (Arunachal Pradesh). The validity of the species is doubtful as it is similar to A. garoensis Hora in many respects except for its slender body (its body depth 7.7-8.0 vs 6.4-7.1 times in standard length). The region has two closely similar species, viz., A. elongatus Hora and A. kempi Chaudhuri and it needs proper verification. However, pending further study, we treat the species as valid. These species occur syntopically in many areas of Arunachal Pradesh.

Though Roberts (1997) considered mrigala a synonym of this species, it is observed that both are quite distinct. C. cirrhosus has four barbells whereas mrigala has only two barbells; dorsal branched rays are 15-16 in cirrhosus vs. 12-13 in mrigala.
Chaudhuri (1912) described Labeo almorae from Almorha District, western Himalaya, Uttar Pradesh, northern India. The species is under genus Bangana (Doi 1997).

Glyptothorax saisii was originally described as Glyptosternum saisii by Jenkins (1910) Sita Nullah stream, Paresnath Hills, Jharkhand. Subsequently, Glyptothorax coheni was described from Subarnarekha River, Chotanagpur Plateau, Jharkhand (Ganguly et al. 1972), which is now synonymized to Glyptothorax saisii (Thomson and Page 2006).

In 2001 according to molecular evidence, Peromyscus dickeyi was considered a subspecies of P. merriami (Hafner et al 2001). Until further evidence demonstrates this it is still a full species (Cornejo-Latorre et al 2017).

Originally described under the genus Cyprinus as Cyprinus semiplotus by McClelland (1839) from the Brahmaputra River, Assam. Day (1878) described the species as Semiplotus mcclellandi. Hora (1937) described the same as Semiplotus semiplotus. On the basis of its jaw anatomy, Howes (1982) placed the genus Semiplotus Bleeker under Cyprinion Heckel. Talwar and Jhingran (1991) recognised Semiplotus as subgenus of Cyprinion without justification. However, Banarescu and Herzig (1995) recognised Semiplotus as distinct genus, as it has more branch dorsal fin rays than Cyprinion. Sen (1985), Jayaram (1999), Vishwanath and Kosygin (2000), Bagra et al. (2009) recognised the fish as Semiplotus semiplotus.
Carinotetraodon travancoricus was described as Tetraodon (Monotretus) travancoricus from Pamba river, Kerala, India (Hora and Nair 1941).
Pillaia indica was described from Sumer stream, about 22 km north of Shillong, Khasi and Jaintia Hills, Meghalaya, India. In addition, there is one paratype from Umsing (at an altitude of 1524 m).

Originally described as Noemacheilus arunachalensis (Datta and Barman 1984) from Namdapha River, Namdapha Wildlife Sanctuary, Tirap District, Arunachal Pradesh, India, the species is currently placed in the genus Lepidocephalichthys.
Hora (1925) described Aborichthys garoensis from Tura, Garo Hills in Meghalaya, India.
Hora (1921) described Barilius dogarsinghi from Chindwin basin, Manipur. He doubted the inclusion of the species under Barilius as it has no mandibular knob, characteristic of the genus.
Hora (1921) described the species from Kanjupkhul Village, Manipur from where Nambul River originates, the type locality of the fish.
Lymnaea ovalior may be a synonym of Lymnaea luteola f. ovalis Gray (Subba Rao 1989) but this requires confirmation.
This species was described from a single female. A male has never been found.

p { margin-bottom: 0.25cm; direction: ltr; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 120%; }p.western { font-family: "Arial",sans-serif; font-size: 12pt; }p.cjk { font-family: "Times New Roman",serif; font-size: 12pt; }p.ctl { font-family: "Arial",sans-serif; font-size: 12pt; }

De acordo com Garutti & Britski (2000) o material tipo encontra-se perdido. Existem incertezas taxonômicas quanto a validade da espécie, dificultando sua identificação.

Six subspecies of this snail are recongized:

Stylodonta unidentata unidentata (Holten, 1802)
Stylodonta unidentata sebertae Gerlach, 2003
Stylodonta unidentata pyramidata (Pfeiffer, 1841)
Stylodonta unidentata globata (Martens, 1869)
Stylodonta unidentata praslina Gerlach, 2003
Stylodonta unidentata parva Gerlach, 2003
Two subspecies have been described: P. n. niger (Dufo, 1840) and P. n. subfuscus Gerlach, 1994.
This species recently changed genus, from Gulella to Glabrennea (Schileyko 2000).
This species recently changed genus, from Gulella to Glabrennea (Schileyko 2000).
This genus has not been formally assigned to a family; it has been tentatively placed in the family Gastrodontidae. There is one recognized synonym: Kaliella subturritula (Nevill & Nevill, 1878).
This genus has not been formally assigned to a family; it has been tentatively placed in the family Gastrodontidae.
This genus has not been formally assigned to a family; it has been tentatively placed in the family Gastrodontidae.
This is an undescribed species restricted to Aldabra atoll; its generic placement is uncertain.
This species is also described as Unio sp. A in Tchang-Si (1948).

Tchang-Si and Tsi, Chung-Yen named this species in their 1949 paper, regarding it as a subspecies. Xia (1982) reviewed the Margarya species in Lake Dianchi, and believed this to be a separate species. Xia is followed here.

Kosygin and Vishwanath (1998) described Garra compressa from Wanze Stream near Khamsom, Manipur, India. Kullander and Fang (2004) considered it as a valid species. It is listed as G. compressus by W. Eschmeyer, however G. compressa is thought to be the correct spelling for this species (M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2010).
Hora (1921) described Danio acuticephala  from Manipur. The species is put under Devario now (Fang 2001).

Vishwanath and Sarojnalini (1988) described Garra manipurensis from Manipur, India. The species is treated as valid by Vishwanath (1993), Jayaram (1999), Kullander and Fang (2004) and Nebeshwar et al. (2009).

Clarias magur was described by Hamilton (1822) from gangetic provinces.  The identity of the southern form of Clarias requires verification.  The range of distribution of Clarias batrachus is now restricted to Sunda Islands (type locality Java) (Ng and Kottelat 2008).

Pterocryptis barakensis was described from the Barak River by Vishwanath and Nebeshwar in Jayaram (2006).  The original description was scanty and the species was redescribed by Vishwanath and Nebeshwar (2009).

Amblyceps arunachalensis was described from the Dikrong River in Arunachal Pradesh, northeastern India (Nath and Dey 1989). This species was considered a junior synonym of A. mangois (Hamilton 1822) by Ng (2005) before Vishwanath and Linthoingambi (2007) revalidated the species.

Zhang (2005) described Garra bispinosa from the Daying Jiang, Yunnan, southern China. He revealed that Garra orientalis reported from the upper Irrawaddy River basin in Yunnan, southern China consisted of two distinct species namely, Garra salweenica Hora and Mukerji and Garra bispinosa which described as a new species (Zhang 2006).
Kullander and Fang (2004) described Garra flavatra from Rakhine Yoma, Myanmar. Nebeshwar et al. (2009) recognised it as a valid species.
Vishwanath (1993) described Garra litanensis from Manipur (Chindwin River basin), India. The species treated as valid by Kullander and Fang (2004) and Nebeshwar et al. (2009).
Vishwanath and Joyshree (2005) described Garra nambulica from Manipur, India. Vishwanath and Linthoingambi (2008) treated it as a valid species.
Vishwanath and Shanta Devi (2005) described Garra paralissorhynchus from Manipur, India. It is considered as valid by Vishwanath and Linthoingambi (2008).
Selim and Vishwanath (2002) described Barilius chatricensis from Chatrickong River (Chindwin basin), Manipur, India.
Vishwanath and Manojkumar (2002) described the species from Chindwin basin, Manipur, India.

Originally described under genus Chela as Chela khujairokensis by Arunkumar (2000). Placement under the genus Laubuca follows Pethiyagoda et al. (2008). Although they do not treat this species specifically ("species previously recognized as Chela Hamilton, 1822 from Sri Lanka are now recognized as belonging to the genus Laubuca"), they do restrict Chela as monotypic (only C. cachius). The current accepted name of the genus is Laubuka (Fricke et al. 2019).
Menon (1987) described Neomacheilus singhi from Kiphire, Nagaland, India. Currently, the species has been placed in the genus Schistura.

Tilak and Husain (1990) described Nemacheilus chindwinicus from Manipur, India (a tributary of the Chindwin River, Manipur). Later Vishwanath and Nebeshwar (2004) collected the fish from Brahmaputra basin in Manipur and treated under the genus Schistura; the taxonomic record of this specimen needs confirmation.  Tilak and Husain's (1990) naming the species as 'chindwinica' meaning a Chindwin species is probably a mistake. Its syntypes in Manipur University museum is from Barak drainage.
Sisor barakensis was described from the Brahmaputra River drainage in Manipur, India (Vishwanath and Darshan 2005).
Devario assamensis was described by Barman (1984) under the genus Danio. Fang (2001) treated it under the genus Devario.

Glyptothorax kashmirensis was described from the Jhelum River drainage in Kashmir Valley (Hora 1923). It has been recorded from the Ganges River drainage in Nepal, but this record awaits further verification.
Regan (1907) described Danio browni from Upper Myanmar. Fang (2001) treated it under the genus Devario.
Vishwanath & Nebeshwar Sharma (2004) described Schistura reticulata from Maklang River (Chindwin basin), Manipur in India.

Hora (1935) described Nemachilus rupecola inglisi from rivers below Darjeeling and in Sikkim, eastern Himalaya.  Menon (1987) included it under the synonym of Noemacheilus multifasciatus Day.  Subsequently the subspecies has been given a species status and included under Schistura by Banarescu and Nalbant (1995).
Vishwanath and Shantakumar (2006) described Schistura minutus from Iyei River, Manipur, Brahmaputra basin.  The species should be called minuta (Kottelet pers. comm.) and not minutus.
Conway et al. (2009) described the species from Bangladesh.

Glyptothorax manipurensis was described from the Barak River (a tributary of the Brahmaputra River) in Manipur, India (Menon 1955). It has been considered a junior synonym of G. sinense (e.g. Talwar and Jhingran 1991), but Kosygin and Vishwanath (2005) demonstrated its validity.
Singh & Bănărescu  in Singh et al. (1982) described Mesonoemacheilus reticulofasciatus from Barapani, near Shillong, Meghalaya, India. Kottelat et al. (2007) placed the species in Schistura.

Gymnocypris dobula was described from an unknown locality by Günther (1868). Wu and Wu (1992) recognize two subspecies, restricting the nominate G. dobula dobula to Peigu (Paiku) Lake, and recognizing the population from Chuocuolong Lake as a distinct subspecies, G. dobula chuoculongensis Tsao, Chen, Wu, Tsao, Chen and Zhu in Wu and Wu (1992).
Schistura tigrinum was described by Vishwanath and Nebeshwar 2005 from Barak River at Khunphung, Tamenglong District, Manipur, India.
Pseudecheneis sirenica was described from the Brahmaputra River drainage in Arunachal Pradesh, India (Vishwanath and Darshan 2007).
Kottelat et al. (2007) described the species from Synrang Pamiang cave system, Meghalaya, India.
Arunkumar and Tombi (1998) described Danio yuensis from Manipur. Fang and Kullander (2009) treated it under the genus Devario.
Pseudecheneis ukhrulensis was described from the Chindwin River drainage in India (Vishwanath and Darshan 2007).

Vishwanath and Manojkumar (1995) described Psilorhynchus microphthalmus from Chakpi Stream, Manipur, India.  Jayaram (1999), Vishwanath et al. (2007), Conway and Kottelat (2007), Arunachalam and Muralidharan (2008), Conway and Mayden (2008a,b) recognised it as valid species.
The species was described as Brachydanio jaintianensis by Sen (2007).  As Brachydanio is now junior synonym of Danio (Fang 2003), it is now valid as Danio jaintianensis.
Schizothorax integrilabiatus was described from Xigong Lake, an endorheic mountain lake in the lower Yarlung Zangbo River (Brahmaputra in India) drainage (Wu et al. in Wu and Wu 1992).
Chaudhuri (1912) described Danio naganensis from Manipur. Fang (2001) treated it under genus Devario.
Botia striata was described by Rao (1920) from Tunga River at Shimoga, Karnataka, India.

Menon (1987) described Noemacheilus nagaensis from Phodung River, tributary of Tizu River, Brahmaputra basin, Nagaland, India. Vishwanath and Laishram (2001) considered the species under genus Schistura.

Vishwanath and Shanta (2004a) described Schistura macrocephalus from the Khuga River, Churachandpur District, Manipur, India. Since it has been found to be junior homonym of Kottelat's species from Laos, it has been replaced by S. khugae (Vishwanath and Shanta 2004b).
This species is unique in the world by the extreme length of the male cerci, almost 30% of the abdomen length and 5 to 6 times as long as epiproct.
Nothobranchius symoensi was established as a species by Wildekamp in 1978, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
The Congolese specimens belong to a new species of Grasseichthys (Stiassny et al., 2007, Schelly and Britz, in prep.). G.gabonensis is restricted to the Ogowe/Ivindo basin.
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Glyptothorax davissinghi was described by Manimekalan and Das (1998) from the Karimpuzha and Paanapuzha tributaries of River Chaliyar, Kerala, India.
Tor khudree was described by Sykes (1839) as Barbus khudree from Mula Mutha river in Pune, India.
Hypselobarbus thomassi was described by Day (1874) from South Canara (Dakshin Kannada), Karnataka State, India.
Etroplus canarensis was described by Day (1865) from South Canara (currently Karnataka, India).
Pseudosphromenus dayi was originally described as Polyacanthus cupanus var. dayi by Köhler (1908) and the type locality of the fish is suggested as southern Kerala (Kottelat 1994 ).
Garra hughi was described by Silas (1955) from streams in the Lower Vauguvarrai Estate in the High Ranges of Travancore, Kerala, India.
Labeo potail was originally described as Cyprinus potail Sykes (1839) from Temburni on Bhima river, Maharashtra.
Monopterus fossorius was described by Nayar (1951) from Karamana, Trivandrum.
Hypselobarbus pulchellus was originally described as Barbus (Barbodes) pulchellus by Day (1870) from inland streams (probably in Mangalore), India.
Gagata itchkeea was described as Phractocephalus itchkeea by Sykes (1839) from Bhima River at Pairgaon, Maharashtra, India.
Nemacheilus petrubanarescui was described by Menon (1984) from Nethravati River, Karnataka, India.

authority: Samarawickrama, Ranawana, Rajapaksha, Ananjeva, Orlov, Ranasinghe & Samarawickrama, 2006
taxonomicNotes: There is considerable controversy over the priority of the names Cophotis dumbara Samarawickrama, Ranawana, Rajapaksha, Ananjeva, Orlov, Ranasinghe & Samarawickrama (2006) and Cophotis dumbarae Manamendra-Arachchi, de Silva & Amarasinghe (2006), with both names being published at very close dates. Hallermann and Böhme (2007) reviewed this issue, and determined that Cophotis dumbara (published on November 25, 2006) should take priority over Cophotis dumbarae (published on December 6, 2006).
Additional studies into the taxonomic status of this species are needed; it is sometimes placed within the genus Typhlops (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007).

The relationship between Cerberus microlepis and C. rynchops has been reviewed, suggesting that C. microlepis may not warrant species status, and may best be considered as an isolated freshwater population of C. rynchops (Karns et al. 2000, Alfaro et al. 2004). The taxonomic status of diagnosable clades within Cerberus are in the process of reevaluation (D. Karns, J. Murphy and H.Voris pers. comm. 2009).

There is a need for further examination of many specimens currently allocated to this species (e.g., those taken on Mindanao) to better determine their correct identification (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007).
This taxon might be a complex of three species; one from each of the islands from which it has been recorded.
Previously under the genus Eugongylus.

Blue Marlin (Makaira nigricans) of the Indo-Pacific and the Atlantic are conspecific (Buonaccorsi et al. 1999, 2001; Collette et al. 2006). The Indo-Pacific Blue Marlin previously was known as Makaira mazara (Jordan and Snyder).

This species was previously known as Tetrapturus albidus (Collette et al. 2006). There is a question as to whether this species is distinct from the Pacific Striped Marlin, Kajikia audax (Graves 1998, Collette et al. 2006, Hanner et al. 2011).
According to Fauna Europaea, Cochlostoma eupleurum Westerlund, 1885 is its junior synonym.

Wollaston (1878) considered macilenta as a separate species, although he noted that it could be a variety of Leiostyla recta. Pilsbry (1922–6) and Waldén (1983) listed the taxa as a subspecies. Cameron and Cook (1999) treat this as a species rather than a subspecies. Seddon (2008) noted the there are differences in shell form and size, and given that the two taxa are present on different islands it seems to be grounds to maintain these two forms as different taxa.
This species was described from the Hanoi area and northern Viet Nam. It may be only a variety of Cristaria plicata but more work needs to be done.

Simpson (1900) listed the original combination as Unio (Quadrula) blaisei Dautzenberg and H. Fischer with a type locality as Bas Luc-Nam village of Van-Ien, Tonkin. Simpson (1914) listed this as Quadrula (Lamprotula) blaisei (Dautzenberg and H. Fischer,1905). Haas (1969) recognized the combination as Lamprotula blaisei and listed the distribution as Tonkin. Dang et al. (1980) lists this species from north Viet Nam and other data is from Cao Bang and Lang Son, Vietnam.

Simpson (1900, 1914)  placed Unio contritus Heude , 1881 as a junior synonym of Quadrula (Lamprotula) caveata (Heude, 1877) combining three similarly shaped taxa from China. Haas (1969) listed Unio contritus Heude , 1881 with a type locality as streams north of Po-yang, Kien -te-hien, China and listed as a junior synonym of Lamprotula leai (Gray, 1834). Dang et al. (1980) recognized this as a valid species from Ha Tay and Bac Thai provinces.

Simpson (1900) erected the genus Gibbosula with this species as the type species. Simpson (1914) also recognized Gibbosula crassa (Wood, 1815). Haas (1969) recognized Lamprotula crassa (Wood, 1815) placing Gibbosula as as junior synonym of Lamprotula and included Unio (Quadrula) mansuyi Dautzenberg and H. Fischer (1908) as a junior synonym. Thannh et al. (1980) used the combination Gibbosula crassa and also included U. mansuyi as a synonym.

Simpson (1914) listed this species as Quadrula (Lamprotula) liedtkei  (Rolle, 1904) and the type locality as Riviere Claire, Tonkin, Vietnam. Haas (1969) used this species as a junior synonym of Mya nodulosa Wood, 1815 in the genus Lamprotula. Dang et al. (1980) recognized both L. liedtkei and L. nodulosa as separate valid species. There is taxonomic uncertainty about if this an distinct species or a synonym Lamprotula nodulosa (Wood) (Hass 1969).

Simpson (1914) used Lamprotula nodulosa (Wood, 1815)  and Lamprotula liedtkei (Rolle, 1904) as a separate species. Haas (1969) placed L. liedtkei in the synonymy of L. nodulosa. Dang et al. (1980) recognized both as valid species.

Unio (Quadrula) leai var. ponderosa Dautzenber & H. Fischer, 1905 was erected as a variety of Lamprotula leai (Gray, 1834) and is not the same as Mya pondersoa Dellwyn, 1817 which is considered by Haas (1969) as a junior synonym of Lamprotula crassa (Wood, 1815). Dang et al. (1980) elevated the  variety to species status and considered it separate from L. leai. Although this assessment treats it as a valid species, it it likely that this is probably only a variety of L. leai.
It has been used as a subspecies of Lanceolaria oxyrhyncha Von Martens, 1902 of Japan (http://fada.biodiversity.be/) (Haas 1969).

The type specimens of Unio messageri do not match the species recorded from Viet Nam, although they come from the same locality. These are possibly two species under the same heading. This assessment refers to the more recently described of the two species.
U. tumidiformis has been a neglected species in Spain and Portugal and replaces U. crassus in the southern Iberian Peninsula (Araujo in: Barea-Azcón 2008).

Originally placed by Rolán (1993), as part of Alzoniella pyrenaica. The species has similar conchological characters, but differs anatomically in characters of the bursa copulatrix and the receptaculum (Arconada et al. 2007).

Morton et al. (1998) reviewed the status of this genus, and noted that although many had considered the genus to be extinct, there was still one extant species in the cave systems in Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia & Hercegovina. They regarded this species as a ‘living fossil’, as the species is a single representative of a genus that once had many species during Tertiary times.

This species has not been redefined since originally collected by Clessin, until recent work by Gloer and Beran (2009) confirmed that the taxon differs from Bithynia tentaculata and Bithynia mostarensis.

This species has been recently described by Ruiz et al. (2009). According to these authors, the main feature characterizing the shell of O. mariae is the relation between the umbilicus and the shell diameter (1/8), the smallest in the Oestophora Iberian group in common with O. granesae (Arrébola 1998). Considering this, even the presence of the palatal tooth and the slight enlargement of the basal edge, are not comparable with the teeth of O. barbula (nor with the tooth of O. barbella), the only Iberian Oestopohora species with this kind of modifications on the aperture. Small morphological differences (including the relation umbilicus/shell diameter aforementioned) and biogeographical issues also distinguish this species from other North African's Oestophora. However, further studies (molecular, anatomical, etc.) must confirm the identity of all of them.

Horalabiosa joshuai was first described by Silas (1953) from the rainforest streams of Tambraparni River, Singampatti, Tirunelveli, Tamil Nadu, India. Talwar and Jhingran (1991) placed it under Garra lamta. The taxonomic identity was in question until it was revalidated by Devi (1992).

Nemachilichthys shimogensis was described by Rao (1920) from Tunga River, Shimoga, Karnataka. There is an ambiguity regarding the taxonomic validity of this species. Menon (1987, 1999) and Talwar and Jhingran (1991) synonymised the species with Nemchilichthys ruppelii (Sykes 1841). However, Banarescu and Nalbant (1995) treated the species as seperately as N. shimogensis.
Travancoria elongata was described by Pethiyagoda and Kottelat (1994) from Vettilapara, 26 km upstream of Chalakkudy town, Kerala, southern India.
Devario fraseri was first desribed by Hora and Mukerji (1935) from the Waldevi and Darna rivers, Deolali, Nasik District in Maharashtra, India.

Parapsilorhynchus discophorus was described by Hora (1921) from Pophli in the Vashishti valley, Ratnagiri district, Maharashtra. Menon (1999) considered this species as a synonym of Parapsilorhynchus tentaculatus following Hora (1925). However, this synonymy is invalid because P. discophorus is distinctly different from P. tentaculatus (Yazdani and Rao 1977, Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Jayaram 1999).
Homaloptera montana was first described by Herre (1941) from a brook flowing through the Puthuthottam estate in Valparai, Anamalai Hills, Tamil Nadu, India.

Batasio sharavatiensis was described by Bhat and Jayaram (2004) from Joginmatha, 1 km upstream of the Jog Falls in the west flowing Sharavati River, Karnataka. Arunachalam and Muralidharan (2007) reported a range extension of this species from the east flowing river Tunga. However, a comparison of their morphometric data and the photograph raises a doubt whether their specimens are conspecific with B. sharavatiensis sensu stricto. Until further taxonomic studies, including molecular methods, are available the report from Tunga is not considered for the assessment.

authority: (Jayaraj, Krishna Rao, Ravichandra Reddy, Shakuntala & Devaraj, 1999)
taxonomicNotes: Salmophasia belachi was originally described as Salmostoma belachi by Jayaraj et al. (1999) from Nelligudda reservoir, southern India.
Puntius deccanensis was described by Yazdani and Rao (1976) from Nalla near Katraj Tank, Pune, Maharashtra, India.

Nemacheilus pulchellus is described by Day 1873 from the Bhavani River at the base of the Nilgiris (India). In recent publications it has also placed in the genus Mesonemacheilus (e.g., Rema Devi and Indra 2002, Shaji 2002).
Crossocheilus periyarensis was described by Menon and Jacob (1996) from the upper reaches of the Periyar River at Thanikkudy, Kerala, India.
Nemacheilus menoni was described from Mlappara in the upper reaches of the Periyar River by Zacharias and Minimol (1999).
Garra menoni was first described by Remadevi and Indra (1981) from Walakkad in the upper reaches of Bharatapuzha River (Kunthi tributary) inside the Silent Valley National Park (Easa and Basha 1995).
Hypselobarbus periyarensis was described by Raj (1941) from Periyar Lake, Kerala, India
Homaloptera santhamparaiensis was described by Arunachalam et al (2002) from Panniyar stream of River Periyar, Idukki District, Kerala, India.
Horabagrus nigricollaris was described by Pethiyagoda and Kottelatt (1994) from Vettilapara on the Chalakudy River, 26 km upstream of Chalakudy Town, Kerala, India.
Garra kalakadensis was described by Rema Devi (1993) from Pachaiyar, east of Sengaltheri, Kalakad Wildlife Sanctuary, Tirunelveli District, Tamil Nadu.

Glyptothorax madraspatanus was described as Glyptosternum madraspatanum by Day (1873) from Bhavani River, Nilgiris, India. Record of this species from Mula-Mutha rivers of Pune (Kharat et al. 2003) are wrong as their specimen do not match with the type specimens (ZSI Kolkata F1235 and F1313) (N. Dahanuker, pers. obs.) and is likely to be an hitherto undescribed species. It is therefore likely that the other records of this species from Mula-Mutha river (Suter 1944, Tonapi and Mulherkar 1963, Wagh and Ghate 2003) are also wrong. Since this species is habitat specialist, it is likely to be restricted in distribution and its reports from river systems other than Cauvery need to be validated. There is an urgent need to delimit the distribution of the species preferably by molecular methods.
Puntius cauveriensis was described by Hora (1937) from the Cauvery River at Coorg.
Hypselobarbus dubius was described by Day (1867) from Bhavani River at the base of Nilgiri hills, India.

Puntius arenatus was originally described as Barbus arenatus by Day (1878) from Madras Presidency, India. While the species is considered valid by Talwar and Jhingran (1991) and Jayaram (1991, 1999) the species was synonymized to Puntius melanostigma by Menon (1999).  Jayaram (2010) treats this as a separate species.
Horabagrus brachysoma was described by Albert Gunther (1864) from Cochin under the name Pseudobagrus brachysoma.
Pseudeutropius mitchelli was described by Gunther (1864) from the erstwhile Madras Presidency, India.

Batasio travancoria was described from Perunteraruvi, tributary of Pamba river, Kerala by Hora and Law (1941). Record of the species from Coorg, Karnataka does not provide exact locality of collection (Raghunathan 1989) and needs to be verified.
Barilius canarensis was described by Jerdon (1849) from erstwhile Canara, southern India.
Glyptothorax anamalaiensis was described by Silas (1952) from a mountain stream flowing through the Anamalai Hills, Western Ghats, India.
Mesonoemacheilus pamabarensis was described by Rema Devi and Indra (1994) from Pambar River in Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary, Kerala, India.

Hypselobarbus kolus was described by Sykes (1839) as Barbus kolus. Menon and Remadevi (1995) synonimised this species with H. curmuca. Later Vairavel et al (1998) recorded this species for the first time from Kerala and treated it as a separate species.  It is a valid species based on mitochondrial genome, meristic, morphometric and osteological characterization (Arunachalam pers.comm.).
Glyptothorax trewavasae was described by Hora (1938) from Koyna valley and Yenna valley in Maharshtra and Shimoga in Karnataka.
The species was decribed as Glyptothorax housei by Herre (1942) from Puthuthottam Estate, Valparai, Tamil Nadu.
Osteochilus longidorsalis was first described from Vettilapara in Chalakudy River, Kerala, India (Pethiyagoda and Kottelat 1994).
Hypselobarbus micropogon was described by Valenciennes (1842) from Mysore, Karnataka, India.
The correct species name should be Neolissochilus wynaadensis following Ali et al. (2014). This species was described as Barbus wynaadensis by Day (1873).
Hemibagrus punctatus was described by Jerdon (1849) from Cauvery River and its principal tributaries in southern India.

Day described Paradanio neilgherriensis from Neilgherry hills in 1867 and he placed in the genus Paradanio. Later in 1878 he placed this species in the genus Danio. The scientific name was recently changed from Danio neilgherriensis to Devario neilgherriensis by Fang Fang Kullander in the doctoral dissertation "Phylogeny and Species Diversity of the South and Southeast Asian Cyprinid Genus Danio Hamilton (Teleostei, Cyprinidae)." in 2001.
Travancoria jonesi was first described by Hora (1941) from a mountain stream in Pampadumpara, Peeramedu, Kerala, India.
Nemacheilus kodaguensis was described by Menon (1987) from Kootu Hole, near Madikeri, (Cauvery basin), Karnataka, India. Should also be listed as Schistura kodaguensis.

Sykes (1839) described Barbus mussullah from Ghod river, Sirur, Pune District. Maharashtra, India. There has been considerable debate on the generic status of the species. This species has been treated as Tor mussullah by Talwar and Jhingran (1991), Jayaram (1997, 2005, 2010) following the discussions given in Hora (1943). Menon (1992, 1999), however suggested that the species considered as Tor mussullah by Hora (1943) is same as Tor khudree and he placed T. mussullah under genus Hypselobarbus following Rainboth (1989). However, both the original suggestion of the genus Hypselobarbus by Bleeker (1860), with Barbus mussullah as its type species, and resurrection of the resurrection of genus Hypselobarbus by Rainboth (1989) is based on the illustration by Sykes (1839) and not by examining specimens.

Suggestions made by Hora (1943) that the species should be called Tor mussullah seems more valid as the species called as 'musunda' in the type locality of Barbus mussullah and neighbouring areas is indeed a Tor species (Neelesh Dahanukar pers. obs.).
Horalabiosa palaniensisis was described by Rema Devi and Menon (1994) from Palani Hills, Tamil Nadu, India.

The Malabar mahseer, Tor malabaricus, was described by the British zoologist, T.C Jerdon in 1849 (Jerdon 1849) from the mountain streams of Malabar (an erstwhile province of Southern India; currently in the northern part of Kerala State), India. The species had a confusing taxonomy, as some authors considered it a synonym of the Deccan mahseer, T. khudree (Menon 1992; 1999), while others believed it to be a valid sub species, T. khudree malabaricus (Indra 1993). Tor malabaricus can be easily identified from its congeners in having a lesser number of lateral line scales (23-24), and a body with a pale brown colour on its upper half, silver on its lower half and reddish fins (Jerdon 1849).

Hyporhamphus xanthopterus was originally described by Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes (1847) from Fresh waters of Alleppey (now Alappuzha), southeastern India. It was rediscovered by Kurup and Samuel (1980) and Collette (1981) from Vembanad Lake in Kerala.

Puntius crescentus was described by Yazdani and Singh (1994) from Kali Nadi at Sunkeri, Karnataka, India. There is a need to establish the precise taxonomic status of the species as is has several characters similar to another species P. vittatus.

Nemacheilus periyarensis was first described from Thannikudy in the upper reaches of the Periyar River by Kurup and Radhakrishnan (2005). This species is known to show close resemblance to N. pulchellus in its colouration and body characteristics, but is distinguished from the latter by the presence of nine branched rays in the dorsal fin against 10.
Puntius fraseri was originally described as Barbus fraseri by Hora and Misra (1939) from Darna river, Deolali, Nashik, Maharashtra.
Horalabiosa arunachalami was described by Johnson and Sornam (2001) from Panniyar stream in Santhamparai, Iddukki district, Kerala.
Parapsilorhynchus prateri was first described from Darna River in the upper Godavari River basin, Deolali, Nasik District, Maharashtra State, India (Hora and Misra 1938).
Pterocryptis wynaadensis was first described from Wynaad, Kerala, India by Day (1873).
Hamilton (1822) described this species as Cyprinus curmuca from Vedavathi River in the Tungabhadra drainage. Barbus kolus Sykes, 1841 was synonymised with C. curmuca by Menon (1992).
Balitora mysorensis was first described by Hora (1941) from Sivasamudram, Cauvery drainage, Karnataka, India.
Nemacheilus keralensis was described by Rita and Nalbant (1978) from Pampadumpara, a tributary of River Periyar in Kerala, India.
Parapsilorhynchus elongatus was described by Singh (1994) from Ghod River, Khondwal village, Ambegaon taluka, Pune District, Maharashtra, India.

authority: Sreekantha, Gururaja, Rema Devi, Indra & Ramachandra, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Schistura sharavatienis was described by Sreekantha et al.(2006) from Kalkatte tributary of Sharavathi River, Karnataka, India.

authority: Sreekantha, Gururaja, Rema Devi, Indra & Ramachandra, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Schistura nagodiensis was described by Sreekantha et al. (2006) from Nagodi tributary of Sharavathi river, Karnataka, southern India.
This species was originally described under the genus Nemacheilus by Day (1867) from the Wayanad.
Mesonemacheilus herrei Nalbant & Bănărescu, 1981 was treated as a synonym for Noemacheilus guentheri Day, 1867 (Menon 1987). But, Eschmeyer and Fricke (2010) treat it as a separate species.
Garra periyarensis was first described by Gopi (2001) from the headwaters of Periyar River inside the Periyar Tiger Reserve, Kerala, India.
Laubuka fasciata was described by Silas (1958) from Anamalai river at Vannanthurai in Chittur taluk, erstwhile Cochin state (Kerala) India.
Puntius mudumalaiensis was described by Menon and Devi (1992) from Kakkanhalla road, Mudumalai, Tamil Nadu.
Lepidopygopsis typus was described by Raj (1941) from Periyar Lake, Kerala, India.
Glyptothorax kudremukensis was described by Gopi (2007) from the headwaters of the Thunga River, Muduba, Kudremukh National Park, Karnataka, India.
Garra surendranathanii was first described by Shaji et al. (1996) from the Orukomban tributary of Chalakudy River, Kerala, India.
The validity of this species has been questioned, but it is currently considered a good species (R. Jenkins pers. comm. June 2011, C. Raxworthy pers. comm. Jan 2011).
Domergue (1984) erected the subspecies Pararhadinea melanogaster marojejyensis for the apparently isolated Marojejy subpopulation, known from a single specimen.

Crottini et al. (2009) considered Cryptoscincus, of which C. minimus was the only member, a junior synonym of Paracontias based on molecular evidence. Specimens from Baie de Sakalava, noted by Glaw and Vences (2007) as needing further study to verify their assignment to this species, have now been confirmed as P. minimus (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011).

There is uncertainty about the number of species represented under the names Uroplatus fimbriatus and U. giganteus (F. Glaw and M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011). Raxworthy et al. (2008) consider U. giganteus to be a synonym for U. fimbriatus; however it has also been argued that additional undescribed species may be revealed within U. giganteus and/or U. fimbriatus by future molecular study (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011), and the population of U. cf. giganteus at Marojejy may warrant separate specific status (Greenbaum et al. 2007). The scheme followed here is that of Glaw et al. (2006), which considers this group to consist of two species, U. fimbriatus and U. giganteus, which correspond to the southern and northern clades of U. fimbriatus respectively (Raxworthy et al. 2008; F. Glaw, pers. comm. January 2011). Due to the geographical proximity of the U. fimbriatus type locality, Nosy Mangabe, to genetic U. giganteus, further research is needed to establish whether the assignment U. fimbriatus to the southern clade treated here under that name is valid, or whether this name should instead be applied either to a single species including both presently recognized clades, or to a northern form presently included under the name U. giganteus (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. January 2011).
F. monoceras is considered a junior synonymn of F. rhinoceratus (Glaw and Vences 2007).

A subspecies Palleon (formerly Brookesia) nasus pauliani is recognized from high-altitude sites at Andringtra, but it was not found during the most recent surveys and its taxonomic status remains unresolved (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 1996).

This species was synonymized with B. dentata by Raxworthy and Nussbaum (1995). This synonymy was questioned by Glaw et al. (1999), and the validity of this species was supported by Townsend et al. (2009)

This species was until recently thought to be known only from the holotype (Glaw and Vences 2007); however animals found in the Fort Dauphin area are considered to represent this species (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. January 2011). This requires clarification, and the taxonomic status and relationships of this skink are in need of further study (Glaw and Vences 2007).
Stenophis guentheri was assigned to Lycodryas by Nagy et al. (2010) in their revision of these genera.

Genetic data reveal that U. ebenaui is a complex of several species and a full taxonomic revision is required (Glaw and Vences 2007, Greenbaum et al. 2007, Raxworthy et al. 2008). Subpopulations from Marojejy, Tsaratanana and Montagne d'Ambre may warrant specific status (Greenbaum et al. 2007).

Nagy et al. 2010 removed Stenophis tulearensis from synonymy with this species (where it had been placed by Vences et al. 2004).The same authors elevated the subgenus Phisalixella to a full genus. The taxonomic identity of both P. tulearensis and P. variabilis requires further clarification (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).
The taxonomy of this species is in need of revision (Glaw and Vences 2007).

Records of this species from northern Madagascar, noted by Glaw and Vences (2007) as requiring further taxonomic study, may represent C. parsonii, C. oshaugnessyi or, in Montagne d'Ambre, C. ambreensis (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. June 2011), although there are no confirmed records of true C. oshaugnessyi from northern Madagascar (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011). A record from Tsaratanana requires further investigation to clarify its specific identity (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011).
Raxworthy and Nussbaum (1995) classed Brookesia legendrei as a junior synonym of B. ebenaui.

This chameleon was formerly considered a subspecies of C. gastrotaenia, but was elevated to species status by Böhme (1997). Individuals from Andohahela in the southeast require additional study to verify their taxonomic status (Andreone et al. 2001, Glaw and Vences 2007).

The Furcifer verrucosus, F. nicosiai, F. oustaleti group is in need of major revision and probably contains as yet undescribed species (Glaw and Vences 2007). Previous records of this species from the Menabe Region appear to be a previously undescribed taxon (Raselimanana 2008).
Stenophis inornatus was assigned to Lycodryas by Nagy et al. (2010) in their revision of these genera.
Specimens resembling this species have been recorded from near Makira at approximately 50 m asl., but these require  confirmation (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011).

This poorly-known species is in need of taxonomic investigation to clarify whether known subpopulations all represent the same species (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011), and its relationships to other Amphiglossus species are unclear (Schmitz et al. 2005).
This species shows a strong similarity to B. thieli (Andreone et al. 2009). The B. thieli/B. lineata complex is in need of revision and may contain several new species (Andreone et al. 2009).

A population from Montagne d'Ambre formerly considered a subspecies of Calumma oshaugnessyi has been given specific status in recent literature, as C. ambreense (Glaw and Vences, 2007; Andreone et al. 2009).

Calumma hilleniusi has variously been considered either a full species or a subspecies of C. brevicorne (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 2006). The identity of southern subpopulations currently assigned to this species requires verification (Vences et al. 2002).

Records of this species from Ambohijanahary are attributable to Furcifer willsii (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011). Records from Parc National Tsingy de Bemaraha may represent this taxon,. F. willsii, or an undescribed form; due to uncertainty about the correct assignment of these records the Bemaraha records are not included in the assessments for either F. petteri or F. wilsii.

This species resembles, but has long been recognized as distinct from, Calumma brevicorne,  being noted as C. sp. aff. brevicorne when first collected (Brygoo 1978). It was formally described only when Raxworthy and Nussbaum (2006) clarified the taxonomy of this species group.

Glaw and Vences (2007) note that a population resembling P. petiti occurs at Tsingy de Bemaraha, but this form is not known from any specimens and is not considered to belong to this species. The Tsingy de Bemaraha form is not considered in this assessment.

Additional genetic comparisons are needed between specimens from Nosy Be and the mainland to determine the status of Lygodactylus madagascariensis petteri at Montagne d'Ambre, and some morphological differences between this subpopulation and that from Manongarivo have been reported (Glaw and Vences 2007, Puente et al. 2009).

Recently-discovered specimens from Baie de Sakalava are provisionally assigned to X. grandidieri, a species previously known only from a single specimen with the type locality "Madagascar" (Glaw and Vences 2007; F. Glaw pers. comm.April 2011), on the basis that two other restricted-range species described by Mocquard have been found at the same locality, providing evidence that collections took place within or near this site (F. Glaw pers. comm. April 2011). These records were treated as belonging to X. mocquardi in Glaw and Vences (2007). Xenotyphlops mocquardi is itself likely to be a junior synonym of this species, as it falls within the range of variation observed within more recently-collected Baie de Sakalava specimens assigned to X. grandidieri (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011; F. Glaw pers. comm. April 2011). If this is the case, this will represent a slight range extension to the south (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).

This species is clearly distinct from any other Malagasy Lygodactylus. It is presumed that the village of Mandritsara where the species has been recorded represents the type locality. However, as the type locality is given as "Mt. Mandritsara, northwest Madagascar" in the original description (Pasteur, 1965), and no mountain exists near the village (which is in northeast Madagascar), this cannot be verified with certainty.

Zonosaurus maromaintso may be a colour variant of Z. boettgeri (Glaw and Vences 2007). Genetic data is needed to confirm the relationships of these taxa. Specimens of Z. boettgeri from the island of Nosy Be (the type locality) are also distinct from those of the nearby mainland and require additional study to clarify their specific status (Raselimanana et al. 2009); should this subpopulation prove to be distinct, the mainland form would therefore require a different name.

Following the recent description of Blaesodactylus ambonihazo, which is expected to be more widespread than is currently known, further morphological and genetic study is needed to clarify the southern limit of B. boivini's distribution and to verify the specific identity of records south of Ankarana (Bauer et al. 2011).

Along with other members of the Liopholidophis stumpffi group, this species was briefly included within the new genus Bibilava (Glaw et al. 2007, Glaw and Vences 2007). Cadle and Ineich (2008) later resurrected Thamnosophis for this species group.

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

There is no observed genetic distinction between Z. laticaudatus and Z. anelanelany in the south-east and further studies are needed using a larger sample size (only two individuals of Z. anelanelany have been included in comparisons), and from a wider area, than has been previously undertaken to clarify whether this is a real effect (Raselimanana et al. 2009). The two species are morphologically distinct, and therefore introgression or hybridization may account for the lack of genetic differences (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).

Cope (1885) used both Cyclura onchiopsis and Cyclura nigerrima; but only the former was diagnosed. Consequently, the latter must was a nomen nudum. Nearly a year later, Cope (1885 [1886]) provided a diagnosis for C. nigerrima. Barbour (1937) relegated C. nigerrima to a subspecies of C. cornuta. Schwartz and Carey (1977) formally placed C. nigerrima in the synonymy of C. onchiopsis.

Originally described as a full species, the Navassa Rhinoceros Iguana was relegated to subspecific status within the Rhinoceros Iguanas (Cyclura cornuta) first by Cope (1885 [1886]), without presenting any evidence other than superficial physical similarity. That status was contradicted by Barbour and Noble (1916), although Barbour (1937) later reverted to the subspecific designation. Carey (1977) recognized Cyclura onchiopsis as a full species, but most subsequent authorities followed Schwartz and Thomas (1975) in recognizing it as a subspecies. Powell (1999) re-elevated the taxon to full species status.
In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to the original description (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2007).
This species is also known as Prisodontopsis johnstoni (E.A. Smith 1893) in recent literature, but that name is a primary homonym of Unio johnstoni Etheridge, 1881.
Gabbia alticola was described as Amnicola alticola (Subba Rao 1989).
The Canary Brimstone used to be considered a subspecies of the Cleopatra (G. cleopatra).
The taxonomic status of this taxon and its relationship to C. leander, C. arcania, and C. gardetta are unclear and require further research.
Petaliaeschna pinratanai Yeh, 1999 is a junior synonym of this species.
This species includes hylaeum as a subspecies (Wilson and Reeder 1993).
Was in the IUCN Red List from 1996 to 2006 incorrectly spelt as Platyla maaseni.
There is low genetic divergence between the three subpopulations but no morphometric divergence.  It is possible that this is a species complex.
Recent genetic data show that the subspecies R. trachyrhynchus trachycephalus (Seipp and Henkel 2000) should be regarded as a full species.

The genetic study (Sadlier 2014) revealed the presence of two clearly differentiated lineages within what has previously been regarded as a single species, Nannoscincus mariei. Although the geographic range of samples available for the genetics study is not as extensive as that represented by museum specimens it is, in combination with morphological data, sufficient to indicate that the samples represent two parapatric taxa: Nannoscincus mariei Bavay (Mt. Koghis south to the Goro Plateau, including Rivière Bleue), and Nannoscincus fuscus (the Chaîne Centrale at Mt. Mou, Mt. Dzumac and Mt. Vulcain).
The true familly of Dierogekko thomaswhitei is DIPLODACTILIDAE and not GEKKONIDAE

There is a moderate level of genetic and morphometric differentiation between the widely disjunct groups of populations in the north and south of the species' range, and there is also a consistent difference in colouration between the population on the Panié massif and Koniambo. In the absence of data on the occurrence of the species between these groups of populations these differences are insufficient for taxonomic distinction.
The true familly of Dierogekko inexpectatus is DIPLODACTILIDAE and not GEKKONIDAE
The true familly of Dierogekko nehoueensis is DIPLODACTILIDAE and not GEKKONIDAE

The population of Kanakysaurus on Dôme de Tiébaghi is genetically very close to Kanakysaurus zebratus yet is morphologically indistinguishable and genetically highly divergent from the Kanakysaurus viviparus with which it is sympatric. Whether this represents a distinct taxon or is the result of mitochondrial introgression awaits further research (Sadlier et al. 2009).

The true familly of Oedodera marmorata is DIPLODACTILIDAE and not GEKKONIDAE

Populations of Oedodera on the Poum and Kaala massifs are genetically and morphometrically divergent from O. marmorata from Dôme de Tiébaghi. They are treated as potentially distinct taxa under description and hence are not included in this assessment for Oedodera marmorata.
The low-elevation specimens (Vavouto) are likely to be another species (on-going studies by Bauer and Sadlier).
The true familly of Dierogekko poumensis is DIPLODACTILIDAE and not GEKKONIDAE

The population of Kanakysaurus on Dôme de Tiébaghi is genetically very close to Kanakysaurus zebratus yet is morphologically indistinguishable and genetically highly divergent from the Kanakysaurus viviparus with which it is sympatric. Whether this represents a distinct taxon or is the result of mitochondrial  introgression awaits further research (Sadlier et al. 2009).
The true familly of Dierogekko validiclavis is DIPLODACTILIDAE and not GEKKONIDAE
There is significant genetic divergence between the known populations on Mt Panié and Tchingou.

Thomas Say originally described Unio cicatricosus in 1829. Isaac Lea described Unio varicosus later the same year. Both names were widely used in the literature; however, varicosus Lea was pre-occupied by varicosus Lamarck, 1819. Frierson (1911) synonomized Unio cicatricosus Say with Unio aesopus Green, 1827 (= Plethobasus cyphyus Rafinesque, 1820) and renamed Lea's shell as Unio detectus Frierson, 1911. He also named two additional species Unio cicatricoides and Unio comptertus as being part of this complex. In 1919, Ortmann synonomized all of Frierson's names under cicatricosus Say. Three years later Ortmann and Walker (1922) sunk cicatricosus into cyphyus. Recent authors have not followed Ortmann and Walker (1922) and recognize Plethobasus cicatricosus as distinct (Parmalee 1967, Bogan and Parmalee 1983, Cummings and Mayer 1992, Turgeon et al. 1998, Williams et al. 2008).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
This newly described species was discovered in 2005. It is the single representative of the family Symphytognathidae in Europe with its closest relatives occurring in Cote D’Ivoire.
This species is morphologically somewhat similar to Plethodon elongatus, but it is genetically distinct.
This species is sometimes considered to be conspecific with Plethodon ouachitae, with which it integrades freely in its narrow zone of contact.
Very closely related to E. innominata and E. jagorii with very similar morphology and DNA, they may even be conspecific.
Kharin (1981) recognized two subgenera in the genus Aipysurus: Aipysurus and Smithohydrophis. He included Aipysurus foliosquama in Smithohydrophis (Kharin 1981).

There is some debate as to whether L. schistorynchus is a separate species, or a subspecies of L. semifasciata, due to similarities in venom chemistry (Guinea et al. 1983, Tamiya et al. 1983) and morphology (McCarthy 1986). This is disputed by Cogger and Heatwole (2005).

The Reptile Database treats this species under the genus Pseudolaticauda.
This species has been treated under the genus Leioselasma.

Aipysurus fuscus is a small to moderately sized venomous snake, typically reaching a length of 60 cm and maximum total length of 98 cm (Cogger 2014, Francis 2006, Mirtschin et al. 2017, Storr et al. 2002). Adults are brown, blackish-brown or purplish-brown, but often have obscure, paler cross bands on the lower flanks. Sometimes the lateral scales will have a darker patch at the centre, resulting in faint, longitudinal striations; younger snakes are typically lighter and dark banded.

Aipysurus fuscus can be differentiated from closely related A. laevis by its smaller size, darker colouration and by the number of scales on belly and mid-body (155 – 172 ventral scales and less than 21 scale rows around the midbody). Other scale features used in taxonomy of A. fuscus include: head shields are regular with some fragmentation of scales occasionally (prefrontals, frontal and supraoculars) especially the parietals; upper labials six to nine, with the first three or four sometimes divided horizontally; anal scales are divided, while ventral scales are broad with a medium keel and no posterior notch. Body scales are smooth with some lowest rows weakly keeled in males. Body scales are imbricate (overlapping) and there are typically 19 scale rows around the neck and 19 around the mid-body. Females have between 24 to 33 subcaudal scales, while males have 30 to 37 subcaudal scales (Francis 2006, Rasmussen et al. 2014).

Microsatellite markers for A. fuscus and A. laevis sampled across four Timor Sea reefs were analysed to assess evidence for recent inter-specific gene flow and historical introgression (Sanders et al. 2014). The data fit an Isolation–Migration model, which showed significant and asymmetrical levels of gene flow following species divergence, and highest rates of introgression from the large A. laevis population into the much smaller A. fuscus population(Sanders et al. 2014). Population assignment analyses recovered two ancestral clusters that broadly corresponded to morphological species designations, but revealed high frequencies of hybrids on all four reefs and individuals of pure A. fuscus ancestry only at Scott and (historically) Ashmore. Most unexpectedly, 95% of snakes sampled at Hibernia were hybrids that resembled A. laevis in phenotype, revealing a collapse of reproductive barriers (‘reverse speciation’) at this reef. These results have dire implications for the conservation status of A. fuscus, and highlight the fragility of reproductive barriers in a recent marine radiation (Sanders et al. 2014).
Kharin (1981) recognized two subgenera in the genus Aipysurus: Aipysurus and Smithohydrophis. He included A. apraefrontalis in Smithohydrophis (Kharin 1981).
