Along with other members of the Liopholidophis stumpffi group, this species was briefly included within the new genus Bibilava (Glaw et al. 2007, Glaw and Vences 2007). Cadle and Ineich (2008) later resurrected Thamnosophis for this species group.
Broadley (1996) synonymized Cryptolycus with Lycophidion.
A.L. Silveira (pers. comm. 2010) considers this species a junior synonym of Tantilla pallida based on work in preparation to revise this widespread species complex.
This species was recognized as a full species based on the mtDNA and allozyme data presented by Schneider et al. (2001), as well as biogeographical and morphological differences from Anolis wattsi.

Podarcis gaigeae was separated from this species by Gruber (1986). Although this status was not recognized by Gasc et al. (1997), it is supported by additional genetic results (Harris and Arnold 1999).

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

The population situated on the eastern slopes of the Andes above Villavicencio may represent a hybrid or intergrade population between P. bicolor and P. nicefori (Loveridge 1929). Further study is required. Harris (1994) suggests that this eastern record may represent an undescribed species, and it is not considered part of this species here.

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

Two subspecies are recognized:
Anolis strahmi strahmi Schwartz, 1979
Anolis strahmi abditus Schwartz, 1979.

It was thought that the species was probably also found in parts of Bolivia, but taxonomic studies suggest that Bolivian populations may well represent undescribed species, as allopatric speciation may be prevalent in this group of rare and habitat-restricted lizards (Rodrigues et al. 2007, Rodrigues et al. 2008) .
The specific status of Cryptoblepharus spp. is not completely accepted and most species are considered as subspecies by many authors (Rocha et al. 2006).
Genetic and morphological data suggest that this is a complex of various species (M. Vences pers. comm.).

authority: Verrastro, Veronese, Bujes & Martins Dias Filho, 2003

taxonomicNotes: Meyer (1897) classified a single specimen from Siau Island together with several others from Sangihe Island as Tarsius sangirensis. A biogeographic hypothesis by Shekelle and Leksono (2004) predicted that the Siau specimen would be taxonomically distinct (see also Brandon Jones et al. 2004). This prediction was subsequently confirmed by Shekelle et al. (2008). The Sangir and Siau islands are separated by c.60km of ocean with depths >1000m and therefore no possible recurrent gene flow between T.sangirensis and T.tumpara.

Chlorocnemis maccleeryi Pinhey, 1969 was described as a subspecies of C. montana St. Quentin, 1942. It differs substantially in coloration and size. Moreover the appendages are more like those of C. abbotti (Calvert, 1892) than C. montana. The differences are sufficient to regard the taxon as a good species (Dijkstra and Clausnitzer in press).
Described by Boulenger (1898) based on specimens from the Chao Phraya River, Thailand.
This species was recognised as conspecific with the Indonesian Balantiocheilos melanopterus Bleeker, 1851 for a long time. It was described as a separate species by Ng and Kottelat (2007).
Lower populations of this fish may actually be a new species (W. Rainboth pers. comm. 2011).

The taxonomy of night monkeys (Aotus spp.) has been debated and still does not provide a complete picture of the diversity of the genus Aotus. Ruiz-Herrera et al. (2005) reported that cytogenetic studies have characterised 18 different karyotypes with diploid numbers ranging from 46 to 58 chromosomes. The taxonomy of the night monkeys essentially followed the early revision by Hershkovitz (1983), with some modifications for the Colombian and Central American forms. Recent molecular studies have made valuable contributions towards the understanding of night monkeys taxonomy and phylogenetic relations (Plautz et al.2009; Menezes et al. 2010).

Reviewing the entire taxonomy and distributions of the night monkeys, Aotus, Ford (1994) carried out multivariate analyses of craniodental measures and pelage patterns and color, and also took into consideration chromosomal data and blood protein variations. Ford (1994) concluded that there was “good support” for just two species north of the Río Amazonas: A. trivirgatus (Humboldt, 1812) east and north of the Rio Negro, and the polymorphic A. vociferans to the west of the Rio Negro. Aotus vociferans, as such, would include all the forms north of the Río Amazonas/Solimões in Brazil (west of the Rio Negro), Peru, Colombia and Ecuador, and in the Chocó, northern Colombia and Colombian Andes, and Panama: brumbacki, lemurinus, griseimembra, and zonalis.

Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976) restricted both lemurinus (Colombian Andes, elevations from 1,000 to 1,500 m up to 3,000–3,200 m) and griseimembra (northern lowlands, Santa Marta mountains, west to Río Sinú, Río San Jorge, lower Río Cauca and lowlands of middle and upper Río Magdalena) to Colombia, while recognizing the form zonalis as the night monkey of north-western Colombia (Chocó) and Panama. Hershkovitz (1983) recognized lemurinus and griseimembra as distinct, but considered them to be subspecies of a single species; he made no mention of the name zonalis, but as he ascribed Central American night monkeys to A. lemurinus lemurinus, by implication he was regarding it as a synonym of this latter form. Groves (2001) followed Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976) in recognizing zonalis as the form in Panama, and listed it as a subspecies of lemurinus along with griseimembra and brumbacki Hershkovitz, 1983. Defler et al. (2001) concluded that the karyotype of Aotus hershkovitzi Ramirez-Cerquera, 1983 (from the upper Río Cusiana, Boyacá, Colombia; 2n = 58) was in fact that of true lemurinus, and that the karyotypes which Hershkovitz (1983) had considered to be those of lemurinus were in fact of zonalis. Defler et al. (2001) and others (Defler 2003, 2004; Defler and Bueno 2003) concluded that Aotus lemurinus of Hershkovitz (1983) is in fact three karyotypically well-defined species, and that the night monkeys of the lowlands of Panama and the Chocó region of Colombia belong to the species A. zonalis, and those of the Magdalena valley to A. griseimembra, while those above altitudes of 1,500 m should correctly be referred to as A. lemurinus. For a review of the taxonomy of the night monkeys of Panama and northern Colombia see Rylands et al. (2006).

Defler and Bueno (2007) discussed the karyology of the grey-necked night monkeys and reaffirmed the validity of A. brumbacki, A. griseimembra, A. lemurinus, A. trivirgatus, A. vociferans and A. zonalis.
Its generic level was validated as Devario by Fang (2001) and and Fang et al. (2009).
Platytropius siamensis was described from the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok (Sauvage 1883) as a species of Pseudeutropius. Hora (1937) subsequently erected the genus Platytropius for this species.

This species is not Hypsibarbus pierrei, with which the name been confused. Nobody has compared the Indochinese (L. pierrei / L. yunnanensis) and Sundanese (L. erythropterus) species and they are considered distinct at present (M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2012). Labeo pierrei is the oldest name for the Indochinese species, and  L. yunnanensis is tentatively considered as a synonym.

This species was originally described as Nemachilus spilopterus var. nasifilis by Pellegrin 1936 from a specimen collected from Song Ko and Song Tan in Central Viet Nam. Since the collection of the types in 1936, this species has not been collected.

Although formerly considered either a subspecies of P. comata, or as a species in its own right (Brandon-Jones 1984, 1995), P. fredericae is most likely conspecific with P. comata (Nijman 1997). Although Groves (2005) continues to list the two as subspecies, it has been shown fairly conclusively that a chain of intermediate populations exists between the formerly recognized subspecies, representing a morphological gradation across the species’ range from grey to black (Vun et al., 2010).
Semnopithecus frontatus S. Muller, 1838, Indonesia, south-eastern Borneo. Restricted by L. Medway in 1965 to south eastern Kalimantan, Murung and Pulu Lampy, near Banjarmasin, Pematang, Kuala.

There are strong indications that the canicrus subspecies can be separated from the others as a distinct species (Meijaard and Groves unpubl. data). The subspecies hosei is based on just a few specimens (type locality) and is of unclear taxonomic status.

 

Semnopithecus hosei Thomas 1889, Malaysia, Sarawak, Niah. The forms sabana and canicrus that are commonly considered subspecies of P. hosei are in fact distinct species, the differences being primarily morphological. The population at the type locality lacks sexual dichromatism and so two subspecies have been described: hosei supposed to be restricted to the region around Niah (extending east to Brunei) lacking sexual color difference and everetti named by O.Thomas in 1892 from the rest of the distribution of the species (inland eastern Sarawak, Brunei, west Sabah, and northern Kalimantan) possessing it. But the ages of the specimen, when considered, brings to doubt the validity of the specimens as they were young females and not adults. Facial skin is pinkish except for black around eyes and bluish lips.

Now all of the subspecies formerly considered are distinct species. Presbytis melalophos though has colour morphs: the ‘foxy-red nobilis’ , ‘less-reddish ferruginae’ and ‘golden buff aurata’, black chested, white tail tipped and the hands and feet black.  A fourth form ‘fluvialtilis’ described in 1940 by N.F. Chasen of Palembang, Sumatra is also accounted for.
Presbytis potenziani is now monotypic and the former subspecies P. p. siberu is now a distinct species.
Possibly referebale to P. comata.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Paraphyosemion).

Paugy et al. use Rhexipanchax kabae in the second edition of the Fishes of West Africa (2003). Huber (1999) described Rhexipanchax as a subgenus of Procatopus, and Ghedotti (2000) elevated it to genus.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).

Populations of this species originating from the upper Lufira system were first identified as N. brieni, which species was the first and, for 40 years, the only Nothobranchius species described from the Congo and upper Zambezi river drainages, and the populations were also referred to as N. aff. taeniopygus, based on the presence of broad light subdistal band in the caudal fin. Finally, Nothobranchius polli was established as a distinct species by Wildekamp in 1978, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.

Aphyosemion bualanum, as defined by Scheel (1968), is regarded here as Aphyosemion elberti. Therefore, all scientific as well as popular aquarium articles about Aphyosemion bualanum, published prior to 1990, in fact deal with the species Aphyosemion elberti. Aphyosemion cameronense that was reported in Blache et al. (1964) from the Mayo Kebbi basin of northern Cameroon, might be identical to A. bualanum.

authority: Taverne, Thys van den Audenaerde & Heymer, 1977
(Taverne, Thys van den Audenaerde, Heymer & Géry, 1977)

taxonomicNotes:
Nothobranchius rosenstocki was established as a species by Valdesalici & Wildekamp in 2005, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.

Populations from the Mansa River drainage, discovered in 1989, were also included in the group of populations regarded as N. rosenstocki, but subsequent morphological and molecular studies showed these populations to represent a distinct species described as Nothobranchius cooperi, by Nagy, Watters and Bellstedt in 2017 (in Nagy et al. 2017).

This species is one of several troglobitic species in the subgenus Ortmannicus. It is highly distinctive, and its closest affinities are with Procambarus delicatus, which appears to be on a line leading to Troglocambarus (J. Cordeiro, T. Jones and R. Thoma pers. comm. 2009).
Subgenus (Pauciradius).
Subgenus (Fundulopanchax).
Subgenus (Diapteron).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).

Thys (1967) noted that Gobius bustamantei Greeff, 1882 has the fleshy processes inside the branchial opening that are diagnostic for Awaous (however, Thys did not use the name Awaous in his review). Watson (1996), in review of the subgenus Chonophorus, places Gobius bustamantei Greeff, 1882 in synonymy of A. lateristriga. However, preliminary analyses made by one of us (IJH) supports Thys’s (1967) distinction of A. bustamantei and A. lateristiga based on higher scale counts in the former.
The spelling of the species name is L. konkureensis in FishBase, different to L. konkourensis in Paugyy et al. (2004).
The specimens of Amphilius lamani of the upper Mpoulou River are Amphilius mamonekenensis.
Subgenus (Chrysobagrus)
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Although the species has been assumed to be an inhabitant of rapids Teugels et al. (1992) have collected it in both rapids and in non-rapidly flowing stretches of the Cross River.
Subgenus (Aphyosemion).
There is very little information available about Synodontis cuangoanus.

From a study conducted by Buhay and Crandall (2009) Procambarus pecki has been transferred from the subgenus Remoticambarus of the genus Procambarus, to the subgenus Aviticambarus of the genus Cambarus. This has been based on genetic studies which more accurately reflect its evolutionary history.
Some references to Tetraodon guttifer in the literature may represent misidentifications of Tetraodon pustulatus.
Subgenus (Pauciradius).
Clariallabes dumerili (David & Poll, 1937) is not a valid name or synonym for Clariallabes teugelsi Ferraris, 2007.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).

authority: Van den Bergh, Teugels, Coenen & Ollevier, 1995

taxonomicNotes: Subgenus (Paraphyosemion).
Barboides gracilis is distinguished from small Barbus species in sight by absence of barbels, absence of lateral line and 1 single nostril in form of 8 at each side of snout.
Subgenus (Kathetys).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).

Brycinus bartoni is close to Brycinus longipinnis. The two species are distinguished by predorsal scale counts (13 in B. bartoni vs. 8 1/2-11 1/2 in B. longipinnis); it is also similar to B. intermedius and B. tholloni, but has fewer scales in transverse row between lateral line and dorsal fin origin (5 1/2 vs. 6 1/2).

The distribution map of L. markerti and L. tigripictilis in Tougas and Stiassny (2014) show that L. tigripictilis only occurs upstream of the Inga rapids. They indicate that a specimens from Nziya village previously identified as L. tigripictilis by Schelly and Stiassny (2004) in fact represent L. markerti (AMNH 233568). However, they do not explain the distribution and do not reveal the taxonomic position of L. tigripictilis specimens from Matadi (BMNH 1899.2.20.10) and Boma (MRAC 48562) identified in Schelly and Stiassny (2004) as L. tigripictilis.
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).

Subgenus (Chrysobagrus) : This species is very close to Chrysichthys (Chrysobagrus) longidorsalis, and was originally described as a subspecies of that taxon. However, Risch (1986) considered that the characters which separate the two are of importance in the evolution of Chrysobagrus (i.e. occipital process a little narrower, nasal barbel a little longer, vomerine teeth slightly more pronounced, and palatine dentition occasionally expressed). For these reasons we follow Risch (1986) in maintaining them as specifically distinct.
Subgenus (Diapteron).
The specimens of Doumea typica from Cameroon are Doumea gracila.
Taxonomy of haplochromine cichlids is in disarray. The species is often included in Ctenochromis. Further phylogenetic work is necessary to resolve generic placement.
Subgenus (Paludopanchax).
It is currently under revision. Teleogramma brichardi is possibly a complex.
This species is very close to Marcusenius senegalensis meristically; difference only in the body form and caudal peduncle
Occurs only in Ghana. Collections from the Lower Guinea identified as C. walkeri appear to be misidentifications (Risch and Vreven, in press).
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Melanodactylus)
Until recently this species was placed in Aplocheilichthys.
Subgenus (Rheoglanis)

Paugy et al. use Rhexipanchax kabae in the second edition of the Fishes of West Africa (2003). Huber (1999) described Rhexipanchax as a subgenus of Procatopus, and Ghedotti (2000) elevated it to genus.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Pauciradius).

Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion): Aphysemion (Chromaphyosemion) melinoides (Sonnenberg, 2007) is distinguished from its close relative Aphysemion (Chromaphyosemion) lugens by the orange colour on the throat and belly, orange in basal half of anal and dorsal fins and orange fin streamer on dorsal fin in males and orange in ventral part of caudal fin in females; the anterior or complete dorsal fin orange, orange hue on flanks of females. A. melinoides is known from several collection localities along the road from Kribi to Ebolowa between the villages Akok and Akom II and on the road from Akom II to Bipindi in southwestern Cameroon.
Appeared in the IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006 under the generic name Prognathochromis.
This species is also spelled as Chriolepis lepidotus.
This species is possibly conspecific with Halichoeres malpelo from Malpelo Island. Genetic studies should be undertaken.
This species is closely related to ,i>Thalassoma purpureum in the Indo-Pacific region (Bernardi et al. 2004).
Possibly conspecific with Halichoeres salmofasciatus from Cocos Island. Genetic studies are needed.
Also known as Arcos poecilophthalmos.

This species is at the single location where it is known. It is intermediate in character between two abundant species (Myripristis benrndti and M. clarionensis) at the same location, therefore it may possibly be a hybrid.

Most populations are assigned to the subterranean subspecies Proteus anguinus anguinus. Unlike the nominate form, the genetically similar subspecies P.a. parkelj from Bela Krajina in Slovenia is pigmented and might represent a distinct species, although a recent genetic study suggests that the two subspecies are poorly differentiated at the molecular level and may not even warrant subspecies status (Goricki and Trontelt 2006).
This species is also known as Chriolepis walkerii (Findley 1983).
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus dendriticus to the genus Gobioclinus.
This species is often misidentified with cogenerics.

This species  lies within one of the groups of subterranean snails that need researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits. A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology pending the results for full analysis for the group. However, given the characteristic shell, this is undoubtedly a valid species.

This species was listed as Knipowitschia sp. nov. ‘Visovac’ by Kottelat and Freyhof, 2007. It was also mentioned as "Knipowitschia mrakovcici" by Mrakovcic et al. (1994), which was not a valid name. It has since been formally named Knipowitschia mrakovcici Miller, 2009.
Assessments of Iberochondrostoma lemmingii published before 2010 included individuals that are now recognised as belonging to a separate species: Achondrostoma salamantinum Doadrio & Elvira, 2007.
Previously this species was included within Squalius pyrenaicus (Günther, 1868), but it is now recognised as a separate species (Doadrio et al. 2007).
Alburnoides maculatus was a subspecies of A. bipunctatus but it was raised to species level by Bogutskaya and Coad (2009).
As with all European unionids, numerous synonyms occur. Falkner et al. (2002) lists seven morphologically distinct 'sub-species'.

Applying the methodology of Heller et al. (2005) to differentiate Melanopsis species, M. brevicula has to be considered as a distinctive Melanopsis species characterised by its minute size, flattened sides, low spire and small mouth aperture.
This species is described in the PhD dissertation of Ghamizi (1998) (nomen nudum). Type specimen in Musee de Paris.

Graf and Cummings (2006) pulled this species from the synonymy of Coelatura gabonensis without having seen the types of Zairia disciformis Rochebrune, 1886 and Pharaonia bourguignati Rochebrune, 1886 (both unfigured and in the MNHN). Those types have since been examined and found to be synonymous with C. rotula. P. bourguignati is a secondary junior homonym of Unio bourguignati Landrin, 1864, so the proper name for this species, following a complete revision, would be Coelatura disciformis.
Nomen nudum for a new species described by Ghamizi (1998) in his PhD thesis. Type specimen in the Musee de Paris.
The generic position is uncertain in absence of anatomical data.
There are many forms of M. magnifica. It's a very beautiful shell. It's possible that it's many species combined.

The generic status of this species is still uncertain, lacking anatomical data. Although taxonomy is uncertain, there is no uncertainty about it being a distinct species. It might be a new genus. Ghamizi has yet to publish on it, though the species is described in the PhD dissertaion of Ghamizi (1998). The type specimen is in the Museum of Natural History of Marrakesh.
The generic position of this new species is still uncertain. The name 'knidirii' is a nomen nudum as the species is only described in the PhD dissertation of Ghamizi (1998).

The generic position of this new species is still uncertain, anatomical data lacking. The name 'valai' is a nomen nudum since the species is only described in the Ph D dissertaion of Ghamizi (1998). Type specimen is in Musee de Paris.
This species is described in the PhD dissertation of Ghamizi (1998) (nomen nudum). Type specimen in Musee de Paris.
The name of the family Mutelidae has been altered in Iridinidae.
The generic position is uncertain due to lack of anatomical data. Synonymisation according to Boeters (1976).
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, but this genus is now tentatively placed in Paludomidae along with Cleopatra until further genetic analysis can confirm the appropriate family for this genus.
The generic status is uncertain due to lack of anatomical data. The taxonomy of the hydrobiids of Algeria has not been revised since 1864.
Originally placed in Cleopatra. Brown (1994) was uncertain of the genus.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.

Kristensen (1985) and Ramdani et al. (1987) consider the Maghrebian M. scalaris as a distinct species. Ghamizi (1998) suggests that it may belong to the Circummediterranean M. dufouri Férusac, 1823. Applying the methodology of Heller et al. (2005) to differentiate Melanopsis species, M. scalaris has to be considered as a distinctive Melanopsis species characterised by its strong subsutural shoulder and turriform shell.

This species is sympatric with Maroccopsis agadirensis, and is found in the same well. Nomen nudum for a new species described by Ghamizi (1998) in his PhD thesis. Type specimen in the Musee de Paris. Very distinct species.
Generic position uncertain lacking anatomical data. Possibly identical to B. limnopsis according to Boeters (1976).
The generic position is uncertain due to lack of anatomical data. Synonymisation according to Boeters (1976).
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.

As Bourguignat (1864) pointed out is this morphotype somewhat similar to the Iberian Melanopsis graëllsiana which also is carinated. Melanopsis subgraëllsiana is not only distinctive in shell morphology but geographically strongly isolated (North-West Algeria). It is therefore considered here as distinctive and not as a variety of M. maroccana.
This species may not be in the genus Hydrobria but anatomical material is not available.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, but this genus is now tentatively placed in Paludomidae along with Cleopatra until further genetic analysis can confirm the appropriate family for this genus.
Further taxonomic work is required on this species.
The generic status is uncertain due to lack of anatomical study.

Originally described by Bédé (1932) as a new subgenus, Liouvillea, on the basis of anatomic differences. Subsequently considered as synonymous with the European Anodonta cygnaea Lake (see Daget, 1998), from which it differs by its smaller size, broad umbo and umbonal ornamenation. Further molecular and taxonomic research is necessary to establish its degree of taxonomic distinction.

For the moment it should not be considered as A. cygnea because the Iberian populations are not considered A. cygnea which would imply a jump, so almost certainly not.
Nomen nudum for a new species described by Ghamizi (1998) in his PhD thesis. Type specimen in the Musee de Paris.
Both Mandahl-Barth (1988) and Daget (1998) regarded Mutela langi as a synonym of M. rostrata. However, Graf regards Mutela langi as morphologically distinct, but based on limited shell data.
The generic position is uncertain due to lack of anatomical data.

Considered by Ghamizi (1998) as a distinct morphotype. Applying the methodology of Heller et al. (2005) to differentiate Melanopsis species, M. chlorotica has to be considered as a distinctive Melanopsis species characterised by its small size, elongate form and the presence of several dark coloured bands.
The generic position uncertain in absence of anatomical data. Synonymisation based on Boeters (1976)

These Moroccan populations were identified by Kristensen (1985) and Ramdani et al. (1987) as Lymnaea glabra. Ghamizi (1990) forwards conclusive arguments that the species originally described by Pallary is distinct and endemic to Morocco.

Theodoxus marteli has been considered by most authors as synonymous with the European T. fluviatilis (Linné 1758). Current research in the Iberian peninsula and the Maghreb has shown that the degree of endemicity in freshwater molluscs of the Mediterranean region is significantly higher than has been assumed hitherto. We therefore prefer to maintain T. marteli provisionally as a distinct species.
Nomen nudum for a new species described by Ghamizi (1998) in his PhD thesis. Type specimen in the Musee de Paris.
This species has also been referred to as Mutela carrei (Putzeys 1898) in recent literature. Both Mandahl-Barth (1988) and Daget (1998) regarded Mutela legumen as a synonym of M. rostrata.

The Maghrebian Anodonta populations were ranged by all modern malacologists (e.g., Daget 1998) under the European A. cygnaea and A. anatina. Recent molecular studies have revealed however the existence of 2 cryptospecies of Anodonta in Mediterranean Europe. According to the present assessors, taking into account the above and the conchyologic distinctive features the Anodonta populations that occur in the marshes of the border region of Algeria and Tunisia should be considered as a separate taxon.
It is sympatric with G. gofasi. Nomen nudum for a new species described by Ghamizi (1998) in his PhD thesis. Type specimen in the Musee de Paris.

The generic position of this new species is still uncertain. The name 'salahi' is a nomen nudum as the species is only described in the PhD dissertation of Ghamizi (1998). Voucher specimens deposited in Paris Museum.

This is a poorly characterized species, known only from the original type material, described by Frierson (1913) from the Lobo and Nyang rivers in Cameroon. Haas (1936) created the new genus Afroparreysia for it. Since the genus Coelatura is considered a polyphyletic trash bin (Graf, ) it is likely that the name Afroparreysia will be reinstituted. However, from a conservationist point of view this may be of little interest, since the species has not been found since its original discovery and is most likely, considering the appalling state of the freshwater habitas in Cameroon, extinct.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.
Nomen nudum for a new species described by Ghamizi (1998) in his PhD thesis. Type specimen in the Musee de Paris.
Nomen nudum for a new species described by Ghamizi (1998) in his PhD thesis. Type specimen in the Musee de Paris.
This species is possibly related to M. recticosta (Brown 1994), but Brown maintained it as a separate species.

Applying the methodology of Heller et al. (2005) to differentiate Melanopsis species, M. letourneuxi has to be considered as a distinctive Melanopsis species characterised by strong ribs with two rows of noduli separated by a marked indentation.

Highly distinctive small species. Applying the methodology of Heller et al. (2005) to differentiate Melanopsis species, M. saharica has to be considered as a distinctive Melanopsis species characterised by its squat extremely globose form.

In his revision of the Paleartic unionids, Haas (1940) considered the three Moroccan species described by Pallary (1918, 1923 and 1928) to belong to a single subspecies of the European Psilunio auricularius (Spengler, 1792 ), namely P. auricularius marocanus. Some authors (Van Damme 1984; Ghamizi 1998) retained the Moroccan form as distinctive while others (Mandahl-Barth 1988; Daget, 1998) did not. Recent molecular and conchiological investigation show that this species is a separate species, differing from the European species e.g., by its smaller size, nearly black outer test and differences in the hinge.

The generic position is uncertain due to lack of anatomical data. According to Boeters (1976) the shells from Goulette (Tunisia) identified by Letourneux and Bourguignat (1887) as B. microcochlia belong to a different species. They are hence not incorporated in this assessment.

Considered erroneously by Van Damme (1984), Daget (1998) and Ghamizi (1998) as a synonym of Unio elongatulus durieui Deshayes, 1847. Unio foucauldianus was considered a synonim of U. gibbus by Araujo et al. (2009). However, based on morphological and genetic analyses, Froufe et al., 2016 recognize U. foucauldianus not as U. gibbus but as the valid name for the other single Unio species found in Morocco. Pallary first described this species in 1936 from specimens collected at the Aït Melloul bridge, in the lower section of the Sous River, which now dries completely in the summer and where the species has not been recorded for decades. Unfortunately, the present location of the type specimens of U. foucauldianus is unknown.

All Unio populations that occur in the rivers belonging to the Mediterranean Basin were considered by Haas (1940) to be subspecies of Unio elongatulus Pfeiffer, 1825. The Maghrebian Unio populations were all listed under Unio elongatulus durieui. For Spanish populations, the name Unio mancus Lamarck does have priority over U. elongatulus. Some authors subsequently erroneously substituted the name mancus for all elongatulus subspecies created by Haas (e.g., Unio elongatulus durieui hence becomes Unio mancus durieui). This is not based on any scientific evidence and it is advisable to reject Haas' excessive lumping and to consider his many subspecies as separate species. Unio durieui is quite distinctive from the Spanish U. mancus in general form, umbonal ornamentation and coloration. According to the present assessors Unio durieui should be given the rank of species, that is geographically confined to the Mediterranean part of Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia

Melanopsis mourebeyensis is considered to be a distinct morphotype by Ramdani et al. (1987) and by Ghamizi (1998). Applying the methodology of Heller et al. (2005) to differentiate Melanopsis species, M. mourebeyensis has to be considered as a distinctive Melanopsis species characterised by a nodular carena and a swollen body whorl.
Nomen nudum for a new species described by Ghamizi (1998) in his PhD thesis. Type specimen in the Musee de Paris.
The generic position is uncertain due to lack of anatomical data. Synonymisation according to Boeters (1976).
Nomen nudum for a new species described by Ghamizi (1998) in his PhD thesis. Type specimen in the Musee de Paris.
Generic position uncertain by lack of anatomical data. Synonymisation according to Boeters (1976), but here considered a distinct species.
The generic position is uncertain in absence of anatomical data. Synonymisation based on Boeters (1976)

This is a distinct species, possibly new genus. The generic status is uncertain due to lack of anatomical data. The taxonomy of the hydrobiids of Algeria has not been revised since 1864. A definite species, but may not be this genus.
The generic position is uncertain in absence of anatomical data. Synonymisation based on Boeters (1976)

In 1968, Brandt described a species named Hydrorissoia hospitalis. In 1974 he mentioned that this species is so closely related to H. munensis that it could be treated as a local morph, appearing in the Mun River.
Manningiella pellucida was assigned to Hubendickia pellucida by Davis (1979) (S. Attwood pers. comm. 2011).

Iberus is an Iberian Peninsula endemic genus, that comprised 20 morphospecies of uncertain validity (traditional classifications conflicted with each other mostly in the number of species), some of them occupying a very restricted geographical area. They were characterized mostly on the basis of the shell morphology because the reproductive system shows no diagnostic features at the specific level (Puente 1994, Arrébola 1995). Recently, Elejalde, Madeira, Arrébola et al. (2008) have studied partial DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and 16S rRNA) from different specimens of Iberus, to test the validity of the described morphospecies of the genus. The analysis have revealed 11 main phylogroups, being genetically unique lineages that are allopatrically distributed and considered to have full species status. One of them is I. gualtieranus, composed by three subspecies:  I.g. gualtieranus, I.g. mariae and I.g. ornatissimus. The first has a keeled and flattened shell with marked ornamentation of spiral and radial costulae (synapomorphy), while the other two show rounded and globose shells with soft ornamentation. I.g. mariae and I.g. ornatissimus have distinct and very restricted range and their shells clearly differ one from another. Both taxa were phylogenetically very closely related to I. g. gualtieranus, in contrast with the opinion of other authors who considered them to be more closely related to I. alonensis s.l., on the basis of shell morphology (Alonso and Ibáñez 1981).

Iberus is an Iberian Peninsula endemic genus, that comprised 20 morphospecies of uncertain validity (traditional classifications conflicted with each other mostly in the number of species), some of them occupying a very restricted geographical area. They were characterized mostly on the basis of the shell morphology because the reproductive system shows no diagnostic features at the specific level (Puente 1994, Arrébola 1995). Recently, Elejalde et al. (2008) have studied partial DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and 16S rRNA) from different specimens of Iberus, to test the validity of the described morphospecies of the genus. The analysis have revealed 11 main phylogroups, being genetically unique lineages that are allopatrically distributed and considered to have full species status. One of them is I. campesinus.

Iberus is an Iberian Peninsula endemic genus, that comprised 20 morphospecies of uncertain validity (traditional classifications conflicted with each other mostly in the number of species), some of them occupying a very restricted geographical area. They were characterized mostly on the basis of the shell morphology because the reproductive system shows no diagnostic features at the specific level (Puente 1994, Arrébola 1995). Recently, Elejalde, Madeira, Arrébola, Muñoz and Gomez-Moliner (2008) have studied partial DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and 16S rRNA) from different specimens of Iberus, to test the validity of the described morphospecies of the genus. The analysis have revealed 11 main phylogroups, being genetically unique lineages that are allopatrically distributed and considered to have full species status. One of them is I. ortizi. Previously, I. ortizi had been considered a minor form of  I. alcarazanus (Ortiz de Zárate in García San Nicolás 1957) although García San Nicolás (1957) assigned it a subspecific status: I. alcarazanus ortizi. However, the data provided by a recent taxonomic revision (Martínez-Ortí et al. 2004) indicate that I. alcarazanus should be considered as a synonym of I. alonensis. Consequently, I. ortizi is a valid name (Elejalde et al. 2008).

There is a general agreement that the undescribed form (Haplochromis sp. nov. 'Red tridens') is a clearly circumscribed species. The formal description for this species was published in 2010 (de Zeeuw and Witte in de Zeeuw et al. 2010).

There is a general agreement that the undescribed form (Haplochromis sp. nov. 'kribensis') is a clearly circumscribed species. The formal description for this species was published in 2010 (Neimantsverdriet and Witte in de Zeeuw et al. 2010).

There is a general agreement that the undescribed form (Haplochromis sp. nov. 'nigrofasciatus') is a clearly circumscribed species. The formal description for this species was published in 2010 (Niemantsverdriet and Witte in de Zeeuw et al. 2010).

Haplochromis sauvagei, Greenwood 1980 is a synonym of Haplochromis fischeri, however Haplochromis sauvagei, (Pfeffer, 1896) is a valid species. Except for very recent ones, most records for Haplochromis sauvagei refer to Haplochromis fischeri, and not Haplochromis sauvagei proper.

There is a general agreement that the undescribed form (Haplochromis sp. nov. 'citrus') is a clearly circumscribed species. The formal description for this species was published in 2010 (ter Huurne and Witte in de Zeeuw et al. 2010).

There is a general agreement that the undescribed form (Haplochromis sp. nov. 'Dusky Wine-red Fin') is a clearly circumscribed species. The formal description of this species was published in 2010 (Meites and Witte in Zeeuw et al. 2010).

There is a general agreement that the undescribed form (Haplochromis sp. nov. '75') is a clearly circumscribed species. The formal description of this species was published in 2010 (ter Huurne and Witte in de Zeeuw et al. 2010).

There is a general agreement that the undescribed form (Haplochromis sp. nov. 'Yellow') is a clearly circumscribed species. The formal description for this species was published in 2010 (Mietes and Witte in de Zeeuw et al. 2010).
This species has recently been placed in its own genus, Mirimiri (Helgen 2005). It was previously considered to belong to Pteralopex.
Bergmans (1990) has shown that this taxon differs more strongly from Pteropus seychellensis than formerly assumed. We follow Simmons (2005) in recognising P. aldabrensis as a distinct species.

The taxonomic status of this species is unclear (Mickleburgh et al. 1992). Conder (2008) states that the species is distinct from all other Australian Pteropus species, but there has been speculation that the single specimen might in fact be a vagrant of another species.

This taxon belongs to the subniger species group. Earlier listed under Pteropus hypomelanus Temminck, 1853 (Andersen 1908, Ellerman and Morrison-Scott 1951, Hill 1967), it is clearly distinct from hypomelanus in bearing softer and larger pelage and smaller dentition (Bates and Harrison 1997) hence treated as distinct species (Simmons 2005, Srinivasulu et al. in press).

This species has in the past been commonly confused with and previously referred to as C. aygula in Australian waters (Randall and Kuiter 1982). It was also referred to as C. cyaena by Whitley (1937) and others.
For taxonomic treatment see Allen (1983).
Pteropus santacrucis is a synonym of this species (Flannery 1995, Simmons 2005).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

There have been problems arising from earlier records of distribution and management of this species in southern Australia due to confusion with A. viridis up until 30 years ago. Earlier records of large size of A. viridis in South Australia (Scott et al. 1974) refer to A. gouldii as does management aspects of Achoerodus in the Spencer Gulf (J.H. Choat pers. comm.. 2008).

The original type locality cited by Ortiz de Zárate (1962) is an error, as Corbellá and Guillén (2002) demonstrated. However these authors considered the species to belong to the genus Gasullia while Arrébola et al. (2006) included it in the new genus Hatumia as Hatumia cobosi (with H. zapateri and H. riffensis).
Appeared in the IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006 under the generic name Ptyochromis.
This species is currently under taxonomic review, and is suspected to be a combination of many species (F. Köhler   pers.comm 2010).
Regarded by Davis as a valid taxa, and listed by Brandt (1974) as a valid species but overlooked during the assessment process.

Strong and Köhler (2009) suggest placement of this species in the family Semisulcospiridae. Some authors consider Biwamelania as a synonym or subgenus of Semisulcospira, and this treatment has recently been supported by a revision of the superfamily (Strong et al. 2011).
There are two recognised subspecies: D. c. caspia (Eichwald, 1855) and D. c. pallasi (Andrusov, 1897).

Further taxanomic studies are suggested as this species may represent a complex of species, with several narrow-range species, rather than the current relatively broad-range single species. Molecular studies (not yet performed) would be needed to assess this (P. Bouchet pers. comm. 2011).

Strong and Köhler (2009) suggest placement of this species in the family Semisulcospiridae. Some authors consider Biwamelania as a synonym or subgenus of Semisulcospira, and this treatment has recently been supported by a revision of the superfamily (Strong et al. 2011). This species may be in need of taxonomic revision, since its status has not been revised since its original description (F. Köhler pers. comm. 2010).
Strong and Köhler (2009) suggest placement of this species in the family Semisulcospiridae.

This species may be in need of taxonomic revision (F.Köhler pers. comm. 2010), since Strong and Köhler (2009) suggest placement of this species in the family Semisulcospiridae. Some authors consider Biwa as a synonym or subgenus of Semisulcospira.
Note that this species should not be confused with Physa arachleica Starobogatov & Prozorova, 1989.
Family is Pachychilidae; species revised by Köhler and Glaubrecht 2006.

DNA phylogenetic studies show that P. daanidentata is a monophyletic lineage, very closely related to P. cantabrica. Its specific or subspecific status requires further research  (Elejalde et al. 2009).

This species was originally described as Unio pullus (Conrad 1838). The Savannah River population was once described as a separate species, Carunculina patrickae (Bates 1966), due to different shell morphology.

Carunculina patrickae was synonymized with C. pullus by Johnson (1970), and is now known as Toxolasma pullus.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Prieto (1991) considered two subspecies: P. navasi navasi and P. navasi sylvatica with the latter living within forests and characterized by its greater size. Nevertheless, DNA sequenciation studies (Elejalde et al. 2009) showed that both morphs are only ecotypes, and subspecific categories should not be considered.

Kantor et al. (2009) describe this as a valid species, however Kabat and Hershler (1993) describe Pseudobenedictia as a subgenus of Kobeltocochlea. Sitnikova et al. (2006) refer to this species as Kobeltocochlea michnoi. For the purpose of this assessment, we follow the taxonomy as used by Kantor et al. (2009).
The status of this species has been confirmed by phylogenetic studies based on DNA sequences (Elejalde et al. 2009).

DNA sequences indicate that Pyrenaearia velascoi is closely related to P. carascalensis, but it constitutes a proper genetic lineage restricted to the Basque Country mountains. Although Altonaga et al. (1994) indicated that P. velascoi could be subdivided into two or three subspecies, molecular studies do not support subspecific taxa.

The genus Marstonia formerly was relegated to synonymy with Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987). But Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species and assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia (J. Cordiero pers. comm. 2010).

This species is believed to be a good species, based on both shell morphology and genetics (Bichain et al. 2007, Benke et al 2009). Prie concluded that B. lancelevei can be synonymised with B. viridis based on the molecular analyses performed by Benke et al. (2009) and morphological evidence (Prie pers. comm. 2009).

The genus Marstonia was formerly relegated to the synonomy of Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987), but Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia.

Abida ateni was considered to be a subspecies of Abida secale by Fauna Europeae (Bank et al. 2006). However, here, we follow Kokshoorn and Gittenberger (2010) who consider them to be distinct species.

Since its description, Lithobates fisheri (Stejneger 1893) has been considered a distinct species (Linsdale 1940; Jennings, Riddle and Bradford 1995), a subspecies of L. pipiens (Stebbins 1959) or a synonym of L. onca (Jennings 1988; Stebbins 2003). Morphological analyses support the view that L. fisheri represents a separate species (Jennings, Riddle and Bradford 1995).

Yellow-legged frog populations now recognized as Rana sierrae formerly were included in Rana muscosa. Vredenburg et al. (2007) examined phylogeography of Rana muscosa as defined by Stebbins (2003) and determined that R. muscosa occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada and in mountains to the south and that populations in the Sierra Nevada north of this range comprise a distinct species (Rana sierrae).

There has been historical confusion and controversy regarding the taxonomic status of various leopard frog populations in the region occupied by Lithobates onca (Jaeger et al. 2001). Some authors have identified extinct populations of leopard frogs in the Las Vegas Valley as L. onca while others consider these populations to have been a separate species, L. fisheri, the Vegas Valley leopard frog (see Jennings (1988)). The systematic relationship of the extinct Las Vegas populations remains unresolved (although see the unpublished report by Jennings, Riddle and Bradford (1995)). Some leopard frog populations along the Virgin River have been identified as L. yavapaiensis (see distributions in Stebbins 2003), but this perspective has been rejected (Jaeger et al. 2001).
Rana luteiventris was included in this species before it was elevated to species status by Green et al. (1996, 1997).
Some systematists doubt that Lithobates subaquavocalis is distinct from L. chiricahuensis.

authority: Gehring, Pabijan, Ratsoavina, Köhler, Vences & Glaw, 2010

taxonomicNotes: A photograph of the only known specimen of this species was included by Glaw and Vences (2007) as Paracontias hildebrandti, with the note that this identification was tentative.

It is likely that an unidentified species reported from the Ankarana Massif in the 1980s represents P. roesleri, but this is not known from specimens and so its identity cannot be confirmed (Glaw et al. 2010).

Germain (1930) and Alzona (1971) list this species under the authorship of Pollonera. According to Falkner et al. (2002) this is the synonym of Cochlostoma simrothi. By contrast, Gargominy and Ripken (2006) believed that it is a distinct taxon.
Described by Fehér (2004). In the Fuchs collection, specimens from the type locality were indicated as "Auritus bischoffi", but this name has never been published.

Populations that are now recognized as belonging to Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were formerly considered as part of Dendrotriton rabbi in the past, a species now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010).

Populations that are now recognized as belonging to Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were formerly considered as part of Dendrotriton rabbi in the past, a species now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010).
Alzoniella (A.) somiedoensis differs from A. (A.) rolani (Boeters, 1986), known from Galicia and Portugal, by a rough, scaly surface of the protooconch (Rolan et al. 2009).
Synonym: Belgrandia gibba Draparnaud, 1805 [partim]. in Nobre (1930: 206). The species Belgrandia gibba refers to both Belgrandia silviae and Belgrandia lusitanica; see Rolan and Oliviera (2009).

Belgrandia alcoaensis was considered as a subspecies by Haase (2000: 185) based on an examination of one shell (a paratype). Rolan and Oliveira (2009) have examined many specimens and consider it very different from the other Portuguese species due to the almost flat whorls, especially the last one, the prominent spiral cord and lack of any axial thickening.
There are three recognized subspecies: Rhinoceros sondaicus sondaicus, Rhinoceros sondaicus annamiticus (Extinct), and Rhinoceros sondaicus inermis (Extinct).
This species was listed as subspecies of I. gloubularis in Fauna Europea (Bank et al. 2006). but raised to a species by Arconada and Ramos (2006) after comparison work was done.
This new species is not listed in Fauna Europea (Bank et al. 2006).
This new species is not listed in Fauna Europea (Bank et al. 2006). Two subspecies were described I. henrici henrici (Córdoba populations) and I. henrici giennensis (Jaen populations).
This species was formerly considered to be in the genus Pygathrix.
It was formerly considered a subspecies of Rhinopithecus roxellana, but is now accepted as specifically distinct (Groves 2001).

The three presently recognized subspecies differ from one another mainly in tail length, as well as in certain features of skeletal structure and width of dental arch (Groves 2001). No genetic separation into distinct clades and therefore the sub-specific designation.
Groves in Wilson and Reeder (1993) also treats this as a distinct species but under the genus <Pygathrix. There is now good support to keep it in Rhinopithecus see Novak (1999).

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

The current IUCN Red List retains the genus Paramyxine until the above taxonomic work has been completed.

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

The current IUCN Red List retains the genus Paramyxine until the above taxonomic work has been completed.

The number of gill pouches in the original description of P. nelsoni was reported as four, based on the holotype, a small specimen with only four gill apertures. When latter dissected, it was found to have five gill pouches. Kuo and Mok (1999) redescribed the species based on 309 specimens, of which most of them had five and just nine had four gill apertures and/or pouches.

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

The current IUCN Red List retains the genus Paramyxine until the above taxonomic work has been completed.

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

The current IUCN Red List retains the genus Paramyxine until the above taxonomic work has been completed.

The correct spelling for this species should be Channa diplogramma. The species was described by Francis Day (1865) from Cochin, Malabar Coast, India. After a period of 146 years of taxonomic ambiguity and synonymy with Channa micropeltes, this species was validated by Benziger et al. (2011).

According to Fernholm (1986, 1998), E. octatrema was only known from the 300 mm holotype. In the original description, Barnard (1923) apparently described only one specimen, but he stated “…ventral fin ending only a short distance (8-10 mm) behind last gill-opening”. The range “8-10 mm” could be evidence that there were at least two specimens used for the description. In addition, the only other known specimen BMNH 1927.12.6.1 (formerly SAM 13031) is listed as "co-type" in the original register. According to the SAM database (M. Bougaardt pers. comm.), the station data for these specimens are: SAM 13030, Cape Saint Blaize, North 1/4 North, 6.5 miles, 36 fm (66 m), 28 June 1899, shrimp trawl, RV Pieter Faure; and BMNH 1927.12.6.1 [ex SAM 13031], Cape Saint Blaize, West 3/4 North, 4 miles, 27 fm (49 m), 25 January 1900, trawl, RV Pieter Faure. Based on this evidence, both specimens are considered here as syntypes of E. octatrema. Also, the type locality provided in Barnard’s (1923) original description (“Agulhas Bank, 25-40 fm”) is an assumed approximation.

Simmons (2005) follows Corbet and Hill (1992) by referring this species to the subgenus Boneia. Some authors (Andersen 1912; Koopman 1993) place it in its own genus (Boneia) but see Bergmans and Rozendaal (1988) and Bergmans (1994).
Taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1977). See also Groves (2001, 2005). Defler (2004) pointed out that two subspecies may exist as mentioned by Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976).

Saimiri taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005). An alternative taxonomy is presented by Thorington Jr. (1985) as follows: S. sciureus sciureus (includes the forms albigena, macrodon, and ustus recognized by Hershkovitz, [1984]), S. sciureus boliviensis (includes the forms pluvialis Lönnberg, 1940 and jaburuensis Lönnberg, 1940 recognized by Hershkovitz [1987]), S. sciureus cassiquiarensis, S. sciureus oerstedii (includes the form citrinellus recognized by Hershkovitz [1984]), and S. madeirae (given as a junior synonym of S. ustus by Hershkovitz [1984]). Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989) recognize S. sciureus caquetensis Allen 1916, given as a junior synonym of S. sciureus macrodon by Hershkovitz (1984). Costello et al. (1993) argued for the recognition of just two species: S. sciureus in South America, and S. oerstedii in Panama and Costa Rica. Boinski and Cropp (1999) using two nuclear genes (IRBP and ZFX) and one mitochondrial (D-Loop) strongly support the Hershkovitz (1984) taxonomy, advocating four distinct species: Saimiri sciureus, S. boliviensis, S. oerstedii and S. ustus.

See Rylands et al. (2006) for a discussion of the taxonomy of the Central American squirrel monkeys.

Squirrel vanzolinii (Ayres 1985) was described based on 13 specimens collected at the confluence of the Solimões and Japurá rivers and deposited in the Museum of Zoology at the University of São Paulo. The type locality is the northern shore of Lake Mamirauá, Amazonas, Brazil. Ayres (1985) allocated S. vanzolinii in the species group "Saimiri boliviensis" (Roman group), based on the taxonomic arrangement of Hershkovitz (1984). Saimiri vanzolinii was referred by Hershkovitz (1987) as a subspecies of S. boliviensis. Although no specimen was examined, Costello et al. (1993), based on the data described by Ayres (1985), considered S. vanzolinii as a junior synonym of S. sciureus. All subsequent authors followed Ayres (1985), considering S. vanzolinii as a valid species. More recently Lynch Alfaro et al. (2015) analyzed biogeographical and molecular data for the genus and concluded that S. vanzolinii is a valid species.
Recorded as Partula solitaria on Moorea by Crampton (1932) but reclassified by Kondo (1968). High altitude populations of S. attenuata turned out to be S. burchi (Ó. Foighi pers. comm.).
This may be closely related to S. abbreviata and S. conica, its shells being a greenish-yellow colour. It is dextral. (See Cowie report).
Unknown
Some people place this as a synonym of S. erythrophthalmus, but kept separate following Kottelat.

See Jackman et al. (2008) for a phylogeny of the genus Paroedura. Unpublished data by Hawlitschek et al. suggest that P. sanctijohannis is a species complex. For this assessment, we treat it as a single species.
This species represents one of three separate colonization events of the Comoros archipelago by the genus Phelsuma, as inferred by Rocha et al. (2009).

This species, together with P. pasteuri and P. v-nigra, represents one of three separate colonization events of the Comoros archipelago by the genus Phelsuma, as inferred by Rocha et al. (2007, 2009).
Menon (1987) described Noemacheilus sijuensis from Siju cave, Meghalaya, India. Kottelat et al. (2007) treated the species in the genus Schistura.

Until 2003, all Scleropages from southeast Asia were considered to belong to the same species; S. formosus. In 2003 Pouyaud et al., considered there to actually be four species, three of which they described as new (S. aureus, S. legendrei, S. macrocephalus). Kottelat and Widjanarti (2005) reviewed the published data and did not reach the same conclusions from the quality of the data presented, and in order for more than one species to be recognised, a professional standard study would need to be presented.

This species was formerly placed in the genus Nasalis. Recent molecular analysis suggest a close relationship between Simias and Nasalis, however, current classification still places Simias concolor in its own genus (Whittaker et al. 2006). To date, two subspecies are recognised, primarily based on slight differences in pelage coloration: S. c. concolor, which is found in Indonesia on the islands of Sipora, North Pagai, as well as South Pagai, and S. c. siberu, which is exclusively found on the island of Siberut (Miller 1903; Chasen & Kloss 1927).

The southern Hispaniolan Solenodon population (distributed south of the Neiba Valley) has been described as a separate subspecies (Solenodon paradoxus woodi Ottenwalder, 2001) on the basis of morphometric analysis, but genetic differences between northern and southern Hispaniolan Solenodon populations have not yet been assessed.

In 2000, this taxon was assessed for The IUCN Red List under the name Spermophilus brunneus brunneus; it is has since been transferred to the genus Urocitelus (Helgen et al. 2009) and in 2017 it was also raised to species level, replacing the entry for Urocitellus brunneus that previously appeared on The IUCN Red List. Yensen (1991) and Gill and Yensen (1992) suggested the two subspecies, U. b. brunneus and U. b. endemicus, may be full species. Although Thorington and Hoffmann (2005) listed endemicus as a synonym, genetic studies by Hoisington-Lopez et al. (2012) confirmed species-level separation. Urocitellus brunneus and U. endemicus are now recognized as monotypic species.
There are two well-differentiated clades (a northern one and a southern); their genetic difference is similar to that separating the other species of European cave salamanders (Carranza et al. 2007).
Eight subspecies have been described, but their validity was not confirmed in a comprehensive review of the species (Kryštufek 1996, 1999).
Giant sea bass was originally assigned to the grouper family, Serranidae, but was later placed in a new family called the Percichthyidae (Domeier 2001).

Originally described as a "Valvata", named Arganiella exilis in the French list of protected species, the name has been changed to Heraultia by Bodon et al. (2001) and then to Heraultiella by Bodon et al. (2002).

This species was originally described as Oestophora (Suboestophora) tarraconensis altamirai, dedicated to Carlos Altimira. Martínez-Ortí (1999) proposed to correct this mistake by naming this species as S. altimirai.

Suboestophora altimirai was considered a subspecies of S. tarraconensis. Based on anatomical studies of the reproductive system, the taxon has been raised to the species level (Martínez-Ortí 1995).

This species was previously known as Arkansia wheeleri, but changed to Arcidens wheeleri in Clarke (1981) and Graf and Cummings (2007).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
We followed Funk et al. (2007) in removing this species from the genus Sus and placing it in the monotypic genus Porcula.

There are two recognized subspecies: Sylvilagus graysoni graysoni and S. g. badistes (Cervantes 1997). S. graysoni is closely related to the adjacent mainland species S. cunicularius (Chapman and Ceballos 1990).
Sylvisorex isabellae possibly represents two similar, but distinct, species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of the two populations currently allocated to this species.

The name has until recently been used for all Corsican species of Tacheocampylaea (for which 27 names have been published). Thus, literature has to be carefully monitored, to understand which species is actually meant.
A polytypic species.  Some variations may represent distinct species or subspecies.

The taxonomy of this species is disputed, with some subspecies considered dubious (Brandon-Jones et al. 2004). Indeed, little work has been done on T. bancanus in the past 20 years and a taxonomic revision based upon intensive and systematic field surveys is overdue. Until more definitive evidence is available, and given that these allopatric populations have already been named as separate taxa, it is more conservative to treat them as distinct than not.

The form known as T. dianae (Niemitz et al. 1991) is almost certainly a subjective

junior synonym of T. dentatus (M. Shekelle pers. comm. 2007).
This taxon was formerly known as T. spectrum, but, Brandon Jones et al. (2004) argued that T. spectrum is a junior synonym of T. tarsier, and this has since been confirmed by Groves (2005).

Niemitz (1984) synonymized three of Hill’s (1955) Tarsius spectrum subspecies (the forms sangirensis, dentatus, and pelengensis) with T. s. spectrum. Feiler (1990) argued for the resurrection of T. sangirensis as a distinct species, an opinion that was independently supported by Shekelle et al. (1997) and Groves (1998). See Groves (2003).

Morphologically, this population appears to be distinct (Groves 2001). Acoustically, it shows many obvious superficial similarities with T. dentatus and might be related to that species (A. Nietsch and F. Burton unpubl. data). A. Nietsch (pers. comm.) nevertheless found the acoustics to be distinctive, in spite of the overall similarity.

There are two subspecies of the water vole: Arvicola sapidus sapidus (Miller, 1908) and Arvicola sapidus tenebricus (Miller, 1908). A. s. sapidus is present in Portugal and southern Spain, while A. s. tenebricus occurs in France and northern Spain. A. s. tenebricus is dark to reddish brown, while the coat of A. s. sapidus is generally lighter and more yellowish (Noblet 2005).

Synonym = Testudo leithii Günther, 1869 (non Testudo leithii Carter, 1852)). The species was classified into the subgenus Pseudotestudo by Loveridge and Williams (1957). This subgeneric name is nonapplicable for T. kleinmanni because the taxon was based on juvenile characters not retained into adulthood (Bour 1989).

Thamnophis hammondii, T. gigas, and T. atratus (including subspecies hydrophilus and aquaticus) formerly were included in Thamnophis couchii but now are recognized as distinct species (Rossman et al. 1996; Crother et al. 2000, 2003; Ernst and Ernst 2003).

Its taxonomic status is under revision; once complete, the revision will split the species into two species (T. pyrrhonotus and T. auricularis), each of which is likely to be threatened. This species should be reassessed following taxonomic clarification.
The identity of populations outside the state of Rio de Janeiro require clarification.
This species was previously considered a subspecies of the Pacific Bluefin Tuna (Thunnus orientalis) or Atlantic Bluefin Tuna (Thunnus thynnus).
This is now considered to be a separate species from the Pacific bluefin, Thunnus orientalis (Collette 1999).
Astacus astacus is comprised of three subspecies: Astacus astacus astacus, Astacus astacus balcanicus, Astacus astacus colchicus.

Known as Folifer yunnanensis by some researchers. It was originally described as F. yunnanensis. The genus is in need of further taxonomic investigation. It may be closer to Spinibarbus, and at present it would be better considered within Folifer (M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2011).

There is disagreement over the validity and physical separation of the subspecies.

Taxonomic Designations of subspecies are not well defined, and a genetic study refutes the Notes: assignment of any (Rosenblum et al. 1997). Phylogenetic studies have established separation of the two subspecies at the species level. T. auratus is closely related to T. cristatus, T. germaini, T. margarita, T. mauritius, and T. selangorensis (Roos et al, 2008) and together form the cristatus species group.

Wangchuk et al. (2003) described a new subspecies, T. g. bhutanensis, from Bhutan in the north of the range, with T. g. geei occurring in the south, the two taxa being separated by the Main Frontal Thrust (MFT) of the Indian plate hitting into the Himalayas (Bhargava 1997). However, T. g. bhutanensis is not recognized here as a valid subspecies, as it has not been described according to ICZN rules.

The taxonomy used here follows Groves (2001). The three named subspecies are morphologically well differentiated, but the association of them with available molecular sequences (Roos 2004) needs further investigation. Roos (2004) reported that “grey langurs” from northern Viet Nam were phylogenetically closer to T. francoisi than to other members of the T. phayrei group, and proposed that Viet Namese populations take the name T. phayrei and that others be considered specifically distinct. However, it is impossible for Viet Namese populations to take the name T. phayrei, as the type locality lies in Myanmar. On the basis of range and known morphology it is most likely that Roos’ Viet Namese populations represent T. p. shanicus, suggesting that perhaps this subspecies is specifically distinct (R.J. Timmins pers. comm.)

Four subspecies are currently recognized, although their validity is in some doubt (it is thought that seasonal variation in pelage color may account for at least some of the variation). The current treatment provisionally follows Groves (2005).

An additional subspecies, S. v. harti, is also recognized by some experts, but is here included as a synonym of S. v. philbricki (Groves 2001).

Mitochondrial DNA studies now classify Trachypithecus vetlus and Trachypithecus johnii under the genus Semnopithecus. Four subspecies of Semnopithecus vetulus are recognized, namely: vetulus, monticola, nestor, and philbricki.

Semnopithecus vetulus vetulus (Erxleben 1777) –Southern Purple Faced Langur - SW Sri Lanka in the Wet Zone, from Kalu Ganga (River) to Ranna in the south up to an elevation of 1000m. The area of distribution though is <5000km2.

Semnopithecus vetulus monticola (Kelaart, 1850)- Highland Purple Faced Langur— C Sri Lanka (1000-2200m)

Semnopithecus vetulus nestor (Bennett, 1833) - Western Purple Faced Langur--W Sri Lanka in the Wet Zone North of Kalu Ganga (River), up to 1000m elevation.

Semnopithecus vetulus philbricki (Philips, 1927)- Northern Purple Faced Langur- N & E Sri Lanka in the Dry Zone, up to 1500m.

This taxon was formerly considered as a subspecies of T. francoisi. The taxon was elevated to species level by Brandon-Jones (1984) and Groves (2001), the later conclusion being supported by molecular genetic studies (Roos, 2003, 2004) and parasitological findings (May, 1994).

This taxon, here considered monotypic, was regarded in the 1960s–1990s as conspecific with Trachypithecus francoisi (Steinmetz et al. 2011). A variety of later classifications have been suggested, all based on inadequate primary information for confidence in their value. For example, Roos et al. (2007) proposed the species T. laotum to contain also the subspecies T. l. hatinhensis (with T. [auratus] ebenus as provisionally synonymous with T. l. hatinhensis). It is here considered a distinct species (as per Roos et al. 2014), though its classification in relation to T. ebenus and T. hatinhensis cannot be resolved without additional primary information.

The earlier recognized subspecies, Trachypithecus poliocephalus leucocephalus is now a species on its own right. Trachypithecus poliocephalus poliocephalus, the once nominate taxon is a separate species (Roos et al. 2013, Zinner et al. 2013). It is a member of the francoisi group; and its former sub-specific congener, T. leucocephalus might have descended alongside T. poliocephalus from T. francoisi (Liuz et al. 2013).

The West Indian Manatee is currently divided into the Florida (T. m. latirostris) and Antillean (T. m. manatus) subspecies (Hatt 1934, Domning and Hayek 1986). Recent mtDNA data (García-Rodríguez et al. 1998, Vianna et al. 2006) indicate three distinctive lineages corresponding geographically with: (1) Florida and the Greater Antilles; (2) Western and Southern Gulf of Mexico, Central America, and NW South America west of the Lesser Antilles; and (3) NE South America east of the Lesser Antilles. Evidence exists for viable hybridization with T. inunguis near the mouth of the Amazon, in Guyana, French Guiana, and possibly Suriname.
A taxonomic review of the genus Trochulus spp. is underway by Gerhard Falkner and Ted von Proschwitz.
Puente (1994) considers X. montserratensis and X. betulonensis two different species. Martínez-Ortí and Bros are working to clarify the taxonomic status.

Although it is often possible to differentiate this species from X. jimenensis only using shell characteristics, a positive distinction can only be done by studying the reproductive system (Puente and Arrébola 1996).
The taxonomic validity of this species needs to be fully investigated, especially at the molecular level.

Was under the family Iguanidae.

Based on electrophoretic analyses, Adest (1977) concluded that Uma scoparia, Uma notata, and Uma inornata comprise a single species (Uma notata) (Adest 1977). Stebbins (1985, 2003) maintained the three taxa as distinct species. Phylogenetic relationships inferred from mtDNA sequences indicate that Uma notata rufopunctata is more closely related to Uma inornata than to Uma notata notata (Wilgenbusch and de Queiroz 2000, Trepanier and Murphy 2001). Trepanier and Murphy (2001) concluded that for the northern species of Uma existing data support either a two-species arrangement (Uma scoparia, Uma notata) or five-species classification (Uma scoparia, Uma notata, Uma inornata, and Uma rufopunctata, plus an undescribed species from Mohawk Dunes, Arizona). Trepanier and Murphy prefered the latter arrangement and stated that a description of the Mohawk Dunes species is in progress. Crother et al. (2003) adopted the taxonomy preferred by Trepanier and Murphy.

The current taxonomy of Ateles geoffroyi is based on Kellogg and Goldman (1944), Rylands et al. 2006, and Morales-Jiménez et al. (2015). Originally, detail analyses of cranial morphology and pelage coloration by Kellogg and Goldman (1944) recognized nine distinct subspecies. Hill (1962), Hall (1981), and Konstant et al. (1985) retained all these subspecies, but morphological and genetic analyses over the past two decades challenged the validity of these taxa. For example, Silva-López et al. (1996) exemplified the enormous variation in pelage coloration of Ateles in Mexico, Guatemala and Belize and concluded that A. g. pan Schlegel, 1876 and A. g. yucatanensis Kellogg and Goldman, 1944 was within the variation of A. g. vellerosus. Napier (1976) also showed that the type specimen A. g. panamensis Kellogg and Goldman, 1944 falls within the variation of A. g. ornatus, Gray, 1870 and recommended considering the former a synonym of the latter. Based on phylogenetic analyses of small fragments of mitochondrial DNA genes, Collins and Dubach (2000) recognized a northern and a southern group of spider monkeys in Central America, but due to their fragmentary sampling could not properly evaluate subspecies distinctiveness. Using ~800 bp of the mtDNA control region, Morales-Jiménez et al. (2015) analyzed the phylogenetic relationships of 49 spider monkeys sampled across Central America, and concluded that individuals from Mexico, Guatemala and Belize should be considered as part of A. g. vellerosus, while individuals from El Salvador should not be included in this taxon. They also found that individuals from southwestern Nicaragua and northwestern Costa Rica should be considered as A. g. frontatus and individuals from Azuero peninsula formed a monophyletic clade, supporting their recognition as distinct subspecies. However, despite recent efforts to improve our understanding of the phylogenetic relationships of the different subspecies of A. geoffroyi, conclusive results regarding the taxonomic validity of its subspecies still require analyses that include samples of individuals from southern Guatemala, Honduras, northern and eastern Nicaragua, central and western Panama, and eastern Costa Rica.Here, we tentatively recognized six subspecies: Ateles geoffroyi geoffroyi, Ateles geoffroyi azuerensis, Ateles geoffroyi frontatus, Ateles geoffroyi grisescens, Ateles geoffroyi ornatus, Ateles geoffroyi vellerosus..
There is a need to review the taxonomic status of animals from the Northern Sierra Madre of Luzon currently allocated to Varanus olivaceus.

This species is included in Montivipera following Nilson et al. (1999). Further taxonomic research is needed to clarify the validity of this species (W. Böhme pers. comm.). It may represent a synonym of M. xanthina (see Schatti et al., 1991), however recent electropheoretic analysis of blood-sera (Göçmen in press) support the recognition of M. albizona at the species level.
This species is sometimes considered to be conspecific with V. raddei (see McDiarmid et al. 1999).

Crochet and Dubois (2004), reported that there are nine subspecies, and a new taxonomic revision would probably produce at least three species. They also reported that Nilson and Andrén (2001) had raised one European and several Asiatic subspecies to species status. However, Crochet and Dubois (2004) suggested that these results needed to be corroborated by complementary approaches. Joger and Stümpel (2005), recently recognized V. ursinii as being restricted to Europe, ranging as isolated populations from France in the west to Moldova in the east. They further recognized populations east of Moldova, formerly allocated to V. ursinii, as belonging to V. renardi (Christoph, 1861). Joger and Stümpel (2005), further considered the disjunct population from southwestern Turkey, to be the distinct species, V. anatolica Eiselt and Baran, 1970. The current arrangement of Joger and Stümpel (2005) is followed here as the most recent publication on this complex group. This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).
