Bigelow and Schroeder (1953) provide good descriptions of the two species R. bonasus and R. brasiliensis from Brazilian material but admitted at the same time that the two forms may not be separate species. The name R. brasiliensis was not used again until a few years ago. Figueiredo (1977) cites only R. bonasus for Southwest Brazil and this may be the reason why subsequent authors assigned catches of Rhinoptera from this area to R. bonasus.

However Gallo-da-Silva et al. (1997 in Menni and Stehmann 2000) confirmed the existence of both species off Rio de Janeiro, and all three specimens of Rhinoptera collected off Rio Grande do Sul in the 1980s were R. brasiliensis (Soto unpub. data).

The two species differ in the size at birth. According to data listed by Bigelow and Schroeder (1953), R. brasiliensis has a broader mouth and greater distances between nostrils and between spiracles than R. bonasus, and this corresponds with the difference between the two species in the tooth plate conformation, brasiliensis having three central rows of broad teeth and bonasus only one such row.
Bott (1955) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Lobopotamonautes) perparvus gonocristatus Bott, 1955. It is recognised here as the valid species Potamonautes gonocristatus.
Bott (1955) treated this species as a junior synonym of Potamon (Geothelphsua) granviki Colosi, 1924. It is recognised here as Potamonautes idjiwiensis.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonautes) berardi ignestii. Cumberlidge (1998) treated it as the valid species Potamonautes ignestii.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonutes) infravallatus. Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes infravallatus.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Platypotamonautes) pilosus. Cumberlidge (1997) and Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes pilosus.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Lirrangopotamonautes) johnstoni platycentron.
Cumberlidge & Vannini (2004) described this interesting species from a number of localities in Tanzania and Kenya.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Potamonautes) johnstoni unisulcatus. Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) recognised this taxon as the valid species Potamonautes unisulcatus.
Synonym = Benthobatis marcida (Krefft reports on the FRV "Walther Herwig" captures).

Synonyms = Galeus arae (Soto, 1997); G. arae (Rincon, Vaske and Vooren, 1998); G. arae (Lessa, Marcante, Rincon, Gadig and El-Deir, 1999).

Taxonomic resolution needs review. The newly described species (Soto 2001) shows overlapping characters with G. antillensis (prepectoral length, anterior margin and posterior margin of pectoral fins) and the diagnosis is not conclusive. Probably the small sample number used in description (only four) restricted the range of variance for morphometric characters.

This taxon is sometimes considered to be in the genus Semnopithecus.
Hybridizes as a brown hybrid with S. priam where parapatric.
Synonyms = Plectostoma decrespignii; Opisthostoma decrespignii.

Simmons (2005) records that this species has been formerly included in Rhinolophus maclaudi (e.g., Smith and Hood 1980) or R. ruwenzorri (e.g., Csorba et al. 2003), but was found by Fahr et al. (2002) to be distinct from both of these species.
This taxon was initially included within Rhinolophus maclaudi by Koopman (1993), but has more recently been recognized as a valid species (see Fahr et al. 2002, Csorba et al. 2003 and Simmons 2005).
A split from the R. maclaudi complex.
This species was previously a synonym of Otomys anchietae. It was found to be distinct by Taylor and Kumurai (2001).
This species was previously considered a subspecies of Otomys tropicalis.

Hill (1960) listed three species of bearded saki: Chiropotes chiropotes, C. satanas and C. albinasa [sic]. Hershkovitz (1985) described a new species, utahickae, and classified satanas and utahickae as subspecies of C. chiropotes. Groves (2001, 2005) followed the taxonomy of Hershkovitz (1985). The three subspecies of Chiropotes satanas (satanas, chiropotes and utahicki) are here listed as full species following the recommendation of Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002), Figueiredo et al. (2006), and Silva-Júnior et al.(2013). Bonvicino et al. (2003) resurrected the name Chiropotes israelita (Spix, 1823) for the bearded saki discovered by Boubli (2002) to the west of the Rio Branco, a tributary of the Rio Negro, Amazonas, Brazil. Genetic and pelage differences, notably a greenish brown (olive) dorsum as opposed to light golden brown as is typical of C. chiropotes, distinguish it from the bearded sakis of the Guianas to the east of the Rio Branco. There is however, a possible confusion concerning the correct names. Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002) argued that the form west of the Rio Branco is, correctly Chiropotes chiropotes (Humboldt, 1811), according to its type locality, and the form to the east of the Rio Branco, extending through the states of Pará and Amapá, and into the Guianas (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana) is C. sagulatus (Traill, 1821) from Demerara (see Silva-Júnior et al. (2013). Doubts still remain, however, concerning Hershkovitz’s interpretation of Humboldt’s type locality of C. chiropotes, which would accordingly alter the nomenclature (J. P. Boubli, pers. comm). With the further research and phylogenetic analysis, both Traill’s sagulatus and Spix’s israelita may be valid species names for different populations of this wide ranging genus.
Listed in the 1996 Red List as Chondrostoma kneri but following FISHBASE it is Chondrostoma knerii. Orthographic error not included in synonyms list.
Was listed in the 1996 Red List as prespensis which was incorrectly spelt.
Thompson and Hershler (2002) propose the genus Floridobia to accommodate species from the eastern United States formerly placed in the genus Cincinnatia (J. Cordiero, pers. comm. 2010).

Clupeonella muhlisi from Lake Apolyond (in Sea of Marmara basin in Turkey) usually considered as a synonym of C. abrau is indeed a synonym of C. cultriventris. Both species cannot be distinguished by morphological or molecular characters. Also Clupeonella abrau is very closely related to C. cultriventris and is not supported as an own evolutionary lineage by molecular data (COI). However, the morphological differences suggest that it is a young species evolved from C. cultriventris. Therefore, we keep C. abrau as a valid species in the Red List.
The generic status of this taxon remains unresolved (Kottelat 1997).
Coelops hirsutus was previously considered a subspecies of Coelops robinsoni (Corbet and Hill 1992), however, we follow L. Heaney (pers. comm. 2007) in considering it to be a distinct species.

Booth (1954), Oates and Trocco (1983), Groves et al. (1993), Groves (2001) and Grubb et al. (2003) considered Dollman’s Black-and-White Colobus monkey, Colobus polykomos dollmani Schwarz, 1927, from areas between the Sassandra and Bandama Rivers in Western Côte d’Ivoire to be a hybrid of C. vellerosus × C. polykomos. Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) and Grubb et al. (2003) listed dollmani as a junior synonym of C. vellerosus. The question of the validity or otherwise of this form was raised by Gonedelé Bi et al. (2006) who, carried out surveys in 2003–2004 in three forest reserves and Marahoué National Park in search of Colobus polykomos dollmani between the Sassandra and Bandama Rivers and found just one group in Bolo Forest Reserve. But reviewing the evidence, Oates and McGraw (2009) opined that dollmani is a Colobus polykomos x Colobus vellerosus hybrid and should not be considered as a subspecies. Gonedelé Bi et al. (2014) subsequently conducted a survey in 2012 in the same region, but Bolo-Dassiéko-Niégré complex had been converted into a cocoa plantation. They found one group in Grébouo I Forest Grove, which is in close proximity to Bolo, where they found that the monkeys had a similar pelage as Colobus vellerosus, but in one vocal aspect, they were similar to Colobus polykomos. However, modest vocal data analysed by these authors produced more complex results. In one parameter (duration), the roar was similar to Colobus vellerosus; whereas it was more similar to Colobus polykomos than to Colobus vellerosus in the number of roars or subunit calls. Hence, Gonedelé Bi et al. (2014) were reluctant to draw definitive conclusions based on vocalisations.

Grubb et al. (2003) list two subspecies: C. s. satanas from Bioko, and C. s. anthracinus from the mainland.

Groves (2001, 2007) listed Colobus satanas anthracinus from Gabon (see Gautier-Hion et al. 1999) as a junior synonym of Colobus satanas (which occurs on Bioko Island). Groves (2005) and Grubb et al. (2003), however, listed it as a valid subspecies.  Oates et al. (2000) found that the loud calls (roar pulse rate) of the two forms were significantly distinct (lower in C. s. satanas).
Listed as a separate species from C. polykomos following Oates and Trocco (1983), Grubb et al. (2003) and Groves (2005).
At some time, the name C. lavaretus has been used for about all Eurasian coregonids (and many North American ones). Its use is now restricted to the present species.

Usually considered to be present in all tributaries of North Sea basin. 'Houtings' from Danish North Sea basin and German rivers from Eider, Elbe west to Ems are C. maraena, a species widespread in Baltic basin.

We retain all the above listed populations (including some winter spawning ones) in C. trybomi. Allozyme data suggest that the different populations have arisen independently from a sympatric population of autumn spawning ciscoes and are distinct species. In this case, three of the four species endemic to Sweden are already extinct.

Blackburn (2008) stated that its molecular data indicates this species is actually Arthroleptis aureoli and it was reported as a direct developer, which confirms it as belonging to the genus Arthroleptis (M.-O. Rodel pers. comm. June 2012).
There are taxonomic difficulties with this species, and it is possible that Ansonia rubigina is a synonym of it (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species might be a synonym of Ansonia ornata (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
There is an ongoing debate on the genus placement of this species (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
This species was elevated to species status by La Marca (1983).

Molecular data and morphological, ecological, and demographic analyses suggest that the Panamanian golden frogs and their kin (the Atelopus varius-zeteki clade) are comprised of five distinct forms (Zippel et al. 2006). Additional analyses identify phenotypic and genetic differentiation consistent with proposed Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs), and support the status of Atelopus varius and Atelopus zeteki as separate species (Richards and Knowles 2007). Atelopus zeteki distribution is limited to the vicinity of El Valle de Anton and Cerro Campana.

This species was recently redescribed by Lötters, La Marca and Vences (2004) following the discovery that the original type material represents Atelopus varius of Central America. The former junior synonym A. vogli is considered to be a distinct species following Lötters, La Marca and Vences (2004).
The subpopulation on Gorgona Island could be recognized as a distinct species, A. gracilis (Rueda-Almonacid et al. 2005), but is retained here pending a formal taxonomic treatment.
This species may be a synonym of Atelopus flavescens (P. Kok and A. Fouquet pers. comm. November 2017).
The specimens in the lowlands may be a different species as they are based on old museum specimens and doubtful collecting localities.
Inclusion in genus Rhaebo is provisional (Frost 2014).

Cocroft et al. (1990) and Lötters et al. (2002b) suggested that Atelopus spumarius might be a complex of more than one species. Lescure and Marty (2001) recognize two subspecies: A. s. barbotini Lescure 1981; and A. s. hoogmoedi Lescure 1973 without arguments and in contrast to their earlier opinion. Lötters et al. (2002b) suggested that A. spumarius occurs in the upper Amazon Basin only (Peru, Colombia, Brazil); populations from southern Peru, Ecuador and central Brazil might refer to undescribed taxa within A. spumarius sensu lato. Populations from the Guianas and eastern Amazonia might be treated as A. hoogmoedi complex (maybe within A. spumarius sensu lato). Atelopus spumarius hoogmoedi is a synonym of A. spumarius under Lescure and Gasc (1986). This form is understood by Lescure and Gasc (1986) to be more or less A. spumarius sensu lato; however, A. spumarius hoogmoedi is not conspecific with A. spumarius sensu stricto (S. Lötters pers. comm.)
Lötters et al. (2011) elevated A. spumarius barbotini to species level.

Molecular data and morphological, ecological, and demographic analyses suggest that the Panamanian golden frogs and their kin (the Atelopus varius-zeteki clade) are comprised of five distinct forms (Zippel et al. 2006). The species has a variable appearance and color and pattern are poor diagnostic characteristics for identification of this species (Richards and Knowles2007). Some populations have a very yellow color, resembling Atelopus zeteki, which is why both Atelopus varius and Atelopus zeteki are sometimes referred to as golden frogs in Panama (Estrada et al. 2014). Genetic analysis of mitochondrial DNA reveals support for recognizing A. varius and A. zeteki as separate clades, but sorting of haplotypes was imperfect and Costa Rican samples sorted into a third outlying group (Richards and Knowles 2007). Genetic examination of the phylogeny of this group would be helpful, but the extreme declines of this group will make sourcing of fresh, genomic quality tissues challenging.
This species was recently recognized as distinct from Atelopus cruciger by Lötters, La Marca and Vences (2004).
The taxonomy and relationships of this species need re-evaluation (Biju 2001).

Four subspecies have been described: P. l. longinasus in Pinar del Río; P. l. cajalbanensis in the Cajálbana Plateau, also in Pinar del Río; P. l. dunni in the mountains of Guamuhaya; and P. l. ramsdeni in the Sierra del Guaso. (González Alonso et al., 2012)
This species was elevated from subspecific status under Peltophryne guentheri by Powell (1993).
This species is currently under taxonomic review.
McCranie and Wilson (2002) refer all Honduran material to Bufo coccifer.
Harvey and Smith (1993) pointed out that Rhinella echinodes, described by Reynolds and Foster (1992), is a synonym of R. quechua. This species is possibly a complex of more than one species.
Due to its morphological intermediacy between Duttaphrynus and Amietophrynus, Frost has returned this concept to the uncertain status of "Bufo" scorteccii.

The Colombian populations have different skin texture and some morphological differences compared to Ecuadorian populations. More research is needed to determine whether or not this is in fact two separate species (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).

Preliminary comparison of the skull morphology between specimens from  Thailand and Myanmar, in combination with existing information on  genetic and echolocation, suggested that the population in Myanmar may  represent a different taxon (P. Soisook, unpublished data). The  taxonomic revision is needed.
Elevated to full species status by Klappenbach and Langone (1992).
The identity of the specimens from the northern part of Parque Nacional Llanganates requires confirmation.

This species is a complex of species, hence its apparently varying conservation status in the different countries in its range (J.V. Rueda pers. comm., G. Gonzalez pers. comm. July 2018 Guayasamin et al. 2008).
This species may be a synonym of Centrolene lynchi (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2016).
This species and Centrolene scirtetes may be conspecific (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).

Recently transferred from Cochranella to Centrolene by Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007). Cisneros and McDiarmid (2006) indicate that the specimens reported by Ruiz and Lynch (1991) from Valle del Cauca may be an undescribed form. Guayasamin et al.(2009) regarded this species as incertae sedis within Centroleninae. Guayasamin et al. (2019) have moved it to Nymphargus.
Recently transferred from Hyalinobatrachium to Cochranella by Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007).
In the past, some specimens of this species were considered to be Hyalinobatrachium fleishmanni.

It is possible that two species might be included in Hyalinobatrachium orientale in Venezuela, one being the species from the type locality, and the other an undescribed form from Macizo del Turimiquire. Animals on Tobago might also belong to a different species.
It has been suggested that this species is not native to Martinique, but is synonymous with another species from South America (M. Breuil pers. comm.).
Molecular data suggest that Allobates kingsburyi is a species complex (L.A. Coloma pers. comm.).

Lötters (1992b) doubted the distinction of this species from Oophaga histrionica.

Records from the Serrania de Baudo and Alto del Oso in the Department of Chocó that were previously questioned to belonging to this species have now been verified and assigned as Oophaga solanensis (Posso-Terranova and Andrés 2018).
Based on morphological analyses, Verdade and Rodrigues (2007) allocate all Atlantic Forest species of Allobates to synonymy with Allobates olfersioides.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Allobates brunneus by Silverstone (1971).
This frog was tentativelly assigned to Mannophryne herminae, but its taxonomic status needs further research (La Marca 1999).

Morphological and chromosomal evidence support the hypothesis that Mannophryne trinitatis is restricted to the island of Trinidad (Barrio-Amorós et al., 2006). The population from Península de Paria, Venezuela, has been found to be a different species, Mannophryne venezuelensis (Manzanilla et al., 2007).

Previous to Grant et al. (2006) the genus Aromobates was known only by a single species: A. nocturnus (Myers et al. 1991). Then, Grant et al. (2006) moved all Colostethus of the alboguttatus group (sensu Rivero 1988) or Nephelobates (sensu La Marca 1994) to Aromobates and provided a well-corroborated phylogeny of the genus. Barrio-Amorós & Santos (2012) provide a phylogeny and a list with current threats for all species of the genus. Rivero (1982a) included Colostehus inflexus Rivero, 1978 in the synonymy of C. alboguttatus. Myers, Paolillo and Daly (1991) and La Marca (1997) revive the species as Nephelobates inflexus in their works without explanation. Recently, Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) consider inflexus different from A. alboguttatus and a valid species, but waiting proper attention.

There are two subspecies: Argenteohyla siemersi siemersi and A. s. pederseni. Taxonomic studies are ongoing to evaluate the taxonomic status of the two subspecies; preliminary results do not support the hypothesis that A. s. pederseni and A. s. siemersi represent distinct species, but rather the same species with color variants (R. Cajade pers. comm. September 2017).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Charadrahyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich, et al. 2005). The taxonomic relationship between G. cornuta and G. ceratophrys needs to be clarified (Luis A. Coloma pers. comm. 2007). It is possible that the specimen collected from Manta Real, Ecuador, represents a new species (Ana Almendáriz pers. comm. 2007). Overall, while there appear to be variations between the Central American and South American individuals, Duellmann and Trueb (2015) noted that they are insufficiently distinguished based on physical characteristics alone and that no clear pattern exists between the variations.
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

The original type locality of this species was Panama, but this is in error according to Savage and Heyer (1969) who suggested that the type specimen might have come from Colombia, Peru or Bolivia. Subsequently, Duellman and De la Riva (1999) found a single specimen. This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005). Faivovich et al. (2018) discussed the tentative nature of the assignment of this species to Exerodonta, and the generic assignment is currently under revision (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the genus Charadrahyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was rediscovered by J. Aparicio and S. Reichle in 1997 at the type locality.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005).

De la Riva et al. (2000) registered a slight doubt as to the taxonomic validity of the species. Faivovich and De la Riva (2006), however, continue to recognize it as a valid species, pending a revision of populations associated with the name Hyloscirtus armatus. In the Hyloscirtus armatus group according to Faivovich and De la Riva (2006).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). We follow Duellman (2001) and Savage (2002) in assigning records from Colombia and Ecuador to Ecnomiohyla phantasmagoria.

Ecnomiohyla miliaria is currently a species complex which is under revision (Brian Kubicki pers. comm.).

This species is possibly a species complex, and further taxonomic work needs to be carried out to verify the identity of Honduran and Guatamalan subpopulations (Duellman and Campbell 1992, J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
This species could be conspecific with Plectrohyla sagorum (M. Acevedo pers. comm.).
The forms that occur in Honduras have been separated to form the species Plectrohyla exquisita (McCranie and Wilson 1998).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but was moved to the genus Hylomantis by Faivovich et al. (2005). Subsequently, it was moved from Hylomantis to Agalychnis by Favivovich et al. (2010).

The use of this name has been clarified by McCranie and Wilson (1993b). This species has been moved from Ptychohyla to Atlantihyla ().

Solis pers. comm. March 2019).

The taxonomic allocation of the western subpopulation to this species was questioned by S.B. Hedges and L. Diaz. The western subpopulation of this species was removed from this concept for its reassessment in 2013 (J. Luedtke pers. comm. July 2015).
The genus Paramophrynella was proposed by La Marca (2007); Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Paramophrynella in the synonymy of Pristimantis, which includes Pristimantis boconoensis.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

La Marca (2007) recently erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis.

Eleutherodactylus dixoni Lynch 1991 is a synonym of E. albolabris (Taylor 1943).

Taylor (1943) first described Tomodactylus albolabris, which Hedges (1989) later reclassified as a species of Eleutherodactylus (Syrrhophus). Prompted by this merger, Lynch (1991) proposed E. dixoni as a replacement name forE. albolabris, believing it to be a junior secondary homonym of Microbatrachylus albolabris Taylor 1939 because that genus had also been combined with Eleutherodactylus (Lynch 1965). However, M. albolabris had already been synonymized with M. pygmaeus by Duellman (1961), obviating the need for a replacement name. Thus, the earliest name available for this taxon is Eleutherodactylus (Syrrhophus) albolabris.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Two new species were described from the species group to which Craugastor coffeus (C. laticeps group) belongs, it is possible, albeit unlikely based on distinguished external morphological characteristics, there is additional taxonomic change yet to be determined (McCranie 2018).

There is doubt about the validity of this species as it was described from a single specimen based on a variable trait (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Genetic analysis has revealed potential cryptic lineages within this species (Crawford et al. 2013), however further taxonomic work is required for verification.
Included by some authors in the genus Syrrhophus.

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was recently separated from Eleutherodactylus bransfordii.
Some historic records of Eleutherodactylus pinarensis might refer to juveniles of E. klinikowskii, and so are not included here (L. Díaz pers. comm.).

There is uncertainty about the taxonomic status of this name in Venezuela. Kaiser, Hardy and Green (1994) state that South American records are based on misidentifications. J. Hardy (pers. comm.) has seen specimens from Venezuela in North American institutions; these are in poor condition and are mis-identifications of Pristimantis urichi. Here we consider the species to be endemic to Trinidad and Tobago, not occurring on the South American mainland.
Lehr (2006) recently synonymized Phrynopus laplacai under Psychrophrynella wettsteini.
We follow De la Riva et al. (2000) in considering this species to be separate from Telmatobius marmoratus, and also follow De la Riva (2004) in considering T. jahuira as a synonym of T. verrucosus.
Telmatobius albiventris and Telmatobius crawfordi were synonymized with this species by Benavides, Ortiz and Sites (2002).
Zhao and Adler (1993) considered this species to be synonymous with Oreolalax major but did not give any reason.
Inger et al. (1990) considered Oreolalax puxiongensis to be synonymous with O. schmidti.
Zhao and Adler (1993) regarded this species to be synonymous with Scutiger ruginosus (= S. mammatus) without discussion.

Diagnosis: This species is closely related to Scutiger chintingenis (Liu et Hu), but differs from the latter by 1) upper jaw toothless, and 2) very rough skin with black spines as much as scuttered over the whole body.

Fei, Ye and Chen (1986) considered that this taxa is just a polymorphic form of Scutiger gladulatus and Scutiger mammatus. It has been reported from two locations but one of these might refer to S. muliensis.
This species was synonymized with Leptobrachium ailaonicum by Cuc et al. (1999), although this was rejected by Ohler et al. (2000).
Fei et al. (1999) considered this taxon to be a subspecies of Xenophrys minor but did not provide any explanation. We here consider it to be a full species.
This species is monotypic (Bidau 2015).
Nothophryne unilurium, N. donaldi, and N. baylissi. have been split from this species by Conradie et al. (2017--forthcoming) and a fourth species is pending description.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (de Freitas in press)."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14781,"3":{"1":0,"3":1},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Helvetica Neue","16":10}">This species is monotypic (de Freitas 2016).
This species has been reported from several additional localities, although these likely refer to undescribed species (S.D. Biju pers. comm.)
Amolops daiyunensis was considered a synonym of A. hongkongensis by Yang (1991), but we follow Fei et al. (1999), Jin et al. (2005) and Ngo et al. (2006) in treating it as a separate species.
Zhao and Adler (1993) considered this species to be synonymous with Amolops liangshanensis but Liu and Yang (1995) provided evidence to show that both species are valid.
Tadpoles of this species have never been recorded, and so it has been argued that this form should not be assigned to the genus Amolops but instead to Odorrana.
The supopulation in Atewa, Ghana is most likely a separate species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
A number of specimens referred to this species in the past are likely to have been misidentified (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).

Rao (1937) originally described this taxon as Philautus kottigeharensis based on a single specimen from Kottigehar. Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred the species from Philautus to Micrixalus. The holotype was lost and recently Bossuyt and Milinkovitch (2001) relocated the species from Bhadrea in Chicamangalore District very near to the type locality. Formal designation of the neotype is under way (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
A number of specimens assigned to Micrixalus nudis are thought to be misidentifications. A detailed taxonomic study is required for further clarification (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Liurana (see Fei et al. 1999). The taxonomy of this species is unclear at present; it might be a synonym of a Southeast Asian species.
The five available museum specimens require further comparison with specimens of Nannophrys ceylonensis.

The original description of this species, as Nyctibatrachus hussaini (Krishnamurthy et al. 2001), did not provide any information about the type specimen. Hence, its taxonomy and nomenclature required further investigation and amendments (Biju 2001; Das and Kunte 2005; S.K. Dutta pers. comm.). Dinesh et al. (2007) provided the replacement name, Nyctibatrachus karnatakaensis.
This species is part of the Limnonectes modestus complex (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
There is quite considerable intraspecific variation in this taxon (Biju 2001).

Fei et al. (2000) in transferred this species from Rana to Pseudoamolops, but we retain it in Rana. High-altitude populations are now regarded as a separate species, Rana multidenticulata (Chou and Lin 1997a).
This species is endemic to China and records of this species from Tibet are in fact Nanorana chayuensis (DQ Rao pers. comm June).
This form probably represents two separate species.
Brown (1965) described two subspecies within Platymantis parkeri: P. p. parkeri from Bougainville; and P. p. bukanensis from Buka.

This species is now regarded as being endemic to the island of Karpathos; populations on Rhodes that were previously assigned to this species are now allocated to P. bedriagae (Lymberakis et al. 2007). The taxonomy of Pelophylax is complex and further studies are ongoing.
The species status of Pelophylax cretensis is "confirmed" by short mtDNA sequences and a large number of private allozyme alleles not found in any other water frog (P. Beerli pers. comm.).
This species is a member of the Lithobates pipiens complex.
This species does not produce hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).

authority: (Cuellar, Méndez-De La Cruz and Villagrán-Santa Cruz, 1996)

taxonomicNotes: Northern populations of this species might represent a distinct species. Smith and Ciszar (2003) consider the record of L. pustulosus from 13km W Matáchic, Chihuahua, Mexico, to actually refer to L. chiricahuensis.

authority: Li, Ye & Fei in Fei, Ye & Li, 2001

taxonomicNotes: We follow Ohler (2007) in treating Rana hmongorum, described by Bain et al. (2003), as a synonym of this species.

authority: Huang, Fei & Ye in Fei and Ye, 2001

taxonomicNotes: Jiang, Hu and Zhao (1987) considered this species to belong to the genus Buergeria, rather than Rhacophorus, and this is now widely accepted.
Genetic studies showed that this form is distinct from populations of Lithobates capito and L. areolata, and has therefore been established as a separate species (Young and Crother 1991).

Although Schneider and Haxhiu (1994) had difficulty distinguishing the voice of Pelophylaxa shqipericus from that of P. lessonae, morphology, allozymes, mtDNA sequences, and crossing experiments all indicate that P. shqipericus is very distinct from P. lessonae. Its relationships with other western Palearctic water frogs are less clear (T. Uzzell pers. comm.). This species does not make hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).

This species was synonymized with Pelophylax nigromaculatus by Fei, Ye and Huang (1991), and this synonymy was accepted by Dubois (1992) and Dubois and Ohler (1996). However, Zhao and Adler (1993) still consider this to be a valid species and hence it is included here pending a definitive decision on its taxonomic status.
NEED TO CONTACT J. JIANPING FOR LATEST TAXONOMIC REVISION, THIS SPECIES MAY NOT BE P. MONGOLICA

authority: (Xu in Wu, Xu, Dong, Li & Liu, 1983)

taxonomicNotes: Specimens recorded as Philautus temporalis and P. leucorhinus from the Western Ghats of India are now considered to be P. wynaadensis. P. temporalis and P. leucorhinus are endemic species of Sri Lanka (S.D. Biju and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm.; Bossuyt and Dubois 2001).

authority: (Liu & Hu In Liu, Hu, Fei & Huang, 1973)

taxonomicNotes: This species is considered distinct from Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species is known only from the holotype which has been misplaced. The type description is not detailed enough to determine whether this species is still extant.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Philautus microtympanum by Dutta and Manamendra-Arachchi (1996).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus leucorhinus (Günther, 1858) following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
Philautus sanctipalustris is an incorrect subsequent spelling of Philautus sanctisilvaticus according to Bossuyt and Dubois (2001).
We consider this species to be distinct from Philautus nanus (Günther, 1858) following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
We follow Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) in considering this species to be separate from Philautus microtympanum, and belonging to the genus Philautus, rather than Polypedates.
Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) suggested that this species could be a synonym of Ixalus beddomii Günther, 1876. However, recent studies indicate that both species are distinct (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).

Specimens of Philautus charius recorded from Ponmudi Hills and surroundings and Wayanad were assessed separately as new undescribed species Philautus sp. nov. "Kalpatta" (S.D. Biju pers. comm.). This species was subsequently described as P. anili Biju and Bossuyt, 2006.
This species is considered distinct from Philautus microtympanum, following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
Specimens refered to this species from Ponmudi and surroundings in India, are now included in the newly described species, Philautus sp. nov. 'Ponmudi Hills' (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species assessment is based on the recent taxonomic revision by Bossuyt and Dubois (2001).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus nanus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005). Further taxonomic studies on this species are required.
We consider this species to be distinct from Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Rhacophorus.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Philautus microtympanum by Dutta and Manamendra-Arachchi (1996).
This species was moved to the genus Philautus from Theloderma by Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
Specimens recorded from Ponmudi Hills (and possibly Wayanad) as Philautus signatus are in the process of being described as the new species Philautus sp. nov. 'Ponmudi_3' (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species was previously assessed as Philautus sp. nov. 'Amboli Forest'.
This species was first reported by Inger et al. (1984) from Ponmudi as Philautus femoralis.
This species is known only from the now lost holotype.

Specimens formerly attributed to Philautus temporalis and P. leucorhinus from the Western Ghats are now correctly assigned to P. wynaadensis. P. temporalis and P. leucorhinus are now considered to be endemic species of Sri Lanka (S.D. Biju and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm.).

Specimens formerly attributed to Philautus variabilis from the Western Ghats of India are misidentified P. wynaadensis. P. variabilis is endemic to Sri Lanka, where it is now considered to be extinct (K. Manamendra-Arachchi and S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus microtympanum following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species was previously placed in the genera Rhacophorus and Polypedates.
Inger et al. (1990) regarded this taxon as a junior synonym of Batrachuperus pinchonii. It was removed from the synonymy of B. pinchonii by Ye, Fei and Hu (1993).

Ye, Fei and Hu (1993) stated that the distinguishing features between Batrachuperus tibetanus and B. karlschmidti (colouration and the number of gill filaments) are quite variable and that the two taxa should be synonymized. Fu et al. (2001) confirmed the distinctiveness of B. karlschmidti, and suggested, on the basis of molecular evidence, that the nominal B. tibetanus comprises four species, three of which are undescribed.

Nishikawa et al. (2001) demonstrate that the populations on Honshu, Shikoku, and Kyushu belong to three separate species, but the formal naming of the populations on Shikoku and Kyushu is pending. Hynobius boulengeri is here provisionally treated as a single species.

The population currently allocated to Hynobius chinensis from Fujian Province, China, might represent a new species. We retain the Fujian population in H. chinensis until further taxonomic studies are undertaken. We consider H. yiwuensis (Cai, 1985) to be a valid species separate from H. chinensis following Fei, Ye and Huang (1990) and Fu et al. (2003).
This taxon was recently reallocated to the new genus Ghatixalus and is considered to be the sister species of Ghatixalus asterops (Biju et al. 2008).
The taxonomic validity of this species is now well accepted (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).

The species boundaries between this species and both Ambystoma lermaense and A. rivularis require further investigation. However, these three taxa are clearly differentiated from all other Mexican ambystomatids (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).

The species was previously included in the genus Rhyacosiredon. Based on unpublished allozyme and mtDNA sequence data, it is a well-defined taxon distinct from Ambystoma (Rhyacosiredon) altimirani (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).
This taxon might be a complex of several species (Highton, 2000).
It is not clear that the Panamanian and Colombian populations belong to the same species, and even within Colombia there might be several species within this concept.
Hynobius yiwuensis is here treated as a valid species, separate from H. chinensis, following Fei et al. (1999) and Fu et al. (2003).
This species might be a complex of more than one species.
This species might be a synonym of Pachyhynobius shangchengensis.
This species was originally confused with Bolitoglossa striatula.

authority: Hu and Fei in Hu, Fei and Ye, 1978
taxonomicNotes: Kuzmin and Thiesmeier (2001) included this species in the genus Ranodon, rather than Pseudohynobius. Zhao (1990) and Zhao and Adler (1993) indicated that this species is a synonym of Liua tsinpaensis. However, the karyotypes of these two species are significantly different. Hence, Ye, Fei and Hu (1993) and Fei (1999) still regarded it to be a valid species in Pseudohynobius, and we follow this arrangement here.

authority: (Liu and Hu in Hu, Zhao and Liu, 1966)
taxonomicNotes: Kuzmin and Thiesmeier (2001) included this species in the genus Ranodon, rather than Pseudohynobius. Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus was considered to be a synonym of this species by Zhao and Hu (1983) and Zhao and Wu (1995), but is considered a valid species by Ye, Fei and Hu (1993) and Fei (1999).
Populations in south-east Costa Rica and north-west Panama have recently been separated as Bolitglossa sombra and B. magnifica (Hanken et al. 2005).
This form was formerly considered to be part of Bolitoglossa subpalmata. Several species might still be involved in what is now considered B. pesrubra.
The taxonomy of this species is currently under revision, and this name will only be applied to the subpopulations in Pico Pijol and Montaña Macuzal (Townsend et al. in review March 2019).

Jacobs (1987) found Eurycea junaluska to be genetically similar to E. aquatica and E. cirrigera and questioned the taxonomic status of E. junaluska. Sever (1989) found E. junaluska to be morphologically unique and genetically distinct from all sympatric Eurycea.
This form might represent a species complex.

Gyrinophilus gulolineatus was formerly regarded as a subspecies of G. palleucus; it was treated as a species by Brandon et al. (1986), Collins and Taggart (2002) and Crother et al. (2000). Petranka (1998) maintained this taxon as a subspecies of G. palleucus.

Three subspecies (palleucus, gulolineatus, and necturoides) have been recognized; intergradation between palleucus and necturoides is evident in some Alabama populations (A. Wynne, in Godwin 1995b). Some populations do not conform well to any of the named subspecies. One form in Tennessee might be sufficiently distinct biochemically to warrant recognition as a separate species (Redmond and Scott 1996). Gyrinophilus gulolineatus (Berry Cave Salamander) was treated as a species by Brandon et al. (1986), Collins and Taggart (2002), and Crother et al. (2000), but Petranka (1998) maintained this taxon as a subspecies of G. palleucus. In this assessment, Gyrinophilus gulolineatus is regarded as a distinct species.

Some authors have regarded this species as conspecific with Gyrinophilus porphyriticus (Blaney and Blaney 1978), but the current consensus is that it is a valid species, based on morphometric analyses (Green and Pauley 1987).

As assessed here, this taxon is restricted to northern Costa Rica (Savage 2000). It is possible that the southwest population of this species may be described as a new species (Federico Bolaños pers. comm.).
The species is genetically diverse and includes several evolutionarily significant units.
The taxonomic issues surrounding this species have now been resolved, which has resulted in the description of two new species, Nototriton nelsoni and N. oreadorum (Townsend 2016).
The type specimen has been lost. In the past the species name has been applied to populations of Chiropterotriton in southern Mexico that are no longer assigned to this species.
The subpopulation of this salamander recorded from Sierra Gorda is likely to represent an undescribed species (G. Parra-Olea pers. comm. 2007).

Darda (1994) split this species into two, but did not provide a formal name for the southernmost population (in Hidalgo State). In this account we treat all four known populations as Chiropterotriton multidentatus, pending the formal description of the southernmost population.
Removed from the synonymy of Chiropterotriton chiropterus by Darda (1994).
There are uncertainties relating to the taxonomic status of this species.

Both Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were included within Dendrotriton rabbi in the past; however, this species is now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010).

Salamanders from springs in the vicinity of Lake Georgetown display a unique combination of alleles and have distinctive mtDNA characteristics; possibly they may also be distinguished based on pigmentation characteristics (Chippindale, Hillis and Price 1994). It is regarded as a distinct species by Chippindale, Hillis and Price (1994) and was formally described as Eurycea naufragia by Chippindale et
al. (2000). It was included in E. neotenes by Sweet (1978, 1982).

Most references to E. neotenes in the literature involve populations that Chippindale et al. (2000) considered Fern Bank Salamanders E. pterophila or members of the E. latitans or E. troglodytes species complexes

This species is included in Eurycea neotenes by Sweet (1978, 1982) and in previous publications. Certain populations provisionally assigned to this species warrant further study and might prove to be taxonomically distinct (Chippindale et al. 2000).
The animals in Mexico might belong to a new species, however new tissue samples are needed to confirm this (G. Parra-Olea pers. comm. 2007).
This species was recently separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was recently separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was recently separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was recently separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).

Carranza and Wade (2004) showed that most of the animals from North Africa previously referred to as Pleurodeles poireti actually belong to P. nebulosus, true P. poireti being restricted to the Edough Peninsula in northern Algeria.
Known only with certainty from the type locality. Similar looking individuals have been recorded at nearby locations, but the identity of these is uncertain.

Recent morphological, ecological and genetic studies on Salamandra algira indicate that there are at least three differentiated phenotypes and genotypes with parapatric distribution. Salamandra algira must be considered a complex of more than one species. A taxonomic revision of this complex is needed (Bogaerts and Donaire-Barroso 2003).
The taxonomic validity of this species is disputed.
This form probably consists of at least three species (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).
The name Thorius minutissimus has been applied to populations at other localities, but these are now known to belong to other species in the genus (Hanken and Wake pers. comm.).
Populations attributed to this species from locations other than the type locality (Cerro San Felipe) need to be confirmed and are currently not included here.
This form might comprise more than one species (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).

Bart et al. (1997) determined that the name Necturus alabamensis applies only to the waterdog in the upper Black Warrior River drainage. For years, the name had been mistakenly applied to a more common species of waterdog that occurs in the coastal plain. Further taxonomic revisions involving this species are likely (Petranka 1998). See Bart et al. (1997) for an account of the nomenclatural history of this and related species.
Rhyacotriton variegatus, R. kezeri and R. cascadae formerly were included in this species.
The conspecificity of the disjunct populations needs to be assessed.
Specimens from Welegama resemble Ichthyophis glutinosus, but appear to be more closely related to I. orthoplicatus. They could represent an undescribed cryptic species (Gower et al. 2005).
Atoconeura aethiopica was formerly considered a subspecies of A. biordinata, but it is now regarded as a valid species (Dijkstra in prep.).

Until recently C. georgiferyi was considered a subspecies of Ceriagrion tenellum but both male and female show distinct morphological characters and it is now considered to be a full species (Schneider 1986, Kalkman 2005).
Three subspecies have been described.

Fraser (1960) stated that of C. abyssinicus "only two females and a male are known. The former came from Abyssinia, the latter from Uganda and is regarded as the correct male […] only on supposition". He added "Uganda, swampy borders of Lake Victoria" as the species’ habitat. The male – now the allotype (Natural History Museum, London) – is labelled "E. abyssinia". Presumably Fraser was in error, misleading later authors such as Pinhey (1962) who stated "Uganda (teste Fraser, ex Carpenter)" for C. abyssinicus. C. abyssinicus is not known from outside Ethiopia.

The type of Enallagma maldivense was examined by K.D. Dijkstra (personal communication) and revealed to not be an Enallagma at all, but some species of Aciagrion, probably the widespread A. borneense.
Originally described as Platysticta hilaris Hagen in Selys, 1860.
Originally described as Disparoneura leucostigma Fraser, 1933c.

Originally described as Gomphus ceylonicus Selys, 1878, this species is known only from a single female. Due to distinct morphological characters, it was given specific rank by F.C. Fraser in the revision of the family Gomphidae from Sri Lanka (Fraser 1933).

According to the New World Orthoptera Hypolestes clara should be transferred to Ortholestes clara. However, Paulson and von Ellenrieder (2005 submissions) note that this should be Hypolestes clara: originally described as Ortholestes clara. There is confusion about whether any Hispaniolan populations are this species, H. trinitatis of Cuba, or a third unnamed species (Dunkle 1991). Hypolestes occupies a somewhat isolated position in its family, and other family placement has been suggested, even a family of its own. It may be a sister group to most other modern damselflies (Rehn 2003).

According to the New World Orthoptera Hypolestes trinitatis should be transferred to Ortholestes trinitatis. However, according to Paulson and von Ellenrieder (2005 Red List submission), this should be Hypoletes: there is confusion about whether any Hispaniolan populations are this species, H. clara of Jamaica, or a third undescribed species (Dunkle 1991). Hispaniolan populations are usually listed with H. trinitatis, but penis structure is different (and this is often used to separate similar species). Hypolestes occupies a somewhat isolated position in its family, and other family placement has been suggested, even a family of its own. It may be a sister group to most other modern damselflies (Rehn 2003).
Originally described under genus Eurypetalia; von Ellenrieder (in prep.) is currently reviewing taxonomy of South American austropetaliids.
Originally described under genus Eurypetalia; von Ellenrieder (in prep.) is currently reviewing taxonomy of South American austropetaliids.

This species was introduced as "Gomphus ruppeli" (after Eduard Rüppell) by Selys-Longchamps (1858). The name has been spelt in several ways since, mainly to correct for the vowel mutation and the missing consonant.
Monotypic genus, taxonomically isolated, no near allies.  Original description: Lestes orientalis Hagen in Selys, 1862.

This Pemba Island species is nearly identical to some species of the Malagasy radiation of Platycnemis, but distant from the Guineo-Congolian species that have tropical Asian affinities. The species is likely to be a long-distance wind-borne arrival from Madagascar, which survived due to favourable climatic conditions on Pemba (Dijkstra et al. 2007).

The Java Stingaree is known only from the type specimen and is considered valid with the holotype housed at the Humboldt-Universität, Museum für Naturkunde, Zoologisches Museum, Berlin, Germany. It is a unique species of stingaree and its placement in the genus Urolophus is provisional (Last et al. 2016). It is the only known stingaree (family Urolophidae) from Java; the Kai Stingaree (Urolophus kaianus), the only other stingaree known from Indonesia, doesn't overlap with the historical range of the Java Stingaree (Last et al. 2016).

Previous studies of the family Gymnuridae have divided it into two genera based on the presence or absence of a dorsal fin; Aetoplatea with a dorsal fin and Gymnura without (Murdy et al. 1997, Compagno and Last 1999, Vossoughi and Vosoughi 1999, Oshigou et al. 2004, Yano et al. 2005). A recent taxonomic review of the Australian Butterfly Ray Gymnura australis (Ramsay and Ogilby 1886), supports the amalgamation of all species into a single genus; Gymnura (Jacobsen 2007). Jacobsen (2007) found that dorsal fin development in G. australis is variable and inconsistent with the two genus hypothesis, thus suggesting that Aeteoplata should be designated as a junior synonym.
This species is poorly represented in collections.
This species is considered distinct from Aetomylaeus milvus (Last et al. 2016).
The genus Rhinoptera is a taxonomically perplexing group that requires a great deal of future investigation to elucidate the actual number of species that belong in this genus.

The small subpopulation on Booby Cay, The Bahamas, has been classified as a distinct subspecies, Cyclura carinata bartschi Cochran, 1931, on the basis of morphological characteristics. Genetic studies are needed to more fully evaluate whether subspecific status is warranted.
Microneura is a monotypic genus.

The historical confusion that surrounds this species' taxonomy is pending resolution and nomenclatural stability. The current lectotype of this species (MNHN 1049 from Nice, France) most likely represents S. couardi, and the paralectotype (MNHN 1019 from Cayenne, French Guiana) most likely represents S. bigelowi. The retention of the name S. tudes would require the rejection of the current lectotype and redesignation of the Cayenne specimen as the lectotype. Compagno (in preparation b) outlines the history and problems associated with this issue.

Until recently this species was regarded as subspecies of Pyrrhosoma nymphula. Kalkman & Lopau (2006) illustrated the differences between the two taxa and confirmed that they should be treated as valid species.
Taxonomically isolated, no near allies.
Originally described as Alloneura caesia Hagen in Selys, 1860.
First described by Fraser (1933d).
Originally described as Tetrathemis fruhstorferi Karsch, 1889.
First described by Fraser (1933d).
Originally considered E. paulsoni Belle, 1981.

This species was introduced as Gomphus ruppeli (after Eduard Rüppell) by Selys-Longchamps (1858). The name has been spelt in several ways since, mainly to correct for the vowel mutation and the missing consonant.

Ris (1919) described Orthetrum poecilops poecilops from Guangdong. The subspecies Orthetrum poecilops miyajimaense Yuki & Doi, 1938 was described, originally as separate species, from Miyajima, a small island near Hiroshima, southern Honshu, Japan. Asahina and Sawano (1957) synonymised the two taxa but later Asahina (1970) reinstated miyajimaense at subspecies level, based principally on its smaller size. Wilson (2001) considers the two taxa are probably synonyms. Nevertheless the Japanese population represents a distinct and isolated (fragmented) population.
The taxonomy of Barbatula is in need of revision.
Formerly, confused with and regarded as a subpopulation of Boyeria irene (Fonscolombe, 1838), but both species are clearly distinct (Boudot 1989, Peters 1991, Kohli et al. 2014).
Recent change of genus from Iberocypris to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003). Valid as Iberocypris palaciosi (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007).

Nothobranchius korthausae was established as a species by Meinken in 1973, and that status has since been accepted by all authors. The species was known to occur only in Mafia Island until 2000, when several populations showing close similarities in male colouration to N. korthausae were found in coastal mainland. These latter populations were described by Costa (2009) as N. ruudwildekampi, restricting the distribution of N. korthausae again to the originally defined Mafia Island.
Nothobranchius flammicomantis was established as a species by Wildekamp, Watters and Sainthouse in 1998, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.

Closely related to 'Barbus' apleurogramma. Most likely an undescribed small Barbus, currently under description (Seegers, work in progress) (see Seegers et al., unpublished).

The genus Barbus (Cyprinidae) is restricted to a small number of species mainly inhabiting the European ichthyographic region including Northeast Africa. Most of the African species which are currently included in the genus, taxonomically do not appear to be closely related to the genus Barbus sensu strictu. However, no attempts have yet been made at an adequate nomenclature of the African forms. We therefore follow Berrebi et al. (1996) and use in this paper the term ‘Barbus’ for the cyprinid fish species which were previously considered as Barbus (Seegers et al., unpublished).
Taxonomic status uncertain. Appears to be close to Aplocheilichthys maculatus Klausewitz, 1957.
Nothobranchius luekei was established as a species by Seegers in 1984, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Roberts (2003) removed most species from Leptoglanis and placed them, instead, into Zaireichthys.

Nothobranchius rubripinnis was established as a species by Seegers in 1986, and that status has since been accepted by all authors. Populations from the Mbwemkuru River in south-eastern Tanzania were initially proposed to belong to N. rubripinnis but subsequent studies showed it to be a distinct species that was described as N. cardinalis by Watters, Cooper & Wildekamp in 2008.

First population of this species was imported in 1957 and was referred to as N. species Dar es Salaam or erroneously as N. palmqvisti Dar es Salaam. Nothobranchius foerschi was established as a species by Wildekamp and Berkenkamp in 1979, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Recent change from genus Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003). Squalius alburnoides transferred to Iberocypris (Kottelat and Freyhoff 2007)
The status of the population in Mzima springs is uncertain. It might be distinct from Ctenochromis pectoralis known from the Pangani drainage. More research is required.
An undescribed species recently collected near Baomo (Seegers et al. unpublished).
Nothobranchius bojiensis was established as a species by Wildekamp and Haas in 1992, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.

Nothobranchius jubbi interruptus was established as a subspecies by Wildekamp & Berkenkamp in 1979. Seegers (1981) proposed Nothobranchius interruptus as a valid species, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Nothobranchius willerti was established as a species by Wildekamp in 1992, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Nothobranchius elongatus was established as a species by Wildekamp in 1992, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Previously also reported as Tilapia alcalica and Oreochromis (Alcolapia) alcalicus alcalicus. Specific rank according to Seegers and Tichy (1999).

Also reported under the old names Tilapia grahami and Oreochromis (Alcolapia) alcalicus grahami. Specific rank according to Seegers and Tichy (1999). Reported as Tilapia mossambica (non Peters, 1852) by Woodhouse (1912), a misidentification.

authority: De Vos, Snoeks & Thys van den Audenaerde, 1991

taxonomicNotes: Initially included in Nemacheilus insignis, but valid as a separate species (M. Goren, pers. comm.).

Previously also reported as Tilapia jipe, T. (Sarotherodon) jipe, T. (Oreochromis) jipe and S. jipe (antiquated names). It also appears Oreochromis pangani is the same species as O. jipe (Snoeks pers. comm.).
Transferred from genus Pseudophoxinus to Telestes.
Haplochromis sauvagei Greenwood, 1980 is a synonym of Haplochromis fischeri, and many records relate to this species. However the name is valid as a different species.
An undescribed species currently under study (Seegers et al. unpublished).
An undescribed species (Seegers et al. unpublished).
Was previously included in T. simonis, but is valid as a separate species (N. Bogutskaya, pers. comm.).

The genus Barbus (Cyprinidae) is restricted to a small number of species mainly inhabiting the European ichthyographic region including Northeast Africa. Most of the African species that are currently included in the genus, taxonomically do not appear to be closely related to the genus Barbus sensu strictu. However, no attempts have yet been made at an adequate nomenclature of the African forms. We therefore follow Berrebi et al. (1996) and use in this paper the term ‘Barbus’ for the cyprinid fish species which were previously considered as Barbus (Seegers et al., unpublished).Status doubtful. Banister (1972, 1973) reports this species as a possible hybrid between Barbus somereni and Varicorhinus ruwenzorii.
There has been a recent change of genus from Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Bogutskaya and Zupancic 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003).
An undescribed species (Seegers et al. unpublished).
Some authorities cite the date of description as 1895.
Recent change of genus from Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003).
Taxonomic distinction probably not obvious when compared with Lates niloticus.
See Kottelat (1997).

The generic position of this species is still unclear and the validity of the genus Astatotilapia is not widely accepted. Therefore, we keep it in the original genus Haplochromis until a conclusive generic review of this group of fishes has been published.
Initially included in Nemacheilus insignis, but valid as a separate species (M. Goren, pers. comm.).
There has been a recent change from genus Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003).
A revision of the genus Rutilus from southern Europe on morphological and molecular basis is in progress by Bianco P.G., Ketmaier, V. and Durand J.-Do.
Nothobranchius albimarginatus was established as a species by Watters, Wildekamp and Cooper in 1998, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.

Originally described from the northern Ewaso Nyiro under the name Labeo percivali, which, according to Reid (1985) is a slender inland form of L. bottegi Vinciguerra, 1897 from the Juba system in Somalia, This is a doubtful synonym which we prefer not to follow here (Seegers et al., unpublished).
Undescribed species.
Nothobranchius lourensi was established as a species by Wildekamp in 1977, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Nothobranchius annectens was established as a species by Watters, Wildekamp and Cooper in 1998, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Nothobranchius kilomberoensis was established as a species by Wildekamp, Watters and Sainthouse in 2002, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Nothobranchius steinforti was established as a species by Wildekamp in 1977, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Nothobranchius geminus was established as a species by Wildekamp, Watters and Sainthouse in 2002, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Taxonomic status uncertain: it has been reported under the names Haplolichthys antinorii and Aplocheilichthys antinorii (Vinciguerra 1883) but it differs from these two species.
It is considered sometimes only as a subspecies.
The taxonomy of Barbatula is in need of revision.

This taxon is recorded as "discarded" because it was in the Red List database twice (under different names). It is now recorded as a synonym of Pelasgus epiroticus and the Phoxinellus epiroticus assessments should be transferred to the Pelasgus epiroticus species account as part of its Red List assessment history.

Following Eschmeyer (2004) Paraphoxinus epiroticus was transferred to Phoxinellus epiroticus.
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain, Reid (1985) suspects the type specimens of Labeo trigliceps to be aberrant specimens of L. cylindricus (see Seegers et al. 2004).
Genus changed from from Leuciscus to Squalius (Bogutskaya 2002).

Recent molecular studies found all sea- and coast-spawing shads from the  Aegean, Black and Caspian Sea basins to be very closely related and  their taxonomy might be revised in the future. This species complex also includes Alosa vistonica. We follow the traditional  species concept until this species complex will be resolved.
Genus changed from Leuciscus to Telestes (Banarescin 1998).
Recent change from genus Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003).
Gobio benacensis considered a valid species according to molecular and morphological studies (Bianco and Ketmaier 2005). Transferred to Romanogobio (see Kottelat and Freyhof 2007).
Recent change of genus from Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003).
The taxonomy of Barbatula is in need of revision.

Following Eschmeyer (2004) the spelling of the specific name huegeli was corrected to Aulopyge huegelii.

There has been some confusion about the date of publication of the specific name, with the years 1841, 1842 and 1843 being used by different sources. Kottelat (1997) is followed here as he states the following: "Although the generic name Aulopyge is available from Heckel (1841a: 384 [published 30 April 1941]; also 1841b: 523 [published 1842 according to Eschmeyer, 1990]), the species name A. huegelii is only available from his 1842 description. In the 1841 paper, Heckel only mentioned that the species would be named for Hügel, but did not use the name huegelii. The description is repeated in Heckel (1843: 1021)."
Genus changed from Leuciscus to Telestes. (Ketmaier et al. 2004).
The taxonomy of Barbatula is in need of revision.

The generic placement of this species has been discussed in the recent past and it is clear, that it is not a species of Pseudophoxinus, as considered by earlier authors. The relationships of the species is close to the genus Alburnus and Anaecypris. It was placed in Anaecypris by Geiger et al. (2014), an opinion followed here.  Indeed, Anaecypris is closely related to Alburnus.
Initially included in Nemacheilus insignis, but valid as a separate species (M. Goren, pers. comm.).
Changed from genus from Leuciscus to Telestes (Banarescin 1998).
Initially included in Nemacheilus insignis, but valid as a separate species (M. Goren, pers. comm.). Previously referred to by Banarescu (1982) as N. tigris Banarescu, Nalbent & Goren, 1982.
This species is closely related to the Acanthodactylus pardalis (Lichtenstein, 1823) complex.

The dorsal colour pattern consist in brown spots ranging from ¼ to 1 times the size of the orbits, arranged fairly symmetrically on the disc, pectoral fins and tail, which distinguish it from the sympatric D. guamachensis.

The species is distinguished from the sympatric Diplobatis colombiensis in that it presents brown bands running longitudinally on the edges of the disc and the pelvic fins and transversely on the body and tail; bands vary in thickness but never exceed 0.5 times the diameter of the eye.
Records of this species from Israel refer to Acanthodactylus beershebensis, and records from Jordan refer to A. ahmadisii (Y. Werner pers. comm). Records from Algeria refer to another species.

This species used to be considered as a subspecies of Chalcides polylepis, but it was separated as a full species by (Pasteur et al. 1988; Brown and Pestano 1998). According to López Jurado (1998), the International Commission of Zoological Nomenclature ruled that the valid name of this taxon is C. simonyi, and not C. occidentalis.
We follow Smith and Wallach (1994) in including this species in the monotypic genus Lycognathophis, rather than in Scopelophis, as proposed by Dowling (1990).
The genus Janetaescincus was established by Greer (1970), and is endemic to the Seychelles.

The genus Janetaescincus was established by Greer (1970), and is endemic to the Seychelles. Cheke (1984) has disputed the validity of Janetaescincus veseyfitzgeraldi. A taxonomic review is in progress (J. Gerlach pers. comm.).
This species is included in Hierophis following Utiger and Schätti (2004).
This species is included in Montivipera following Nilson et al. (1999).

Iberolacerta cyreni and Iberolacerta martinezricai are now separated as distinct species from Iberolacerta monticola (Mayer and Arribas 1996) and mitochondrial DNA (Mayer and Arribas 2003; Carranza et al. 2004a; Crochet et al. 2004). This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003). The population in the Montes de León has recently been described as a separate species, Iberolacerta galani (Arribas et al. 2006).

authority: Moravec, Baha El Din, Seligmann, Sivan & Werner, 1999
Mateo, García Márquez, López Jurado & Barahona, 2001
taxonomicNotes: This taxon was originally described as a subspecies of Gallotia simonyi by Mateo et al. (2001), but we follow Afonso and Mateo (2003) in treating it as a full species. There is an urgent need to establish the identity of recently observed animals in northern La Palma (Mínguez et al. 2007) which might represent a remnant population of this species.
Following the ruling of the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, the name of this species is Gallotia bravoana, not Gallotia gomerana.

authority: Barbadillo, Lacomba, Pêrez-Mellado, Sancho and López-Jurado, 1999
taxonomicNotes: This species is described by Hernández et al. (2000), but the name first appeared in Barbadillo et al. (1999).

This taxon is now considered to be a full species based on evidence from Arribas (2001), Crochet et al. (2004), Mayer and Arribas (1996, 2003) and Odierna et al. (1996). It was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003).

This taxon is considered to be a full species based on evidence from Arribas (1996), Carranza et al. (2004), Crochet et al. (2004), Mayer and Arribas (1996, 2003) and Odierna et al. (1996). It was formerly treated as a subspecies of Iberolacerta monticola. The specific status of this taxon is supported by morphology (Arribas 1996), allozymes (Mayer and Arribas 1996) and mitochondrial DNA (Mayer and Arribas 2003; Carranza et al. 2004a; Crochet et al. 2004). It was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003).
Animals from Jordan might belong to a separate subspecies. More taxonomic work is needed on the fragmented populations of this species.

This species was formerly treated as a subspecies of Iberolacerta monticola, but genetic and morphological data support a full specific rank (Mayer and Arribas 2003; Arribas and Carranza 2004; Crochet et al. 2004). It was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003).

Both spellings (latastei and latasti) appeared in different places in the original description by Boscà and were subsequently used by different authors. David and Ineich (1999) acted as the first reviser and selected latastei as the valid spelling. However, the name is still under dispute (Montori and Llorente 2005), and is under discussion in the International Commission for Zoological Nomenclature (V. Pérez-Mellado pers. comm.). Populations in the Atlas mountains of Morocco, currently assigned to a separate species V. monticola, may in fact belong to this species (Brito et al. 2006).
The isolated eastern subpopulation in Montenegro has been proposed as a separate species (Ljubisavljevic et al. 2007).

This taxon was formerly a subspecies of Podarcis bocagei, but was raised to species rank (Sá-Sousa 2000a, Sá-Sousa and Harris 2002) based on genetic differences (see also: Harris et al. 2002; Harris and Sá-Sousa 2001, 2002; Pinho et al. 2003).

This taxon was raised to species rank by Gruber (1986), with two subspecies, gaigeae and weiglandi (Grube and Schultze-Westrum 1971). Although this status was not recognized by Gasc et al. (1997), it is supported by additional genetic results (Harris and Arnold 1999).

This species was described from specimens that were earlier provisionally assigned to Bolitoglossa nigrescens (Hanken, Wake and Savage 2005).

taxonomicNotes: This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
