This species possibly represents a distinct genus from Cyclophorus.

Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14684. Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum) RMNH collection number 5004181
Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14690. Type material will be deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum)
Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 9955[MS1] . Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum). RMNH collection number 5004174
Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14691. Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum) RMNH collection number RMNH 5004175
Named as Philautus hallidayi by Meegaskumbura and Manamendra-Arachchi in 2005, the genus has been revised and replaced with Pseudophilautus by Li et al. in 2009.

The population in Sri Lanka assigned to Hylarana aurantiaca probably belongs to an undescribed species (S.D. Biju and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm.). However, pending taxonomic revision, H. aurantiaca is treated here as a single species.
Pseudoeurycea boneti has recently been resurrected from synonymy with P. bellii (Parra-Olea et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to Isthmura (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2012). It was previously removed from the synonymy of Isthmura bellii by Parra-Olea et al. (2001 - as Pseudoeurycea bellii).

Anonyxmolytes lilliput is the only species of the genus Anonyxmolytes, which is restricted to the Hon Chong limestone hills (Meregalli and Osella 2007), possibly extending into nearby areas in Cambodia (Deharveng pers. comm). It is well characterized within the subfamily Molytinae, and unique among Curculionidae by the extreme reduction of its tarsi. It is a blind species of low vagility, associated with deep soil, and highly specialized, probably very sensitive to change in the habitat conditions (deforestation, changes in the water-content of the soil, etc.). It is possibly related to a Japanese genus, and appears to be a relict taxon of high phylogenetic and biogeographic interest (Meregalli, Pers. Comm.).

The genus Delamarephorura contains few species and occurs in Africa and in Viet Nam (Janion et al. 2013). Delamarephorura tami is one of the two Vietnamese species of the genus in Viet Nam, the other one being a littoral form described known from Binh Chau beach. The genus has so far not provided other species from Viet Nam, contrary to several other Tullbergiidae genera.
Eustra honchongensis belongs to a genus including species which are all rare and narrowly endemic in Southeast Asia (Deuve, 1996).

Eutrichodesmus griseus belongs to a genus that includes a large number of species in Southeast Asia, mostly in caves and all narrow endemics. It is unusual morphologically compared to its congeners, because of its greyish coloration. E. griseus is the only species of the genus in the Hon Chong region (Golovatch et al., 2009).
Groves (2002) provisionally listed two subspecies of Grevy's Zebra. However, Groves and Bell (2004) concluded that the species is indeed monotypic. Reviewed by Churcher (1993).

Gnomulus bedoharvengorum is a species of the large Indo-Malayan genus Gnomulus. The Hon Chong species is biologically of interest because of its occurrence in caves and rarer occurrence in surface litter under bushes, while most other species of the genus live in rainforest litter. It appears as a relictual form in this respect.

Isometrus deharvengi belongs to the rather large genus Isometrus, which is known from Vietnam and surrounding countries by several species (Lourenço & Duhem, 2010). All species of the genus except one have reduced distribution areas. The presence of I. deharvengi in caves is unusual for the genus Isometrus, though the species is not troglomorphic.

Folsomides sp. nov. 'HC - blind' is a new undescribed species of Isotomidae Collembola. The genus Folsomides is poorly diversified in the tropics, but its three widespread are possibly the most abundant pantropical Collembola. The presence of a blind and well characterized species in a cave of Hon Chong was quite unexpected.


Species under description by Louis Deharveng and Anne Bedos, vouchers in MNHN Paris (3 specimens), to be deposited in Ho Chi Minh City University and MNHN Paris

Microblattellus lecongmani is a remarkable species, the only species of the genus Microblattellus. The new tribe Falsocossyphini was erected to accomodate it together with two other monospecific genera (Ferrer 2006). The unusual morphology of those species casts doubts on the monophyly of this tribe, but not on the originality of the species it includes (Bremer & Lillig 2014). It has therefore to be considered as one of the most remarkable endemic species of Hon Chong, and a major issue regarding biodiversity conservation, though the species is less strongly threatened than many others from the Hon Chong-Kampot karst.

Species under description by Louis Deharveng, Marko Lukic and Anne Bedos, vouchers in MNHN Paris (6 specimens), to be deposited in Ho Chi Minh City University and MNHN Paris.

Acrocyrtus sp. nov. 'HC - blind' is a new undescribed species of Entomobryidae Collembola provisionally assigned to the genus Acrocyrtus. This genus is widespread and well diversified in Southeast Asia, and has several new species in the Hon Chong area. A. sp. nov. 'HC - blind' would be the only blind and the only troglobitic species of the genus
The species is the first representative of the genus Sumatrillo outside Sumatra from where two species are known, and the only troglomorphic species of Oniscidea (blind and unpigmented) in Hon Chong.

scientificName: Burmoniscus sp. nov. 'HC - first segment white'
taxonomicNotes: Species under description by Stefano Taiti and Giovanna Monticelli Cardoso (May 2016), vouchers in Firenze (1 specimen), and 2 specimens to be deposited in MNHN Paris (Taiti 2016, pers. comm.).

Species under description by Louis Deharveng and Anne Bedos, vouchers in MNHN Paris (6 specimens), to be deposited in Ho Chi Minh City University and MNHN Paris.

Ceratophysella sp. nov. 'HC' is a new undescribed species of Hypogastruridae Collembola, assumed to be related to temperate region species of the genus. Its is a remarkable relict restricted to one cave of the Hon Chong hills, and the only non-guanobitic cave Hypogastruridae known from the tropics.
Plusioglyphiulus boutini belongs to a genus that includes a large number of species in Southeast Asia, living mostly on bat guano in caves. Most species are narrow endemics (Golovatch et al. 2009).

The former Anniella pulchra was divided into five species by Papenfuss and Parham (2013). Parham and Papenfuss (2009) speculated that the Carrizo Plain subpopulation may be a hybrid or intergrade subpopulation, but Papenfuss and Parham (2013) included it in their concept of A. grinnelli.

Two dwarfed hippopotami were described from recent fossil remains at Madagascar: Hippopotamus lemerlei and Hippopotamus madagascariensis. In a critical contribution, Stuenes (1989) thoroughly described the morphological differences between these species and provided detailed diagnoses. After Stuenes’ work (1989), the most complete account is that by Rakotovao et al. (2014), who notably documented significant intraspecific variations within both species. The origin of these species remains uncertain: they are generally seen as deriving from continental species of Hippopotamus, maybe from the extant Hippopotamus amphibius. A third extinct Madagascan species, Hippopotamus laloumena, was proposed by Faure and Guérin (1990) on limited evidence. A recent publication by Faure et al. (2010) does not add significant evidence in favor of the validity of this species, and  its dissimilarity from Hippopotamus amphibius needs to be clarified. It may represent evidence for sporadic Mozambique Channel crossing by individuals of the extant large species during the Holocene, including since the European colonization of Madagascar (Burney et al. 2004).

Fovet et al. (2011) suggested that Guldberg's type specimen of H. madagscariensis actually pertains to the other small species, H. lemerlei. In 1902, C.J.F. Major re-described H. madagascariensis Gulberg, 1883 using a new Malagasy skeleton which was quite different to H. lemerlei. However, because H. madagascariensis would be no more than a replacement name for H. lemerlei, Fovet et al. (2011) proposed the new name H. guldbergi to designate the species described in 1902 by C.J.F. Major. Rakotovao et al. (2014) disagreed with Fauvet et al. (2011) on the attribution of Guldberg’s specimen to H. lemerlei, and confirmed its identification as H. madagascariensis, in line with Stuenes (1989). This debate is not closed (see Faure et al. 2015), but given that H. madagascariensis was extensively used as an available name prior to 1961 and since then (see section 11.6 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature), and given that the ICZN recommendations regarding the stability of taxonomic nomenclature, it is for now more cautious to continue to use H. madagascariensis and to consider H. gulbergi as its junior synonym. In any case, this debate calls for further revising the material attributed to the two dwarfed hippopotami from Madagascar, including notably their postcranial skeleton.

Two dwarfed hippopotami were created from recent fossil remains in Madagascar: Hippopotamus lemerlei and Hippopotamus madagascariensis. In a critical contribution, Stuenes (1989) thoroughly described the morphological differences between these species and provided detailed diagnoses. After Stuenes' work (1989), the most complete account is that by Rakotovao et al. (2014), who notably documented significant intraspecific variations within both species. The origin of these species remains uncertain: they are generally seen as deriving from continental species of Hippopotamus, maybe from Hippopotamus amphibius. A third extinct Madagascan species, Hippopotamus laloumena, was proposed by Faure and Guérin (1990) on limited evidence. A recent publication by Faure et al. (2010) does not add significant evidence in favor of the validity of this species, and its dissimilarity from Hippopotamus amphibius still needs to be clarified (Weston and Lister 2009). It may represent evidence for sporadic Mozambique Channel crossing by individuals of the extant large species during the Holocene, including since the European colonization of Madagascar (Burney et al. 2004).

Fovet et al. (2011) suggested that Guldberg's type specimen of H. madagscariensis actually pertains to the other small species, H. lemmerlei. In 1902, C.J.F. Major re-described H. madagascariensis Gulberg, 1883 using a new Malagasy skeleton which was quite different to H. lemmerlei. However, because H. madagscariensis would be no more than a replacement name for H. lemerlei, Fovet et al. (2011) proposed the new name H. guldbergi to designate the species described in 1902 by C.J.F. Major. Rakotovao et al. (2014) disagreed with Fauvet et al. (2011) on the attribution of Guldberg’s specimen to H. lemerlei, and confirmed its identification as H. madagascariensis, in line with Stuenes (1989). This debate is not closed (see Faure et al. 2015), but given that H. madagascariensis was extensively used as an available name prior to 1961 and since then (see section 11.6 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature), and given that the ICZN recommendations regarding the stability of taxonomic nomenclature, it is for now more cautious to continue to use H. madagascariensis and to consider H. gulbergi as its junior synonym. In any case, this debate calls for further revising the material attributed to the two dwarfed hippopotami from Madagascar, including notably their postcranial skeleton.

authority: Batista, Hertz, Mebert, Köhler, Lotzkat, Ponce & Vesely, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This species has previously been regarded as a subpopulation of Ecnomiohyla rabborum, but is now regarded as a distinct species as a result of morphology and molecular examination of specimens (Batista et al. 2014).

Populations of a Paedocypris species in Peninsular Malaysia have been provisionally identified as this species. However, there is ongoing genetic analysis to determine whether they represent Paedocypris micromegethes (H.H. Tan pers. comm. 2019).

Mokodongan et al. (2018) found that the Oryzias woworae species group (comprising of O. asinua, O. wolasi, and O. woworae) could not be separated by their body shape using geometric morphometrics and that their phylogenetic relationships did not support the presence of three species. As such, they recommend a taxonomic re-examination of the O.woworae species group.
Chlamydotis undulata and C. macqueenii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. undulata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. Chelonoidis donfaustoi is a recently described species (Poulakakis et al. 2015), previously included within C. porteri. The name C. porteri is now restricted only to the species of tortoise found on western Santa Cruz Island in the area known as La Reserva (the originally designated Tortoise Reserve). This Red List assessment treats this newly described taxon, C. donfaustoi, as a full species.
This species may be a species complex, and further taxonomic work is required to verify this (K.O. Chan and E. Quah pers. comm. January 2018).

Telmatherina bonti is the only valid name currently available for riverine Telmatherina (Kottelat 1990, Miesen et al. 2015). Nevertheless, Telmatherina cf. bonti has been used for different riverine populations in the Malili Lakes System and several separate adjacent drainages due to high level of phenotypic and genotypic diversity recorded among them, as comprising thirteen geographically fragmented morphotypes following Herder et al. (2006b) that can be genetically assorted more inclusively into three strongly supported groups (Herder et al. 2006a). Although the two studies (Herder et al. 2006a, 2006b) seem to abandon the status of T. bonti by referring to all the pertinent riverine populations—except the one in the Petea River—together with the lacustrine one as T. cf. bonti, it is necessary to reserve the name T. bonti in the strict sense for the group that includes any populations readily assigned to the identity as redescribed by Kottelat (1990). Therefore, all the populations embedded in the larger riverine clade of Herder et al. (2006a) need to be treated as T. bonti, while leaving the other two stream-dwelling groups as taxa, the status of which needs to be resolved taxonomically.

This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Weberogobius but is now considered valid in the genus Mugilogobius. It most closely resembles Mugilogobius hitam described by Larson et al. in 2014 from Lake Towuti; but the two species can be discriminated based on lateral scale count — 52-65 in Mugilogobius amadi and 31-34 in Mugilogobius hitam (Larson et al. 2014).
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List as Tamanka sarasinorum but is now valid in the genus Mugilogobius.

This species was previously thought by Berry (1975) and Kiew (1975) to include Limnonectes tweediei. However, Dring (1979), Grandison (1982) and Leong Tzi Ming (pers. comm.) consider the two forms to be distinct.
A re-description of this species is ongoing with new specimens from the type locality (D. Lumbantobing pers. comm. 2019).

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species. Troides dohertyi is sometimes treated as a subspecies of T. rhadamantus: separation of the two taxa is based on differences in coloration and may not be justified (Matsuka 2001, in Vane-Wright and de Jong 2003).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

This species is known only from the type series, and further taxonomic studies are required.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.
In literature this species was often placed under the genus Erinna which is found in Hawaii in similar habitat. However, this is a case of convergence and not relationship.

The genus name Germainaia was created by Graf & Cummings (2009) for a few medium sized najad shells that had been collected by the French naturalist Martin-François Geay during his explorations in Madagascar (1904-1908) and originally described as Unio (Nodularia) geayi by Germain (2011). No precise type locality is known and considering that Geay also collected in New Zealand and Australia in 1908, where he died, the origin of the material remains uncertain. Graf and Cummings (2009, 2011) do accept that the material originates from Madagascar, adding that its family classification remains doubtful (incertae sedis), i.e. either Unionidae (with Laurasian and African distribution) or Hyriidae (Australian- S. American).
The generic name Afrogyrus Brown & Mandahl-Barth, 1973  being occupied (Coleoptera, Gyrinidae), the genus now is called Africanogyrus Özdikmen & Darılmaz (2007).

Neritina spiniperda Morelet, 1860 (endemic to the Nossi-Bé are in Madagascar) is not considerd as a valid species by Bouchet et al. (2016) but as a possible synonym of Clithon madecassinum. However, this form has not been refound over a century and its taxonomic place remains doubtful.

Unio madagascariensis is a nomen dubium (Graf & Cummings, 2009). It is only known from the extremely summary description of  Sganzin (1841) who states that adult specimens have the size of a Potadoma littoralis (hence with an adult lenght of ca. 50-70 mm) but are very fragile and of a greenish color.

Unio malgachensis is also considered a nomen dubium by Graf & Cummings (2009). Only the type is known, which is of a juvenile najad (L = 12 mm) that can not be identified on genus or family level (Graf and Cummings 2009).
According to recent molecular research (Pigneur et al. 2014) is Corbicula madagascariensis a distinct species and not a form of C. fluminalis.
The type material of P. pauliani, deposited at the Museé d'Histoire Naturel (Paris) seems to be lost.

authority: (Rowley, Stuart, Neang, Hoang, Dau, Nguyen, & Emmett, 2015)

taxonomicNotes:
Neritopsine populations from Madagascar and the Mascarenes have been often described as Clithon corona (Linnaeus, 1758) or as C. longispina (Récluz, 1841) and C. brevispina (Riech, 1937), which should be considered synonyms of the first.

Clithon corona does occur in the eastern Indo-Pacific, in Papua New Guinea, Guam, Caroline Islands, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Samoa, Taiwan and New Caledonia. All above references from Madagascar and the Mascarenes should be attributed to Clithon coronatus (Leach, 1815). Inversely, references of C. corona from the eastern Pacific are erroneous.

The shells described as C. longispina (Récluz, 1841) and Clithon brevispina described from the island  of Madagascar do come from other localities in the Indo-Pacific according to Fischer-Piette and Vulkadinovic (1973).
This species is presently placed in the new genus Madagisikara Köhler & Glaubrecht, 2010. It previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Melanatria.

In Hylarana signata complex, this is a split from the broader concept of Hylarana siberu (Chan et al. 2014). Currently known as Pulchrana centropeninsularis after a phylogenetic review by Oliver et al. (2015).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

The taxonomy of this species needs to be resolved, as current collections probably represent more than one taxon.

The validity of this species was questioned by Golubev in Ščerzbak (2003), who considered it an isolated population attributable to Phrynocephalus maculatus. According to Barabanov and Ananjeva (2007) P. golubewii is presently considered a valid species. It was treated within P. maculatus by Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008), who however, noted that it appeared to be well-separated in the phylogeny provided by Arnold (1999).

Verified records of this species come only from Peninsular Malaysia. Records from other countries are either misidentified or misattributed. Records from peninsular Thailand and Borneo are referrable to Microhyla perparva and M. petrigenea according to Manthey and Denzer (2014).
This species was assessed in 2008 as a subspecies of Cercocebus atys, but is now raised to a species. This species was also formerly treated as a subspecies of C. torquatus.

This species was treated in previous Red List assessments (1986 to 2008) under the genus Cercopithecus, but is now placed under Allochrocebus following Mittermeier et al. (2013). The genus name Allochrocebus was first used by Elliot in 1913 and later referred to as a geospecies by Grubb et al. (2003). The species is more terrestrial than any of the Cercopithecus taxa (Oates, 2011, Tosi et al. 2004).

This species was treated in previous Red List assessments (1988 to 30 June 2008) under the genus Cercopithecus, but is now placed under Allochrocebus following Butynski (2013). Along with A. solatus and A. lhoesti, it forms part of the Allochrocebus preussi geospecies (Grubb 2006). There are two subspecies, C. preussi preussi and C. p. insularis, following Grubb et al. (2003) and Groves (2005).

Booth (1955) and Napier (1981) treated this monkey as a subspecies of Cercopithecus campbelli within the C. mona group, but Kingdon (1997) made it a full species within his Cercopithecus mona superspecies. Groves (2001) followed Kingdon’s arrangement whereas Grubb et al. (2003) considered it a subspecies of C. campbelli. The latter treatment was followed for the 2008 Red List assessment. Groves (2005) continued to classify C. lowei as a distinct species, and that approach is followed by (Mittermeier et al. 2013) and in this assessment. However, such taxonomic splitting may be premature, because no rigorous genetic, morphological, or vocalization analyses have been applied to test species differences between the two taxa, and because individuals with pelage features of both putative species occur between the Cavally and Sassandra Rivers in eastern Côte d’Ivoire, as well as individuals with features intermediate between the two (Oates 1988).

Cercopithecus diana and C. roloway comprise the diana species group. In the 2008 IUCN Red List these taxa were treated as subspecies (C. d. diana and C. d. roloway) of a broader species-concept following Kingdon (1997) and Grubb et al. (2003). Groves (2005) elevated both to full species and that treatment is now followed here (based on Mittermeier et al. 2013). Not all assessors agree with this classification; Oates (2011) recognizes one species with two subspecies: diana and roloway.

Cercopithecus diana and C. roloway comprise the diana species group. In the 2008 IUCN Red List these were treated as subspecies (C. d. diana and C. d. roloway) of a broader species-concept following Kingdon (1997) and Grubb et al. (2003). Groves (2005) elevated both to full species and that treatment is now followed here (as in Mittermeier et al. 2013). Not all assessors agree with this classification; Oates (2011) treats roloway as a subspecies of C. diana.
Chan et al. (2010), suggested that the dubious records of Leptolalax gracilis from Gunung Tahan might actually represent this species.
Previously confused with Ansonia penangensis (Wood et al. 2008).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the olive colobus into two genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, 2015; Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus, Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the olive colobus and Piliocolubus for the red colobuses) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of using two genera is followed here (Groves 2001, 2005, 2007).
This species has been considered a subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius, Procolobus (Piliocolobus) pennantii, Procolobus (Piliocolobus) rufomitratus, or Procolobus (Piliocolobus) kirkii, but is here treated as a full species following Groves (2001, 2005, 2007), Grubb et al. (2003), Struhsaker et al. (2013), and Kingdon (2015).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the Olive Colobus into two genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus, Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolubus for the red colobus) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of using two separate genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the Olive Colobus into two genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus, Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolubus for the red colobus) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of using two separate genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here.
Here treated as a distinct species from P. pennantii following Kingdon and Butynski (2013); this species has, in the past, also been considered a subspecies of P. badius.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the Olive Colobus into two genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus, Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolubus for the red colobus) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of using two separate genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here.

This taxon was formerly the nominate subspecies of a wider concept of P. badius which included temminckii and waldronae as subspecies. The subspecies are now treated as distinct species following Groves (2007).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the Olive Colobus into two genera,  Piliocolobus  and  Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus, Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolubus for the red colobus) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of using two separate genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here.

This taxon was formerly a subspecies of a wider concept of P. badius which included badius, temminckii and waldronae as subspecies. The subspecies are now treated as distinct species following Groves (2007).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the Olive Colobus into two genera: Piliocolobus and Procolobus respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus (Procolobus) with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolubus for the red colobus) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Oates 2011, Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of using two separate genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here.

This taxon formerly was regarded as a subspecies of the Upper Guinea species P. badius which included badius, temminckii and waldroni as subspecies.

Although Groves (2007) used the name waldronae for this monkey, Brandon-Jones et al. (2007) have shown clearly that waldroni is a valid name.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the Olive Colobus into two genera,  Piliocolobus  and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus, Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolubus for the red colobus) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of using two separate genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here.

This taxon was formerly the nominate subspecies of a wider concept of P. pennantii which included bouvieri and epieni as subspecies. The subspecies are now treated as distinct species following Groves (2007). This taxon has also been treated as a subspecies of Procolobus badius in the past.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the Olive Colobus into two genera,  Piliocolobus  and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus, Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolubus for the red colobus) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of using two separate genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here.

This taxon was formerly a subspecies of a wider concept of P. pennantii which included bouvieri, epieni and pennantii as subspecies. The subspecies are now treated as distinct species following Groves (2007). This taxon has also been treated as a subspecies of Procolobus badius in the past.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the Olive Colobus into two genera,  Piliocolobus  and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus, Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolubus for the red colobus) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of using two separate genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here.

This taxon was formerly a subspecies of a wider concept of P. pennantii which included bouvieri, epieni and pennantii as subspecies. The subspecies are now treated as distinct species following Groves (2007). The study by Ting (2008) on vocalizations and mitochondrial DNA confirmed that P. epieni is not closely related to its closets geographic relatives (P. pennantii and P. preussii). This taxon has also been treated as a subspecies of Procolobus badius in the past.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either place the red colobuses and the Olive Colobus in separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus, Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the olive colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobuses) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The two genera arrangement is applied here.

This taxon was formerly the nominate subspecies of P. rufomitratus for subspecies semlikiensis, foai, langi, oustaleti, parmentieri, tephrosceles, and tholloni (subspecies ellioti and lulindicus are no longer recognized). All of these taxa are now treated as species following Groves (2001, 2007).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the Olive Colobus into two genera,  Piliocolobus  and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus, Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolubus for the red colobus) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of using two separate genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here.

This taxon was formerly a subspecies of a wider concept of P. rufomitratus which included subspecies rufomitratus, semlikiensis, foai, langi, oustaleti, parmentieri, tephrosceles and tholloni (subspecies ellioti and lulindicus are no longer recognized). The former subspecies are now treated as distinct species following Groves (2007).
