Arborophila charltonii, A. tonkinensis, and A. graydoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. charltonii following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lophura erythrophthalma and L. pyronota (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. erythrophthalma following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lophura erythrophthalma and L. pyronota (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. erythrophthalma following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Coenocorypha aucklandica, C. huegeli, C. barrierensis and C. iredalei (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. aucklandica following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Prioniturus discurus and P. mindorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. discurus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Coracopsis nigra, C. barklyi and C. sibilans (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. nigra following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Actenoides princeps and A. regalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. princeps following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Otidiphaps nobilis, O. aruensis, O. cervicalis and O. insularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. nobilis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pteroglossus bitorquatus and P. sturmii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. bitorquatus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Treron australis and T griveaudi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as T. australis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Rhizothera longirostris and R. dulitensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. longirostris following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Geotrygon purpurata and G. saphirina (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. saphirina following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Chlorodrepanis flava (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Hemignathus and listed as H. flavus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Aerodramus bartschi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Collocalia. Collocalia inquieta (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously split into C. bartschi following Browning (1993) and AOU (1998) and C. inquieta following Browning (1993).
Dromaius minor (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as D. ater following Christidis and Boles (1994); the name minor has priority.
Alopochen mauritiana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as A. mauritianus.

Psittacara labati (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aratinga.

Conures were also reported from Barbados (Clark 1905a) and Martinique (Clark 1905b), but insufficient evidence exists to assign them taxonomically.
Porphyrio caerulescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as P. coerulescens.
Hypotaenidia poeciloptera (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Nesoclopeus as N. poecilopterus.
Zapornia nigra (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Porzana.
Zapornia astrictocarpus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Porzana.

Gallinula nesiotis and G. comeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. nesiotis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Groenenburg et al. (2008, 2009), and before that had been treated as separate species by Collar and Stuart (1985).
Fulica newtonii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as F. newtoni.
Necropsittacus rodricanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as N. rodericanus.
Erythromachus leguati (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aphanapteryx.
Poodytes rufescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bowdleria rufescens.

authority: O'Neill, Lane, Kratter, Capparella et al., 2000

taxonomicNotes:
Clanga hastata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aquila.

Aquila pomarina (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously split into A. pomarina and A. hastata following Parry et al. (2002).
Geotrygon caniceps and G. leucometopia (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. caniceps following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Geotrygon caniceps and G. leucometopia (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. caniceps following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Struthio camelus and S. molybdophanes (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as S. camelus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae and H. chathamensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as H. novaeseelandiae following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Nisaetus philippensis and N. pinskeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Haring et al. (2006), which before then was placed in the genus Spizaetus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Turnix varius and T. novaecaledoniae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as T. varius following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Goura scheepmakeri and G. sclaterii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. scheepmakeri following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Nisaetus philippensis and N. pinskeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Haring et al. (2006), which before then was placed in the genus Spizaetus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Crax fasciolata and C. pinima (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. fasciolata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Malacoptila striata and M. minor (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. striata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pyrrhura picta, P. snethlageae, P. parvifrons, P. amazonum, P. lucianii, P. roseifrons, P. peruviana, P. subandina, P. caeruleiceps and P. eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. picta following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pyrrhura picta, P. snethlageae, P. parvifrons, P. amazonum, P. lucianii, P. roseifrons, P. peruviana, P. subandina, P. caeruleiceps and P. eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. picta following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pyrrhura picta, P. snethlageae, P. parvifrons, P. amazonum, P. lucianii, P. roseifrons, P. peruviana, P. subandina, P. caeruleiceps and P. eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. picta following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pyrrhura picta, P. snethlageae, P. parvifrons, P. amazonum, P. lucianii, P. roseifrons, P. peruviana, P. subandina, P. caeruleiceps and P. eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. picta following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pyrrhura picta, P. snethlageae, P. parvifrons, P. amazonum, P. lucianii, P. roseifrons, P. peruviana, P. subandina, P. caeruleiceps and P. eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. picta following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ninox jacquinoti, N. granti, N. malaitae and N. roseoaxillaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. jacquinoti following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ninox jacquinoti, N. granti, N. malaitae and N. roseoaxillaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. jacquinoti following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Psophia viridis, P. dextralis and P. obscura (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. viridis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Psophia viridis, P. dextralis and P. obscura (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. viridis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Coeligena bonapartei, C. consita and C. eos (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. bonapartei following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ceyx melanurus and C. mindanensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. melanurus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ceyx melanurus and C. mindanensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. melanurus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Neomorphus geoffroyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as N. geoffroyi and N. squamiger following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Coenocorypha aucklandica, C. huegeli, C. barrierensis and C. iredalei (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. aucklandica following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pionites leucogaster, P. xanthomerius and P. xanthurus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. leucogaster following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pionites leucogaster, P. xanthomerius and P. xanthurus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. leucogaster following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Aegolius gradyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was newly described from fossil remains by Olson (2012).
Aratinga solstitialis and A. maculata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. solstitialis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Prosobonia cancellata and P. parvirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. cancellata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

This is a split from the broader concept of Alcalus baluensis by Brown et al. (2015), who recognised this species as distinct and placed it in this genus (it was previously known as Ingerana baluensis - Inger and Tan 1996).
Formerly this species included Otomops martiensseni.
This species has been split from Rhinopoma muscatellum by Hulva et al. (2007) and Benda et al. (2009).

Rhinolophus belligerator (Patrick, McCulloch, and Ruedas 2013) previously was included with R. arcuatus proconsulis by Hill (1988) based on a single specimen from the Tengah Province of Sulawesi. Subsequent analyses by Patrick and co-workers (2013) elevated this taxon to species status.
Records of Cardioglossa pulchra from Tchabal Mbabo (Amiet 1972) now refer to this species (Herrmann et al. 2004).

Studies are needed to determine whether or not specimens from Cameroon and Togo belong to the same species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). It is currently unclear whether there are any Werneria species in Togo, but it has been suggested that if there is one, it could be either W. preussi or alternatively a different, distinct species, Werneria africanus, which would be an endemic species to Togo (see Segniagbeto et al. 2007).

Following Amiet and Dowsett-Lemaire (2000), Leptodactylodon bueanus is here considered a separate species from L. albiventris (as opposed to a subspecies of L. albiventris following Amiet (1987)). Rödel and Pauwels (2003) provisionally assigned records of L. albiventris from Equatorial Guinea (De la Riva 1994) to L. stevarti.
Following Amiet and Dowsett-Lemaire (2000), Leptodactylodon bueanus is here treated as a separate species from L. albiventris (as opposed to a subspecies of L. albiventris following Amiet (1987)).
Iskandar (pers. comm.) has examined the type specimen, and considers that this species does not belong to the genus Oreophryne.

Voucher specimens held at MNHN. This species is known from the rivers of the Massif Ambre in northern Madagascar. Submitted as Ptychochromis sp. nov. 'Tsipoy verte' and subsequently changed to Ptychochromis sp. nov. 'Green Garaka' on recommendation of Paul Loiselle.

This species mistakenly appeared on the IUCN Red List as Ptychochromis loisellei. However, Ptychochromis loisellei includes both Ptychochromis sp. nov. 'Green Garaka' and Ptychochromis sp. nov. 'Garaka'. An updated Red List assessment has been created to reflect this name change.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).
This species was previously considered a subspecies of Alopia glorifica, but raised to species level following revision of the genus by Fehér et al. (2013).

This species was previously considered a subspecies of Alopia subcosticollis, but raised to species level following revision of the genus by Fehér et al. (2013). According to the same study, A. grossuana nemethi Deli and Szekeres, 2011 is a subspecies of A. grossuana.
We follow Rödel and Pauwels (2003) in provisionally assigning records of Leptodactylodon albiventris from Equatorial Guinea (De la Riva 1994) to this newly described species.

This species was previously considered a subspecies of Alopia glorifica, but was raised to species level following revision of the genus by Fehér et al. (2013). According to the same study, Alopia mafteiana has two subspecies: A. mafteiana mafteiana Grossu, 1867 and A. mafteiana valeriae Szekeres, 2007.
The Atelognathus praebasalticus complex needs to be re-examined taxonomically. There are four known subspecies, some of which may constitute new species. Some of these subspecies may be extinct.

authority: Evans, Carter, Tobias, Kelley, Hanner & Tinsley, 2008
taxonomicNotes: This species is considered to be the sister taxon of Xenopus wittei (Evans et al. 2008).

Honda et al. (2014) revised Japanese members of Goniurosaurus, previously considered either the full species G. kuroiwae, G. toyami, G. yamashinae, G. orientalis and G. splendens, or a single taxon G. kuroiwae with five subspecies. These authors' results supported the recognition of two full species, G. splendens and G. kuroiwae, and they proposed treating G. orientalis, G. toyami and G. yamashinae as subspecies of G. kuroiwae.

Further molecular research into this species complex is ongoing, and has confirmed that there are at least five species-level clades in the Ryukyus, corresponding to subspecies of G. kuroiwae recognized by Honda et al. (2014) plus G. splendens (H. Ota pers. comm. 2016). As a revision of this group is due to be submitted for publication shortly, this account adopts a traditional five-species treatment of this complex, while recognizing that both G. kuroiwae and G. orientalis as presently recognized may be further subdivided in the near future.

This taxon was previously considered as belonging to the otherwise central Ryukyu species Takydromus smaragdinus (Boulenger 1887), but is now recognized to be a distinct, phylogenetically rather distant species (see Lin et al. 2002, Ota et al. 2002).

Trionyx triunguis has been considered a single widespread, relatively uniform species for decades, with no subspecies or other taxonomic units recognized or proposed in recent years. Phylogeographic studies of regional variation have demonstrated different, partly conflicting results, but were based on generally limited sets of specimens and genetic markers (Gidis et al., 2011; Guclu et al., 2011, 2015; Shanas et al., 2012). However, there is still uncertainty as to whether Mediterranean and African populations may in fact represent genetically definable separate Management Units (O. Türkozan unpubl. data).
This species appeared on the IUCN Red List as Hoplotilapia retrodens until 2016. It is now valid as Haplochromis retrodens (Eschmeyer et al. 2016).

This species is valid in the genus Haplochromis in FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2016) based on Van Oijen et al. (1991). It is valid in the genus Allochromis in Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2016) based on Poll and Gosse (1995). Previously, this species appeared on the Red List in the genus Allochromis but the taxonomy of FishBase is now followed.

This species is valid in the genus Haplochromis in Fishbase (Froese and Pauly 2016) based on Van Oijen (1996). It is valid in the genus Lithochromis in Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2016) based on Seehausen et al. (1998). Previously, this species appeared on the Red List in the genus Lithochromis but the taxonomy of FishBase is now followed.

This species is valid in the genus Haplochromis in FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2016) based on Van Oijen (1996). It is valid in the genus Macropleurodus in Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2016) based on Van Oijen et al. (1991), Poll and Gosse (1995) and Greenwood (1995). Previously, this species appeared on the Red List in the genus Macropleurodus but the taxonomy of FishBase is now followed.

This species is valid in the genus Haplochromis in FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2016) based on Van Oijen (1996). It is valid in the genus Mbipia in Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2016) based on Seehausen et al. (1998). Previously, this species appeared on the Red List in the genus Mbipia but the taxonomy of FishBase is now followed.

According to Seehausen et al. 1998, this is a large haplochromines with a relatively steep, straight dorsal head profile, many tooth rows, and bright male nupital coloration. Males are distinguished from males of H. mbipi by smaller eyes, a usually shallower body, a usually longer snout, by bright yellow male colouration with distinct vertical bars (vs.cCoppery black or dark greenish yellow without distinct bars), by less ctenoid scales on the rostral part of the body, by small cycloid scales in the anal/ genital region (vs. a mixture of small cycloid and larger ctenoid scales), and a scaleless dorsal fin (vs. cycloid scales on the spiny part).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species is valid in the genus Haplochromis according to Van Oijen et al. (1991) and this is followed by FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2016). Eschmeyer et al. (2016) state that Yssichromis is valid "based on placement of type species". Previously, this species appeared on the Red List in the genus Yssichromis but the taxonomy of FishBase is now followed.

This species is valid in the genus Haplochromis in FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2016) based on Van Oijen 1996. It is valid in the genus Neochromis in Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2016) based on Seehausen et al. 1998. Previously, this species appeared on the Red List in the genus Neochromis but the taxonomy of FishBase is now followed.

According to Seehausen et al. 1998, this is a large, moderately deep bodied haplochromine with a steep and convex dorsal head profile, an often slightly retrognath lower jaw, closely bicuspid outer teeth, many rows of inner teeth, blue male flank colouration with black vertical bars, or entirely black flank colouration, a red or wine-red anal fin, and a similarly but fainter coloured caudal fin.

This species is valid in the genus Haplochromis in FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2016) based on Van Oijen (1996). It is valid in the genus Pundamilia in Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2016) based on Seehausen et al. (1998). Previously, this species appeared on the Red List in the genus Pundamilia but the taxonomy of FishBase is now followed.

This species is valid in the genus Haplochromis in FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2016) based on Van Oijen (1996). It is valid in the genus Pundamilia in Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2016) based on Seehausen et al. (1998). Previously, this species appeared on the Red List in the genus Pundamilia but the taxonomy of FishBase is now followed.

This species is valid in the genus Haplochromis in FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2016) based on Van Oijen (1996). It is valid in the genus Pundamilia in Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2016) based on Seehausen et al. (1998). Previously, this species appeared on the Red List in the genus Pundamilia but the taxonomy of FishBase is now followed.

This species is valid in the genus Haplochromis in FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2016). It is valid in the genus Pyxichromis in Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2016). Previously, this species appeared on the Red List in the genus Pyxichromis but the taxonomy of FishBase is now followed.

There are no recognized Trichechus senegalensis subspecies and limited genetic information indicates high genetic diversity (Vianna et al. 2006, Keith Diagne 2014). Anecdotal assertions of morphological differences between isolated inland populations and coastal populations persist, but there is no genetic or morphological evidence (Domning and Hayek 1986, Vianna et al. 2006, Keith Diagne 2014).

Current scientific review of the taxonomy of wild equids (Groves 1986) places Przewalski's Horse as a subspecies of the extinct Equus ferus. Although Przewalski's Horse (Equus ferus przewalskii) can hybridize with domestic horses (Equus ferus caballus) to produce fertile offspring (Ryder et al. 1978, Trommerhausen-Smith et al. 1979), the existence of 2n = 66 chromosomes in Przewalski's Horse identifies it as being more different from its domestic relatives (2n = 64) than are any two breeds of domestic horse (Ryder 1994). Furthermore, mitochondrial DNA research has shown that the Przewalski's Horse is not the ancestor of modern domestic horses (Vilà et al. 2001). Przewalski's Horse also show a number of consistent differences in their appearance as compared to domestic horse breeds: the mane is short and erect when in good body condition; forelocks are nearly nonexistent; the upper part of the tail has short guard hairs; a dark dorsal stripe runs from the mane down the spine to the tail; several dark stripes can be present on the carpus and generally the tarsus (Groves 1994). Przewalski's Horses grow a thick mane in winter, which contrary to domestic horses they shed each spring with the rest of their winter coat.

Other studies of the genetic differences between Przewalski's and domestic horses have indicated very little genetic distinction between them. Only four alleles at four separate serological marker loci have been identified as specific to Przewalski's Horse (Bowling and Ryder 1987); the vast majority of blood protein variants are present in both Przewalski's and domestic horses and even the fastest evolving DNA region known in mammals (the mitochondrial DNA control region), does not show significant differences between the two types of horse (Ishida et al. 1995, Oakenfull and Ryder 1998). Thus it is clear that Przewalski's and domestic horses are very closely related and have in the past interbred, but the fixed chromosomal number difference between them indicates that they are distinct populations (Oakenfull et al. 2000). A variety of molecular studies support their phylogenetic relationship as sister taxa (Steiner et al. 2012, Côté et al. 2013) diverging between 150,000 and 250,000 years ago (Goto et al. 2011, Steiner and Ryder 2011).

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anaur, Grismer, Quah, Murdoch, Muin, Davis, Aguilar, Klabacka, Cobos, Aowphol & Sites, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This population represents a new species of karst-adapted Bent-toed Gecko from the Cyrtodactylus pulchellus complex. All the morphological and genetic data concerning this population has been evaluated and confirms its new species designation (Grismer et al. 2014)

Classically considered a single species, the Clouded Leopard has been split into two species. Based on analysis of mitochondrial DNA, microsatellites, chromosomal differences and skull and pelage characteristics, Neofelis nebulosa is restricted to mainland southeast Asia, and N. diardi, the Sunda Clouded Leopard, is found on the islands of Sumatra and Borneo (Buckley-Beason et al. 2006; Kitchener et al. 2006, 2007; Christiansen et al. 2008, 2009; Wilting et al. 2007; Wilting et al. 2011). Sundaland or the Sunda regions refer to the islands of Sumatra, Borneo, Java and Bali as well as to the Malay Peninsula. Although samples are limited from Peninsular Malaysia, it appears to be inhabited by the mainland Clouded Leopard N. nebulosa, rather than the Sunda Island type (Kitchener et al. 2007). The original type specimen of N. diardi originated from Sumatra, but it was initially recorded in error as from Java (Kitchener et al. 2006). As this type specimen described by Cuvier (1823) is not present in any museum, Christiansen 2009 designated a Neoptype (RMNH1981) from Palembang, Sumatra, which is housed at the National Museum of Natural History (Naturalis), in Leiden, the Netherlands. Clouded Leopard fossils have been found on Java, where it perhaps became extinct in the Holocene (Meijaard 2004). Based on analysis of genetic, skull and pelage characteristics, Wilting et al. (2011) recognized two distinct subspecies of N. diardi: the Sumatran Clouded Leopard N. d. diardi and the Bornean Clouded Leopard N. d. borneensis.

Classically considered a single species, the Clouded Leopard has recently been split into two species. Based on analysis of mitochondrial DNA, microsatellites and morphology, Neofelis nebulosa is restricted to mainland Southeast Asia, and N. diardi is found on the islands of Sumatra and Borneo (Buckley-Beason et al. 2006, Kitchener et al. 2006, Wilting et al. 2007).

Molecular data suggests that this taxon might in fact consist of two species, although further research is required to confirm this (Kryštufek et al. 2007). Genetic data clearly indicate that the Balkan Snow Vole is composed of three historically isolated, independently evolving sets of populations, that can be regarded as evolutionary significant units (ESUs).
Mouldingia orientalis was assessed as Endangered in 1996. Köhler and Criscione (2013) transferred this species to Nanotrachia.

Chelodina parkeri is a morphologically distinct and uncontroversially recognized species, with an adequate description and diagnosis provided in the original account (Rhodin and Mittermeier 1976; Georges and Thomson 2010; TTWG 2017). No subspecies or geographic variations are recognized and it has not yet been genetically analyzed. It can conceivably be confused with Chelodina oblonga (formerly Chelodina siebenrocki or Chelodina rugosa), but the species do not occur sympatrically and C. parkeri is distinguished by the distinct white head patch immediately above and behind the tympanum, with or without dark blotches and a ventral surface of the cervical scute longer than wide.

Elseya branderhorsti (Ouwens, 1914)1914 Emydura branderhorsti Ouwens, 1914, described from a live specimen, type either non-existent or lost (Leo Brongersma pers. comm. to John Goode 1967, 28 June 1963), from southern New Guinea. 1994 Elseya branderhorsti—Bour et al., in David, 1994. First use of combination. 
Commonly confused with Elseya novaeguineae because of its superficial resemblance. Original description states lack of a cervical scute as the diagnostic character, by which it can typically be distinguished from Elseya novaeguineae (recently split to recognise Elseya shultzei and Elseya rhodini). A prominent alveolar ridge on the triturating surfaces of the mouth is also diagnostic. DNA sequence data suggest affinities with the species of Elseya from northern Australia. No subspecies are recognised.

Previously considered to encompass the Broad-headed Map Turtles inhabiting the Pascagoula and Pearl river systems, Graptemys gibbonsi was reduced in scope when the Pearl River form was described as a separate species, G. pearlensis Ennen, Lovich, Kreiser, Selman & Qualls, 2010.
This species is under taxonomic review and it is likely to be split into five species (P. Praschag pers. comm. 2018).

Cuora flavomarginata is generally considered to include the form evelynae as a subspecies (Ota et al. 2009), though Ernst et al. (2008) retained evelynae as a full species. The name sinensis has been applied to mainland Chinese populations as a subspecies, with the typical flavomarginata restricted to Taiwan, but recent reviews (Fritz and Havas 2007; Ota et al. 2009; TTWG 2010) have not recognised Taiwanese and mainland populations as taxonomically distinct.

Two subspecies are recognised: C. m. mouhotii (Gray, 1863) and C. m. obsti (Fritz, Andreas & Lehr, 1997).

Traditionally placed in the monotypic genus Pyxidea until Honda et al (2002) demonstrated that mouhotii is genetically nested inside Cuora. Hybrids of C. mouhotii with Cuora galbinifrons or C. bourreti gave rise to specimens that were erroneously described as a separate species, Cuora serrata.

Cuora yunnanensis has been suggested to be an old example of an inter-specific hybrid, but a 1908 museum specimen was found to have unique mt-DNA indicating it to be a valid species status (Parham et al. 2004), and recent trade specimens of unreported origin agreed genetically with the 1908 specimen (He et al. 2007).

The taxon Hardella indi (Gray, 1870) was traditionally considered a subspecies, Hardella thurjii indi, but was most recently synonymized as insufficiently distinct from the typical form to warrant recognition (Praschag et al., 2007).
Appeared on IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the generic name Hieremys.

Was treated under the generic name Geoemyda in the 1996 IUCN Red List. Genus was changed to Heosemys in the 2000 IUCN Red List. Now reassigned to a new monotypic genus, Leucocephalon (A. Rhodin, pers comm.)
The common name for this species in Vietnamese is Rùa Trung Bộ.
Genetic variability – see Fong et al.
Generally considered to consist of at least two morphologically distinguishable lineages.
Traditionally placed in the genus Kachuga, it was assigned to the subgenus Pangshura by Moll (1987); Pangshura was elevated to genus level by Das, 2001.
See Shi et al 2008
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the generic names Heosemys and Geoemyda.
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the generic names Geoemyda and Heosemys.No subspecies or synonymised data.
Historically placed in Podocnemis. No subspecies are currently recognized.
Placed by some as a subspecies under C. chitra.

Anderson (1875) described it as Trionyx nigricans from the pond at the Hazrat Sultan Bayazid Bostami Shrine in Nasirabad near Chittagong, Bangladesh. Subsequent authors believed that the species either became extinct in the wild (Pritchard 1979; Groombridge 1982) or that it ‘descended from introduced individuals of the more widespread Trionyx gangeticus’ (Groombridge 1982; Khan 1987) or of N. hurum (Rashid 1990). Using mainly skull osteology as well as coloration and pattern characters, Praschag and Gemel (2002) recognized it from northeast India as Aspideretes nigricans. Based on molecular data, Engstrom et al. (2004) and Praschag et al. (2007) transferred the genus Aspideretes Hay 1903 into synonymy of Nilssonia (Gray, 1872). See Praschag & Gemel (2002) for discussion of taxonomic distinction from other large Asian softshell species.

Pelochelys bibroni was redescribed and separated from Pelochelys cantorii and restricted to the southern lowlands of New Guinea by Webb (1995), based partly on Rhodin et al. (1993). The genetic divergence of P. bibroni from Asian P. cantorii was confirmed by Engstrom et al. (2004), but it has yet to be compared genetically with P. signifera (Webb 2003), a morphologically distinct species from northern New Guinea. No geographic variation has been reported within the species' range and no subspecies have been named.
The conservation assessment of this taxon is complicated by the conviction that the current taxonomic designation hides a complex of several different species.

Le et al. (2014) concluded that the Yangtze and Red River populations of Rafetus swinhoei do not show significant genetic divergence and do not warrant recognition as separate evolutionary significant units for conservation management. However, it appears that Le et al. (2014) did not actually have any samples from the Yangtze population, only samples from the Vietnamese and Chinese parts of the Red River catchment. Chen (2015) found two distinct mtDNA lineages of R. swinhoei which are roughly 2.8% divergent from each other (Cytochrome B and NADH dehydrogenase 4), one represented by Red River specimens and the second one by a Shanghai museum specimen of unknown origin. In the mean time tissue samples from the male of Suzhou Zoo and the female of Changsha Zoo proofed to be concordant with this Shanghai museum specimen (Chen, pers. comm.). This points to a possibility that the Yangtze and the Red River populations may represent separate taxa at least at the level of subspecies. In that case the Yangtze population would represent the nominate form Rafetus swinhoei swinhoei and the Vietnamese and Chinese Red River population the subspecies Rafetus swinhoei leloii.
Phillips et al. (1996) elevated rossignonii and acutirostris to species level (from geographically isolated subspecies of C. serpentina) based on genetic differentiation.

This is the single living species and genus in this family which dates back to the Eocene. A number of synonyms have been published for the species, all obsolete and not used for a long time. The corrected but invalid spelling mawei has been supported by some taxonomists.

Previously this species was known as Clemmys insculpta, under which name it appeared in IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006; paraphyly of the traditional genus Clemmys (sensu McDowell, 1964) required placement of insculpta and muhlenbergii into Glyptemys (Holman and Fritz 2001, Parham and Feldman 2002).

Previously this species was known as Clemmys muhlenbergii, under which name it appeared in IUCN Red Lists until 2008. Paraphyly of the traditional genus Clemmys (sensu McDowell, 1964) required placement of muhlenbergii and insculpta into Glyptemys.
Previously this species was considered the Pearl River population of Graptemys gibbonsi, until G. pearlensis was described by Ennen et al. (2010) as a full separate species.

Currently considered to comprise six subspecies: Terrapene carolina carolina (Linnaeus, 1758), T. carolina bauri Taylor, 1895, T. carolina triunguis (Agassiz, 1857), T. carolina major (Agassiz, 1857), T. c. mexicana (Gray, 1849) and T. c. yucatana (Boulenger, 1895). The taxonomic status of the taxa yucatana and mexicana remains dynamic; they were treated as full species by Smith et al. (1996) and Stephens and Wiens (2003), but were treated as subspecies of carolina by Fritz and Havas (2007) and TTWG (2010). Butler et al. (2011) argued that the subspecies T. c. major is based on a phenotype resulting from introgression of genes of the extinct subspecies Terrapene c. putnami in eastern subspecies (mainly T. c. carolina) and does not warrant formal recognition.
No subspecies and no synonymised taxa attributed.

Traditionally considered a subspecies of Trachemys scripta, recognised as full species by several authors, including Seidel (2002). Seidel (2002) placed two taxa as subspecies of T. gaigeae: T. gaigeae gaigeae (Hartweg, 1939), and T. gaigeae hartwegi (Legler, 1990).
This taxon has traditionally been considered to be a subspecies of Trachemys scripta (Legler 1990), but it was elevated to full species rank by Seidel (2002).
Traditionally considered a subspecies of Trachemys scripta, noted as sufficiently distinct to warrant species rank by Legler (1990), and formally elevated to full species by Seidel (2002).
This taxon was traditionally considered to be a subspecies of Trachemys scripta, but it was elevated to full species rank by Seidel (2002).

Traditionally placed in Chinemys, reevesii has in recent years been widely accepted as a species of Mauremys (Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2010). The species includes the forms Chinemys megalocephala Fang, 1934, Geoclemys grangeri Schmidt, 1925, and Damonia unicolor Gray, 1873, which have on occasion been considered as valid species or subspecies, but have in recent years been treated consistently as synonyms of reevesii (Guo et al. 1997; Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2010).
We follow Matsui et al. (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of S. tuberilinguis.

The genus Nesolestes may be a synonym of Neurolestes (Gambles 1970). Similar specimens from adjacent Cameroon may pertain to another species (Vick unpubl). The original 2009 Red List assessment included this species in Nesolestes. In 2017, it was moved to genus Neurolestes.

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Brede, Hillers & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Sandberger-Loua, Hirschfeld, Brede, Emmrich, Kouamé, Hillers, Gonwouo, Nopper, Adeba, Bangoura, Gage, Anderson & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Hirschfeld, Brede, Bangoura & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).

Feldhamer et al. (1988) and Geist (1998) included Dama mesopotamica as a subspecies of Dama dama, though it was regarded as a separate species by Haltenorth (1959), Ferguson et al. (1985), Uerpmann (1987), and Harrison and Bates (1991). We follow Pitra et al. (2004) and Randi et al. (2001) in treating D. mesopotamica as a separate species, based on a major study on the evolution and phylogeny of old world deer.

authority: Coloma, Carvajal-Endara, Dueñas, Paredes-Recalde, Morales-Mite, Almeida-Reinoso, Tapia, Hutter, Toral-Contreras & Guayasamin, 2012
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hyloscirtus larinopygion (Coloma et al. 2012).
This species was previously considered as incertae sedis, however the validity of this species has now been confirmed (Jungfer et al. 2013).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Atelopus ignescens by McDiarmid (1971).

Coloma, Lötters and Salas (2000) redefined Atelopus ignescens and restricted the species to the north-central Andes of Ecuador. Populations in northern Ecuador (in Cachi Province), and adjacent southern Colombia (Narino Department), previously assigned to Atelopus ignescens are now considered to belong to an undescribed species.
Records other than from the type locality (e.g. Peters 1973) are considered here to refer to Atelopus planispina.

The taxonomic status of A. planispina and A. palmatus was discussed by Coloma (1997). Records of A. palmatus from Napo Province actually belong to this species (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).
This species and Epipedobates anthonyi were separated by Schulte (1999). We follow Graham et al. (2004) in restricting the distribution of E. tricolor to central Ecuador.
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The genus Gastrotheca has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
Atelopus onorei can be distinguished from other similar species by its colour patterns (Coloma et al. 2007).
Brock (1999) placed the species in the monospecific genus of Pseudobactricia of which it is the type species.

The type locality for Acisoma panorpoides ascalaphoides is Madagascar. It is not currently certain that the populations of Madagascar and mainland Africa are similar (K. Schütte in Dijkstra and Boudot 2010), so it is likely that the present subspecific name will have to change in the future for Africa.

This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List as Acisoma panorpoides ssp. ascalaphoides but it has now been promoted to Acisoma ascalaphoides.

DNA-based studies have shown that there are two genetic lineages within Sandelia bainsii; a southern lineage that is distributed in the Kowie, Great Fish and Keiskamma river systems, and a northern lineage that occurs in the Igoda and Buffalo river systems (Roos 2005, Chakona et al. unpublished. Samples from the Xulu and Nahoon river systems have not yet been analysed genetically. Morphological assessments and additional genetic analyses are being done to determine whether or not the northern and southern lineages of S. bainsii represent two distinct species. Both lineages will be included in this assessment, pending findings from the ongoing taxonomic evaluation of this species.
Formerly placed in family Bagridae, but recognized in a separate family by Mo (1991) and de Pinna (1998) (Nelson 2006).

Serranochromis robustus and Serranochromis jallae were previously considered to be subspecies of Serranochromis robustus. They are now both considered to be valid at the species level - this is therefore the more restricted concept of Serranochromis robustus, which was previously assessed at the subspecies level.

authority: Wood, Grismer, Grismer, Ahmad, Chan & Bauer, 2009
Grismer, Quah, Wood, Anuar, Muin, Davis, Murdoch, Grismer & Cota, 2016
Grismer, Quah, Wood, Anuar, Muin, Davis, Murdoch, Grismer & Cota, 2016
Chan, Grismer, Anuar, Quah, Muin, Savage, Grismer, Ahmad, Remigio & Greer, 2010
Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Riyanto, Ahmad, Muin, Sumontha, Grismer, Chan, Quah & Pauwels, 2014
taxonomicNotes: Cnemaspis temiah was described based on a population of Cnemaspis from the Cameron Highlands that was long recognized but previously considered to belong to C. flavolineata (Grismer et al. 2014).

It must be noted that P. capensis formerly belonged to the genus Barbus, but following the work of Yang et al. (2015), Pseudobarbus was expanded to include additional species resulting in the renaming of the Breede-Berg River whitefish to ‘Pseudobarbus’ capensis (Skelton 2016). These nomenclatural changes were made because the type specimen on which the name Barbus capensis was based was re-identified as the Cape Whitefish or Witvis, and not the Clanwilliam Yellowfish, as previously thought (Skelton 2016). The name ‘Pseudobarbus’ capensis (Smith, 1841) for the Berg-Breede whitefish is in tune with the generic alignment of Yang et al. (2015).

It must be noted that 'Pseudobarbus' erubescens formerly belonged to the genus Barbus, but following the work of Yang et al. (2015), the genus Pseudobarbus was expanded to include additional species resulting in the renaming of the Twee River redfin to ‘Pseudobarbus’ erubescens (Skelton 2016).

The relationships between isolated populations of this species and between this species and other chubby head minnows (Enteromius anoplus) needs investigation. It must be noted that Enteromius gurneyi formerly belonged to the genus Barbus, but following the work of Yang et al. (2015) it has been changed to Enteromius (Skelton  2016).

It must be noted that Enteromius treurensis formerly belonged to the genus Barbus, but following the work of Yang et al. (2015), the genus Enteromius was expanded to include additional species resulting in the renaming of the Enteromius treurensis (Skelton 2016).

Most recently, Yang et al. (2015) proposed that the genus Pseudobarbus should be expanded to include all tetraploid cyprinines from southern Africa. This suggestion was accepted pending a critical evaluation of the generic status of these additional tetraploid species (Skelton 2016). Barbus trevelyani is one of the species that had been transferred to the genus “Pseudobarbus” (Skelton 2016). Skelton et al. (2018) subsequently erected a new genus, Amatolacypris, and transferred “Pseudobarbus” trevelyani to this genus. Amatolacypris trevelyani was described from the Buffalo River System, with its distribution extending into the neighbouring Keiskamma River System. However, Ellender (2013) uncovered species level genetic divergences between the Buffalo population (Amatolacypris trevelyani sensu stricto) and the Keiskamma population (hereafter Amatolacypris ‘trevelyani sp. Keiskamma’). These two lineages will thus be assessed separately. This assessment is on Amatolacypris trevelyani sensu stricto.

Smith (1841) described the first redfin species as Barbus (Pseudobarbus) burchelli, but the origin of the specimens that were used for this description is unknown, and no type material exists (Barnard 1943). When Skelton (1988) defined a monophyletic redfin genus, he raised Pseudobarbus to full genetic status and assigned a specimen from the Tradouw catchment as the neotype for P. burchelli. For two decades following Skelton’s (1988) revision, redfins from the Breede and three adjacent river systems (Heuningnes, Duiwenhoks and Goukou) were all considered to belong to Pseudobarbus burchelli (Skelton 2001). Subsequently, DNA-based studies by Swartz et al. (2009) and Chakona et al. (2013) revealed existence of four genetically distinct lineages within P. burchelli (referred to as Pseudobarbus sp. ‘burchelli Giant’, Pseudobarbus sp. ‘burchelli Tradouw’,  Pseudobarbus sp. ‘burchelli Breede’, and Pseudobarbus sp. ‘burchelli Heuningnes’). The Giant Redfin was described as a distinct species, Pseudobarbus skeltoni (Chakona & Swartz, 2013). There are ongoing investigations to determine the taxonomic integrity of the other three lineages of P. burchelli. If these lineages are found to constitute novel species, the name P. burchelli will become restricted to the Tradouw lineage (due to designation of the neotype from this river), the Heuningnes lineage will require a new name, and one of the three synonyms of P. burchelli may need to be re-validated for the widespread Breede lineage. Pending further taxonomic investigation, the Tradouw lineage is being provisionally designated as P. burchelli sensu stricto. This assessment is therefore only based on the Tradouw population.
The Verlorenvlei population of this species had been described as a new species Pseudobarbus verloreni (Chakona et al. 2014)

Pseudobarbus quathlambae was originally described by Barnard (1938) based on specimens that were collected from the uMkomaas River System in KwaZulu Natal Province of South Africa. The species had not been recorded from South Africa since the original specimens were collected from the type locality in 1938, until a recent survey led to the rediscovery of this species in the uMzimkhulu River System which is adjacent to the uMkomaas River system (Kubheka et al., 2017). Previous and ongoing genetic analyses have revealed the existence of three genetic lineages within P. quathlambae (Swartz 2005, Swartz et al. unpublished data). Detailed morphological assessment are being done to determine whether these lineages constitute separate taxonomic entities.

The population of the cryptic Silhouettea sibayi seems to be restricted to the upper part of Maputaland in KwaZulu-Natal (Lakes Sibaya, Kosi (KwaZulu-Natal (KZN), South Africa) and Piti (Mozambique)) with evidence that populations may extend south towards the aMatikulu and Thukela River with unconfirmed anecdotal observations from KwaZulu-Natal Ezemvelo Wildlife collections. Potential relationships between similar gobies within Maputaland and larger KZN are still unknown.

Undescribed but clearly different from specimens collected near the type locality for K. auriculata in Mozambique (voucher specimen held by the South African Institute of Aquatic Biodiversity (SAIAB)). The Kneria sp. nov. 'South Africa' population exists in a small geographic range near Lydenberg, Mpumalanga, South Africa.
Work in progress (Bloomer et al.) suggests that Chiloglanis do not migrate very much. An analysis of population structuring would be valuable to nature conservators when developing managements plans.

Listed in Skelton (2001) as occurring as two distinct populations. The southern population occurs in the Incomati and Phongolo Rivers in South Africa (KwaZulu-Natal and Mpumalanga) and Swaziland. The northern population occurs around the Pungwe and lower Zambezi Rivers, Zimbabewe. These two populations are considered as two distinct species and only the southern population is assessed here. Chiloglanis emarginatus was described from the Incomati River System near Carolina, South Africa and so the southern population is assessed as this species.
This species is very similar to Liolaemus wiegmanni, and it has been suggested the two taxa may be conspecific (Etheridge 2000).
Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Craig and Hastings (2007) consider Epinephelus albomarginatus to be a member of the genus Mycteroperca.
There is some genetic evidence that suggests there is a cryptic species in the Red Sea (K. Yan Ma pers. comm. 2016).
Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Craig and Hastings (2007) consider the species Epinephelus marginatus to be a member of genus Mycteroperca.
A recent publication changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus (Craig and Hastings 2007) and a change of family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007).
Epinephelus bruneus was recently split into two species, the other being a former synonym of E. bruneus: E. moara (Liu et al. 2013).
The species was placed in a new genus, Wollastonaria, by De Mattia et al. (2018a,b).
The species was placed in a new genus, Wollastonaria, by De Mattia et al. (2018a,b).

Rousettus obliviosus was previously considered to be a subspecies of R. madagascariensis (e.g., Peterson et al. 1995), but the two forms have been shown to be distinct species (Kock 1978, Goodman et al. 2010a).

The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (2003) ruled that the name for this wild species is not invalid by virtue of being antedated by the name based on the domestic form. Therefore, IUCN considers the wild species of yak under Bos mutus, while the domestic form is considered under Bos grunniens (see Gentry et al. 1996).

Grubb (2005) lists mutus as a subspecies of grunniens, contrary to most authors.

authority: D. Holyoak, G. Holyoak, Yanes, Santana, García, Castro, Artiles, Alonso & Ibáñez, 2014
taxonomicNotes: The genus Vermetum was moved from Gastrodontidae to Pristilomatidae (Holyoak et al. 2014).
This is a polymorphic species that presents different morphotypes adapted to aquatic or terrestrial environments (Cuello et al. 2008).
The species Zeuneriana amplipennis occurs in the eastern Balkans. As the species is morphologically quite similar to Z. marmorata, the status of both species needs to be studied.

authority: Grismer, Belabut, Quah, Chan, Wood & Hasim, 2014

taxonomicNotes: There is unpublished morphological and genetic data suggesting that the Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Islands populations represent distinct species (R. Bray unpubl. data). Until this work is formally published, this account retains the traditional concept of Oligosoma lichenigerum.

The typical subspecies Aprasia rostrata rostrata was listed previously on the IUCN Red List, but as the other subspecies A. r. fusca Storr, 1979 is now recognized as a good species, the typical subspecies now becomes a full species.

The taxonomic history of Cyrtodactylus pulchellus is summarized by Grismer et al. (2016). This species was described from Pulau Penang based on a small number of characters by Cantor (1847), and the name was subsequently widely applied for populations on nearby islands and the Malay Peninsula (Grismer et al. 2016). Over the past decade, subpopulations outside Penang have been described as distinct species (summarized in Grismer et al. 2016), restricting C. pulchellus sensu stricto to this island.

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Quah, Muin, Mohamed, Chan, Sumarli, Loredo & Heinz, 2014
Grismer, Wood, Quah, Anuar, Muin, Sumontha, Ahmad, Bauer, Wangkulangkul, Grismer & Pauwels, 2012
Cobos, Grismer, Wood, Quah, Anuar & Muin, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Harvengia vietnamita is a remarkable blind species, very isolated phyletically, for which the genus Harvengia and the subtribe Harvengina has been erected (Ferrer 2004). It has therefore to be considered as one of the most remarkable endemic species of Hon Chong, and a major issue regarding biodiversity conservation. Further taxonomic analyses are needed to decide if the subpopulation in the northern hills are distinct of those from the southern hill from where holotype was described. For now they are considered the same species.

Currently this species belongs to the genus Chamalycaeus. A taxonomic revision of the family Alycaeidae is currently underway, which may result in C. micronus being moved to an independent genus (B. Páll-Gergely pers. comm. 2016).

Currently this species belongs to the genus Chamalycaeus. A taxonomic revision of the family Alycaeidae is currently underway, which may result in C. micronus being moved to an independent genus (B. Páll-Gergely pers. comm 2016).

The Bonobo is also known as the Gracile Chimpanzee; formerly it was known as Pygmy Chimpanzee and Dwarf Chimpanzee. Population genetics suggest that Bonobos have a stable population history (Eriksson et al. 2004, Schubert et al. 2013), and that gene flow between populations is constrained by the larger riverine barriers (although Bonobos regularly enter water, they do not swim).

authority: Grismer, Huat, Siler, Chan, Wood, Grismer, Sah & Ahmad, 2011

taxonomicNotes:
According to genetic analyses, nine subspecies are recognized, with all continental African Leopards attributable to the nominate form, P. p. pardus (Miththapala et al. 1996, Uphyrkina et al. 2001).

UAE Taxonomic Note
Leopards occurring in the Arabian Peninsula, including the UAE, are traditionally considered to be the Arabian Leopard Panthera pardus nimr Hemprich & Ehrenberg, 1833 (Harrison and Bates 1991) which is much smaller and lighter in weight than other leopards.

Populations that may be referrable to this species have been found in the southeast and central Arnhem scarp (Oliver and Parkin 2014, P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). The known specimens from these localities exhibit a degree of morphological differentiation from Strophurus horneri, and molecular data is required to confirm their identity (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). Pending further taxonomic work these records are excluded from this assessment.

The species status needs to be revisited (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). It exhibits very low genetic divergence and few morphological differences from two species occurring in nearby areas (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017).

Acanthodrilus kermadecensis Lee, 1953: 50, Pl. 5 figs. 1-3; 1959: 37, fig. 11; Easton, 1984: 120; Blakemore, 2004:  177; 2008; 2010: 54; 2012: 127.

Holotype was in the Soil Bureau collection now in the Molluscs (sic) section of Te Papa Museum as W.000548.  However, there is a slight discrepancy in that Lee (1953: 49) said only three specimens were collected, yet Lee (1959: 38) lists three syntypes in addition to holotype (= 4).  None of these specimens has been subsequently inspected.

Although it shares the definitive J-shaped nephridial bladders with other holoic, acantodriline members of the genus found in New Caledonia, it is unusual in its saddle-shaped clitellum, more ventral nephridoipores, lack of tufted nephridia and spermathecal diverticula that are clavate rather than intramural and/or multi-loculate [cf. the only other congeneric NZ taxon Acanthodrilus ravus (Lee, 1959) from Three Kings Islands as recently new combination by Blakemore (2012)].

Lee (1959: 254) listed it as Octochaetus microchaetus "incertae sedis" (of uncertain status) although it was included in checklists by Blakemore (2004, 2008, 2010, 2012).   Benham's original 1950 paper is online here - http://rsnz.natlib.govt.nz/volume/rsnz_78/rsnz_78_02_003870.html (December, 2016).

Slapcinsky and Krause (2016) compared Partula calypso, P. leucothoe and P. thetis to their newly described genus and species Sphendone insolita, and to other partulids and found that these three species require their own genus because their morphology is quite different from that of true Partula and from that of all other genera. Therefore, they resurrected the genus Palaopartula Pilsbry for these three snails.

Slapcinsky and Krause (2016) compared Partula calypso, P. leucothoe and P. thetis to their newly described genus and species Sphendone insolita, and to other partulids and found that these three species require their own genus because their morphology is quite different from that of true Partula and from that of all other genera. Therefore, they resurrected the genus Palaopartula Pilsbry for these three snails.

Slapcinsky and Krause (2016) compared Partula calypso, P. leucothoe and P. thetis to their newly described genus and species Sphendone insolita, and to other partulids and found that these three species require their own genus because their morphology is quite different from that of true Partula and from that of all other genera. Therefore, they resurrected the genus Palaopartula Pilsbry for these three snails.

The taxonomy of this species has been disputed over the years. It was reclassified as Partula jackieburchi and then as Partula otaheitana rubescens by Johnson, Murray and Clarke (1986). Gerlach (2016) placed it in Partula.
This is a newly discovered (2006) species, described as Samoana meyeri the following year (Burch 2007). The species was placed in genus Partula in 2016 (Gerlach 2016).
As noted in its type description, this species is superficially similar to D. forsteri (Lee, 1959) with which it may be confused by novices; only dissection and DNA can separate taxa.
Similar species are discussed in the original description (Blakemore,  2010) and by Blakemore (2012), but its taxonomic and phylogenetic  relationships depend upon further DNA analyses.
The species is currently divided into two sub-species that differ only slightly, but both anatomically and gentically.

This species was unambigously defined when Blakemore (2010) tied morphology of its name-bearing holotype to its DNA barcode from a tissue sample, as per Blakemore et al. (2010).  Nevertheless, it yet requires comparison with all congeners.

Closest taxonomic affinites are indicated in Blakemore (2010, 2011, 2012).

DNA is available for this species which would confim its identity and relationships with other taxa within its eleven congeners (see Blakemore, 2012).  The closest taxonomic and toopical association unsurprisingly appears with Deinodrilus gorgon Blakemore, 2010 from the same type-locality.

Megascolex species from Australia and New Zealand are now placed in the genus Anisochaeta (Blakemore 2010).

The holotype redescription by Blakemore (2011) found spermathecal diverticula and dorsal pores to actually be present but a lack of genital markings (cf. Lee, 1959). This large species (20 cm long) was transferred from Megascolex to Benham’s (1890) overlooked genus Anisochaeta by Blakemore (2004, 2008).

The specific name is likely from “animae” (Latin f. pl.) meaning “spirits” as in Spirits Bay, or “winds”, but in either case as a noun in apposition does not require gender agreement.
Megascolex species from Australia and New Zealand are now placed in the genus Anisochaeta (Blakemore 2010).

Michaelsen's contemporary, Ude (1905) thought his species Notoscolex unipapillatus may be the same as T. orthostichon but this was disputed by Blakemore (2012) and by current studies (Blakemore, unpublished).  Of note is that the revision based on types by Michaelsen (1917) did not mention this similarity and showed the male pores to be radically different, both to M. unipapillatus and to Lee’s (1962) revision of London specimens of “Megascolides orthostichon” that Blakemore (2014) showed was T. maorica (see Blakemore 2014 fig. 12 comparisons with Benham’s original figures).  Lee (1962) was seemingly unaware of Michaelsen’s (1917) revision and also missed his own (Lee 1959) review as another apparently significant difference is the spermathecal pores being segmental in T. maorica rather than intersegmental as in T. unipapillata.  For T. orthostichon the spermathecal pore location was given by Lee (1959) as in 7/8/9 the same as T. unipapillatus but – as already noted – Michaelsen (1917) found the male pores and markings, at least, to differ conclusively for these two taxa.

Hypogaeon orthostichon Schmarda (1861) was the first native earthworm formally described from Australasia.  It was collected from Maunga Rei / Mount Wellington in Auckland, New Zealand by Ludwig Karl Schmarda sometime over a five week period of his visit in 1854.
This species was reviewed by Benham (1905), Michaelsen (1917), Lee (1959) and Blakemore (2000, 2008, 2012) with new combination in Tokea by Blakemore (2014).
Although the description of Tokea orthostichon (Schmarda, 1861) was basic, and partly in Latin, it was standard orthodoxy for the time and quite adequate for this species that Schmarda collected at Maunga Rei / Mount Wellington in 1854 as part of a world tour.

Ude (1905) thought his species may be the same as T. orthostichon (Schmarda, 1861) but this was disputed by Blakemore (2000, 2012) and by the current study (Blakemore, unpublished).  Of note is that a revision based on types by Michaelsen (1917) did not mention this similarity and showed the male pores to be radically different, both to T. unipapillatus and to Lee’s (1962) revision of “Megascolides orthostichon” that Blakemore (2014) thought was T. maorica (see Blakemore 2014 fig. 12 comparisons with Benham’s original figures).  Seemingly, Lee (1962) was unaware of Michaelsen’s (1917) revision and also missed his own (Lee 1959) review as another apparently significant difference is the spermathecal pores being segmental in T. maorica rather than intersegmental as in T. unipapillata.

For T. orthostichon the spermathecal pore location was given by Lee (1959) as 7/8/9 the same as T. unipapillatus but, as already noted, Michaelsen (1917) found the male pores and markings, at least, to differ conclusively for these two taxa.



An alleged “Megascolides ?unipapillatus (WM11)” report by non-specialists has DNA similar or identical with several other “species” including “Megascolides repans (WM10)” (online at: doi:10.1016/j.ympev.2010.09.024 - as was noted by Blakemore 2010, 2011, 2012).  Most likely either/or both are actually of T. maorica which Edwards (1954) and Lee (1959) had already recorded from Little Barrier Island more than 50 years ago as also noted by Reid et al. (1982).  Further directed eco-taxonomic study by specialists is requried with recourse to DNA as per Blakemore et al. (2010), Blakemore (2010, 2016).
Tamias bulleri is recognized under the genus Neotamias (Patterson and Norris 2016).

This species was revised by Wang et al. (1993). It is a well-defined species sharply distinct from the parapatric or marginally sympatric M. chrysogaster; see Grubb (1982).

Four subspecies are recognized by Grubb (2005):
M. b. berezovskii Flerov, 1929; Sichuan, Qinghai, Tibet
M. b. bjiangensis Wang & Li, 2003; northwestern Yunnan;
M. b. caobangis Dao, 1969; Yunnan, Guangxi, Guangdong, northern Viet Nam;
M. b. yunguiensis Wang & Ma, 1993; Yunnan-Guizhou highland, Hunan, Jiangxi; Wang (2003) lists an unnamed form as occurring in south Gansu, Ningxia, south Shaanxi, west Hubei and west Henan (Wang et al. 1993); Wemmer (1998).

Moschus anhuiensis has in the past been included in this species (Yang et al. 2003); it is still not clear whether or not the recognized subspecies are really part of this species. The subspecies M. b. caobangis is a good candidate for separate species status, but this has never been looked at (J.W. Duckworth pers. comm.). Until recently the Viet Namese population was considered to be M. moschiforus by Russian scientists (much literature follows this; J.W. Duckworth pers. comm.).

The species was first described by Risso (1810) as Squalus ferox from the type locality at Nice and most early records were from the Mediterranean and eastern North Atlantic. Whitley (1950) described O. herbsti from southeastern Australia, differentiating it from O. ferox mainly on differences in dental formulae, and the absence of pigment spots. Garrick's (1974) account of two specimens from New Zealand cast doubt on any differences in dentition between the species but retained O. herbsti for the plain-coloured Odontaspis.

However, Compagno (1984) reviewed the two species and considered that O. herbsti was a junior synonym of O. ferox, noting (as did Robins et al. 1980) that the presence or absence of spots was highly variable, much as with Carcharias taurus. The existence of spotted specimens outside the Mediterranean Sea, including from California (Seigel and Compagno 1986), is supported by in-situ observations made off Lebanon, New Zealand and Malpelo Island (Columbia), where specimens exhibit considerable variability in the presence, density and size of spots. There may be some regionalised trends controlling the intensity of such pigmentation. In the absence of any further evidence to support the validity of an O. ferox/O. herbsti dichotomy, recognition of the single Odontaspis ferox of Risso, as previously argued by Compagno (1984, 2001), remains valid.
Cryptotettix macrophthalmus probably belongs to the genus Rhynchotettix (H. Devriese pers. comm. 2016).

Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

Published records of  Pseudobatos percellens in southern Brazil (Chao et al. 1982 in Vooren et al. 2005) are due to problems with one of the criteria used for separating P. horkelii and P. percellens. From measurements of only four specimens (two juveniles of P. percellens and two juveniles of P. horkelii, all from Rio de Janeiro), Bigelow and Schroeder (1953) used the relative size of the nasal groove as a diagnostic criterion for separating P. horkelii and P. percellens. However, the value of this morphometric measurement as stated by Bigelow and Schroeder (1953) does not permit the correct identification of specimens of all sizes and from all areas where these species occur. All 9,853 specimens of Rhinobatos from southern Brazil examined according to other criteria described by Bigelow and Schroeder (1953) (adult body size and colour) since 1972 by Lessa (1982) and Sadowsky (1973) in Vooren et al. (2005) were P. horkelii. Therefore all fishery data for Rhinobatos from southern Brazil refer to P. horkelii (Vooren et al. 2005). This aspect of taxonomy and identification is important for the enforcement of laws for the protection of P. horkelii in Brazil.

The taxonomy of the 'whitespotted wedgefish' species-complex (which includes several Indo-West Pacific wedgefishes) is not fully resolved, and the status of the Taiwanese Wedgefish is in need of critical re-evaluation by comparing it to other regional species.

Erythropitta erythrogaster, E. inspeculata, E. caeruleitorques, E. palliceps, Erythropitta celebensis, E. rufiventris, E. rubrinucha, E. macklotii, E. meeki, E. gazellae, E. splendida and E. novaehibernicae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Pitta erythrogaster following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Erythropitta erythrogaster, E. inspeculata, E. caeruleitorques, E. palliceps, Erythropitta celebensis, E. rufiventris, E. rubrinucha, E. macklotii, E. meeki, E. gazellae, E. splendida and E. novaehibernicae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Pitta erythrogaster following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Erythropitta erythrogaster, E. inspeculata, E. caeruleitorques, E. palliceps, Erythropitta celebensis, E. rufiventris, E. rubrinucha, E. macklotii, E. meeki, E. gazellae, E. splendida and E. novaehibernicae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Pitta erythrogaster following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Erythropitta erythrogaster, E. inspeculata, E. caeruleitorques, E. palliceps, Erythropitta celebensis, E. rufiventris, E. rubrinucha, E. macklotii, E. meeki, E. gazellae, E. splendida and E. novaehibernicae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Pitta erythrogaster following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pitta sordida, P. novaeguineae and P. rosenbergii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. sordida following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Grallaria rufula and G. saltuensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. rufula following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Sclerurus scansor and S. cearensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. scansor following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Dendrocolaptes sanctithomae and D. punctipectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. sanctithomae following AOU (1998 & supplements) and SACC (2005 & updates).
Premnoplex tatei and P. pariae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. tatei following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).

Séret and McEachran (1986) tentatively synonymised Glaucostegus petiti (reported from the Western Indian Ocean) with G. cemiculus because the morphometrics and the meristics of the holotype and only known specimen of G. petiti fell into the ranges of variation of G. cemiculus. Glaucostegus cemiculus is an Eastern Atlantic species, however, and does not occur in the Western Indian Ocean from which G. petiti is reported (Bernard Séret pers. comm. 2008). It is possible that there was a mistake in the origin of the type specimen, although the collector Georges Petit did explore the Tuléar region of Madagasar. No further specimens of Glaucostegus petiti have been found to date, despite the presence of an active research station in Tuléar for decades, although other guitarfishes (Acroteriobatus annulatus and Rhinobatos holcorhynchus) have been collected from the region (Bernard Séret pers. comm. 2008).

Glaucostegus petiti is considered a synonym of G. cemiculus (William T. White and David A. Ebert pers. comm. 2016).

Asthenes dorbignyi. A. arequipae, A. usheri and A. huancavelicae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. dorbignyi following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Gerygone magnirostris and G. hypoxantha (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. magnirostris following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Lalage leucomela and L. conjuncta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. leucomela following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyanolanius madagascarinus and C. comorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. madagascarinus following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Symposiachrus verticalis and S. ateralbus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Monarcha verticalis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Petroica macrocephala and P. dannefaerdi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. macrocephala following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993), Turbott (1990).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Hypsipetes parvirostris and H. moheliensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. parvirostris following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Phylloscopus poliocephalus and P. makirensis (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped and subsequently split into P. poliocephalus, P. misoriensis and P. maforensis following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).

Phylloscopus poliocephalus and P. makirensis (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped and subsequently split into P. poliocephalus, P. misoriensis and P. maforensis following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).
Poodytes punctatus and P. caudatus (del Hoyo and Collar   2016) were previously lumped as Bowdleria punctata following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Turbott (1990).
Zosterops conspicillatus and Z. saypani (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. conspicillatus following Slikas et al. (2000).
Mixornis flavicollis and M. prillwitzi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Macronous flavicollis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. The two western Atlantic species (F. colarensis and F. geijskesi) differ significantly from the other taxa in this genus and may prove to be non-congeneric with the four species from western African (Last et al. 2016).

This species is often mistaken with Hypanus guttatus but snout length and pelvic fin shape differ.
Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon.

Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon.

Former records of Dasyatis (=Fontitrygon) margarita have included misidentified specimens of as the smaller sympatric species, F. margaritella. Both species are still mixed in landing statistics.
Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon.

Last et al. (2016) placed Himantura kittipongi, H. oxyrhyncha, and H. signifer within their newly described genus Fluvitrygon.

This species was submitted to The IUCN Red List in 2000 as H. oxyrhyncha, but it was noted as H. oxyrhynchus in Eschmeyer and on FishBase. L. Compagno comments "as a noun in apposition to the generic name, the original spelling oxyrhynchus can be retained". But, more recent correspondence from the IUCN SSC Shark Specialist Group (SSG) states that the species should be oxyrhyncha and not oxyrhynchus (Pete Kyne in litt. 2004). M. Kottelat (pers. comm. 2011) commented that oxyrhynchus is the correct spelling, which conforms to the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature in his opinion, based on rules for the formation of complex nouns.

W. White (pers. comm. 2011; SSG) expressed the opinion that, 'given the genus name this [the -a ending] makes sense unless it was named as a noun in apposition which it mustn’t have been.'
Last et al. (2016) placed Himantura kittipongi, H. oxyrhyncha, and H. signifer within their newly described genus Fluvitrygon.

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, consisting of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including gerrardi).

Reports of the species are often confused with Himantura uarnak (e.g., Chaudhuri 1911, Devanesen and Chidambaram 1953, Mohsin and Ambak 1996).
Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, consisting of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including pastinacoides).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including fai).

This species is frequently misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) jenkinsii.
Hylocitrea bonensis and H. bonthaina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. bonensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including hortlei).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including jenkinsii).

This species has probably been misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) fai in the literature (W. White pers. obs). More specimens of both this species and of H. draco from South Africa need to be examined to resolve the taxonomic status of this species. Presently, H. draco is considered a synonym of P. jenkinsii. The South African species had dark spots along the posterior margin of the disc, but this form has also been reported from the Arafura Sea and off Sumatra in Indonesia. It is possible that these may in fact be colour forms of the same species. Examples of specimens with dark spots along the posterior margin of the disc are from the Arafura Sea, Sumatra (Last and Stevens 1994, Fahmi pers. obs. 2007), and from western Sri Lanka (Morón et al. 1998, Manjaji 2004), and the Sulu Sea (B.M. Manjaji-Matsumoto pers. obs. 2002).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including uarnacoides). Previously on The IUCN Red List, bleekeri was treated as a junior synonym of uarnacoides (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007). However Pateobatis bleekeri is considered a valid species by Last et al. (2016).

This species is misidentified for Himantura lobiostoma, Pateobatis hortlei and Maculabatis pastinacoides (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007).
Hemignathus lucidus, H. hanapepe and H. affinis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. lucidus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pyrrhula nipalensis and P. waterstradti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. nipalensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Arremon torquatus, A. costaricensis, A. assimilis, A. basilicus, A. perijanus, A. atricapillus, A. phaeopleurus and A. phygas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. torquatus following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates).

Arremon torquatus, A. costaricensis, A. assimilis, A. basilicus, A. perijanus, A. atricapillus, A. phaeopleurus and A. phygas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. torquatus following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates).

Zosterops poliogastrus, Z. kaffensis, Z. kulalensis, Z. kikuyuensis, Z. silvanus, Z. eurycricotus, Z. mbuluensis and Z. winifredae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. poliogastrus following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
