Formerly a monotypic genus (containing only U. asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) added five more species to Urogymmus, including U. granulatus.

Formerly a monotypic genus (containing only Urogymnus asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) added five more large to very large species to Urogymmus, including lobistomus.

This species is probably misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) uarnacoides and Himantura (=Pateobatis) hortlei (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007).

Formerly a monotypic genus (containing only Urogymnus asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) added five more large to very large species to Urogymmus, including polylepis.

Himantura chaophraya was described in 1990 from Thailand, but it did not take into account the description by Bleeker in 1852 of Himantura (=Urogymnus) polylepis. Last and Manjaji-Matsumoto (2008) compared material from the holoytpe of polylepis (Java, Indonesia) with material from the Chao Phraya (Thailand), Sabah (Malaysia) and from India confirmed that polylepis is the senior name.

In the recent description of U. dalyensis from Australia (formerly thought to be chaophraya but considered to be restricted to Australia and possibly New Guinea and Papua New Guinea; W. White pers. comm. 2011, P. Last pers. comm. 2011), Last and Manjaji-Matsumoto (2008), clarified that polylepis (the type locality for which is in Java, Indonesia) is a senior synonym and recognised this as the valid species name, thus making H. chaophraya a junior synonym.

This species requires further taxonomic research and it is possible that populations in the Mekong and other drainages may also pertain to other species (W. Rainboth, pers. comm). Significant differences in the DNA and amino acid sequences were found between Thai and Indian specimens (Sezaki et al. 1999, see Martin 2005), suggesting evolutionary divergence between subpopulations.

Last et al. (2016) placed Himantura kittipongi, H. oxyrhyncha, and H. signifer within their newly described genus Fluvitrygon.

This species is similar to F. signifer.
Rhipidura cyaniceps, R. sauli and R. albiventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. cyaniceps following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

One of two Malaysian syntypes of Calotes floweri, taken from Gunung Tahan (Boulenger 1912), was assigned as the holotype of the new species Pseudocalotes dringi by Hallermann and Böhme (2000). The other appears to have been lost (Hallermann and Böhme 2000) but presumably also represents P. dringi. A record of P. floweri (Boulenger, 1912) from Kon Tum Province by Bain et al. (2007) was re-assigned to P. ziegleri by Hallermann et al. (2010).

As presently understood both species co-occur in this area, and molecular research is required to clarify taxonomic boundaries within both species (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Botov, Phung, Nguyen, Bauer, Brennan & Ziegler, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Taxonomic research is recommended to clarify the relationship between this species and Gekko thakhakhensis, which was described from the same area (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Luu, Calame, Nguyen, Le, Bonkowski & Ziegler, 2014
taxonomicNotes: Taxonomic research is recommended to clarify the relationship between this species and Gekko bonkowskii, which was described from the same area (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).
Proposed taxonomic revisions would place this species and other North American skinks in the genus Plestiodon (Brandley et al. 2005).

Boophis brachychir is sometimes confused with Boophis madagascariensis and was removed from synonymy with it by Glaw and Vences (1992). Subsequently, Glaw et al. (2010) removed Boophis entingae from synonymy with B. brachychir.

While Amiet (2012) considers this species to be a synonym of Hyperolius tuberculatus which is followed by Frost (2016), we are following expert consensus (R. Bell and S. Lötters pers. comm. November 2016) that it should be maintained as a separate species pending further taxonomic study.

Several recent molecular studies have provided support for a monophyletic assemblage of South American endemic canids (Lindblad-Toh et al. 2005, Perini et al. 2010), with Chrysocyon and Speothos forming a sister-clade to the monophyletic south American foxes and Atelocynus. On the basis of morphology, Zunino et al. (1995) reviewed previous work and also supported clustering species within the two previous paraphyletic genera (Pseudalopex, Lycalopex) into a single monophyletic genus. They further argued that Lycalopex had priority over Pseudalopex, subsequently also supported by Zrzavý et al. (2004: 324). The only outstanding question would have been whether Dusicyon would have been a more appropriate name, since Perini et al. (2010) reported a close relationship between L. culpaeus and Dusicyon. However, we now know that Dusicyon is far outside this clade (Slater et al. 2009, Austin et al. 2013). Based on this evidence, the genus Lycalopex is used over Pseudalopex for all South American foxes, following Wozencraft's (2005) earlier treatment.
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).

Populations in Serra da Canastra could pertain to a different taxon (R. Brandão pers. comm. 2008).

This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

Amietophrynus has been synonymised with Sclerophrys, and as a result all species that were previously in the former genus are now known under Sclerophrys (Ohler and Dubois 2016).

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. It was described as a subspecies of Amietophrynus funereus (Hulselmans 1977), and was considered a distinct species by Joger (1982) and Böhme and Schneider (1987). J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers that it is a junior synonym of Amietophrynus villiersi, an opinion not shared by U. Joger (pers. comm.).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

A recent revision of the genus Atlantica by Cameron et al. (2013) based on shell characters and genital anatomy, promoted the transfer of this genus from Discidae to Gastrodontidae (Gastropoda: Pulmunata). Furthermore, the former taxon Discus guerinianus subsp. calathoides (Lowe, 1863) becomes Atlantica calathoides (Lowe, 1863) according to this revision.
This is a distinct taxon related to the D. oxytropis group, with one further extant taxon and several fossil species. It is recognised on size, morphology and distribution.

The species may belong to another genus (Gorochov 2016). As the record from Mt. Kalulong is based upon a female specimen (which are more difficult to distinguish), confirmation of its presence should be confirmed based upon a male specimen.

The genus Saussurella is in need of a taxonomic revision as the intraspecific variability in some traits that have been used in species descriptions is not well documented. It is possible that Saussurella acuticornis is a junior synonym of Saussurella decurva (J. Skejo, pers. comm. 2018).
This species might belong to the genus Liara, subgenus Acanthocoryphus (S. Ingrisch 2018, pers. comm.).
This species may represent a species complex (D. Rentz, pers. comm. 2018). Therefore, more taxonomic work is needed.

Africa was previously thought to be represented by a single galaxiid species, the Cape Galaxias Galaxias zebratus (Barnard 1943, Skelton 2001). The Cape Galaxias was considered to be a widespread and morphologically variable species, with a distribution range extending from the Gamtoos River system in the eastern Cape Fold Ecoregion (CFE) to the Verlorenvlei River system on the west coast of South Africa (Waters and Cambray 1997, Skelton 2001), making it the second most widely distributed freshwater fish species in the CFE. The use of molecular markers to assess the level of genetic diversity within Galaxias zebratus uncovered several strongly diverged lineages within this species, indicating that the diversity of galaxiid fishes in Africa had been vastly underestimated (Chakona et al. 2013, Waters and Cambray 1997, Wishart et al. 2006). Fine scale geographic surveys conducted between 2008 and 2010 generated comprehensive data that allowed more accurate mapping of the distribution ranges of G. zebratus lineages in the south-western CFE (Chakona et al. 2013). Preliminary results from the ongoing taxonomic revision of G. zebratus indicate that many of these newly identified lineages constitute novel species (Chakona et al. in preparation). These lineages will therefore be assessed separately. This assessment is based only on the Breede lineage (hereafter Galaxias sp. nov. ‘Breede’) (Chakona et al. 2013). The other lineages of the Galaxias zebratus complex are excluded from this assessment.

Africa was previously thought to be represented by a single galaxiid species, the Cape Galaxias (Galaxias zebratus) (Barnard 1943, Skelton 2001). The Cape Galaxias was considered to be a widespread and morphologically variable species, with a distribution range extending from the Gamtoos River system in the eastern Cape Fold Ecoregion (CFE) to the Verlorenvlei River system on the west coast of South Africa (Waters and Cambray 1995, Skelton 2001), making it the second most widely distributed freshwater fish species in the CFE. The use of molecular markers to assess the level of genetic diversity within Galaxias zebratus uncovered several strongly diverged lineages within this species, indicating that the diversity of galaxiid fishes in Africa had been vastly underestimated (Waters and Cambray 1997, Wishart et al. 2006, Chakona et al. 2013). Fine scale geographic surveys conducted between 2008 and 2010 generated comprehensive data that allowed more accurate mapping of the distribution ranges of G. zebratus lineages in the south-western CFE (Chakona et al. 2013). Preliminary results from the ongoing taxonomic revision of G. zebratus indicate that many of these newly identified lineages constitute novel species (Chakona et al. in preparation). These lineages will therefore be assessed separately. This assessment is based only on the lineage that is endemic to the Goukou River system (hereafter Galaxias sp. nov ‘Goukou’). The other lineages of the Galaxias zebratus complex are excluded from this assessment.

The use of molecular markers to assess the level of genetic diversity within Galaxias zebratus uncovered several strongly diverged lineages within this species, indicating that the diversity of galaxiid fishes in Africa had been vastly underestimated (Waters & Cambray 1997, Wishart et al. 2006, Chakona et al. 2013). Preliminary results from the ongoing taxonomic revision of G. zebratus indicate that many of these newly identified lineages constitute novel species (Chakona et al. in preparation). These lineages will therefore be assessed separately. This assessment is based only on the lineage that is endemic to the Gouritz River System (hereafter Galaxias sp. nov ‘Gouritz’). The other lineages of the Galaxias zebratus complex are excluded from this assessment.

The Cape Galaxias was considered to be a widespread and morphologically variable species, with a distribution range extending from the Gamtoos River system in the eastern Cape Fold Ecoregion (CFE) to the Verlorenvlei River system on the west coast of South Africa (Waters and Cambray 1995, Skelton 2001), making it the second most widely distributed freshwater fish species in the CFE. The use of molecular markers to assess the level of genetic diversity within Galaxias zebratus uncovered several strongly diverged lineages within this species, indicating that the diversity of galaxiid fishes in Africa had been vastly underestimated (Waters and Cambray 1997, Wishart et al. 2006, Chakona et al. 2013). The taxonomic status of Southern Africa bulldogs was reviewed by Maake et al. (2014) and several new species were described. Marcusenius caudisquamatus was described for the southern most population known for mormyrids in Africa, from the Nseleni and Mhlatuze river systems in the KwaZulu-Natal Province, South Africa.

Pseudobarbus afer was previously considered to be the most widely distributed Redfin species in the Cape Fold Ecoregion of South Africa, with a distribution range spanning across more than 28 isolated river systems from the Sundays near Port Elizabeth to the Klein Braak which discharges into Mossel Bay (Skelton 1988). A genetic study by Swartz et al. (2007, 2009) revealed four deeply divergent taxonomic units: (i) the Mandela lineage (restricted to the Baakens, Swartkops and Sundays), (ii) the St Francis lineage (confined to the Gamtoos and adjacent river systems), (iii) the Krom lineage (endemic to the Krom River system), and, (iv) the Forest lineage (widely distributed from the Tsitsikamma to the Klein Brak River System). A subsequent comprehensive taxonomic review of P. afer  by Chakona & Skelton (2017) led to the resurrection of P. senticeps from synonymy with P. afer,  a description of a new species P. swartzi (St Francis lineage) and provision of new diagnosis for P. afer sensu stricto (Mandela lineage). Pseudobarbus afer is thus now confined to three river systems (Baakens, Swartkops and Sundays) that discharge into Nelson Mandela Bay (also known as Algoa Bay) (Chakona and Skelton 2017).

The Fiery Redfin (Psuedobarbus phlegethon) is a small cyprinid endemic to the Olifants-Doring River System (ODRS) of South Africa (Skelton 2001).  It occurs as two distinct taxa based on genetic differences noted by Swartz et al. (2004). These taxa are P. phlegethon (this assessment) which only occurs in tributaries in the Olifants River, and Pseudobarbus sp. nov. "Doring", which occurs in two tributaries of the Doring system. This species can be distinguished from the Doring lineage with allozyme loci and it does not share mitochondrial DNA alleles (Swartz et al. 2004). In addition there are consistent colour pattern differences as reported by Swartz et al. 2005. The Doring river lineage is awaiting formal description and is excluded from this assessment.

authority: Ahmadzadeh, Flecks, Carretero, Mozaffari, Böhme, Harris, Freitas & Rödder, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Anderson (1999) suggested that the population from Mazanderan in the valley of the Rud-e Atrak of the Kopet Dagh may prove to be a distinct taxon. This form has subsequently been described as the new species Darevskia kopetdaghica by Ahmadzadeh et al. (2013).

The taxonomic status of southern Africa bulldogs was reviewed by Maake et al. (2014) and several new species have been described. Maake et al. (2014) indicated variation of the Kosi population and that it could represent a new species, pending further investigation. In a follow up study of the analyses of the electric organ discharges, Kramer et al. (2016) indicated that Marcusenius pongolensis specimens from different locations (including Kosi Lake) showed a high degree of variability between each other. It is likely that M. pongolensis is a species complex and more species could be split. Recommendations includes in-depth study to describe the Kosi population as a new species (voucher specimen to be selected from specimens held by the South African Institute of Aquatic Biodiversity (SAIAB)).

Pseudobarbus senticeps was described by Smith (1936) as Barbus senticeps based on specimens that were collected from the Krom River System in the eastern Cape Fold Ecoregion of South Africa. Jubb (1965) subsequently placed P. senticeps into synonymy with Pseudobarbus afer (Peters 1864), a decision that was accepted by subsequent authors (Skelton, 1988, 2001; Cambray 1994). Most recently, Chakona and Skelton (submitted) resurrected P. senticeps from synonymy with P. afer based on evidence of substantial genetic divergence of the Krom lineage from other lineages within P. afer (Swartz et al. 2007, 2009) and careful examination of morphometric and meristic data. In this revision, Chakona and Skelton (submitted) provided a new diagnosis for P. afer sensu stricto and described a new species, Pseudobarbus swartzi. These three species which were previously included under one widespread species (P. afer sensu lato) are allopatrically distributed. Pseudobarbus senticeps is a narrow range endemic species which is restricted to the Krom River system, P. afer occurs in the Baakens, Swartkops and Sundays River systems, while P. swartzi occurs in the Gamtoos and adjacent river systems (Chakona and Skelton submitted).

For a long time, the Eastern Cape Redfin Pseudobarbus afer was considered to be the most widely distributed redfin species in the Cape Fold Ecoregion of South Africa, with a distribution range spanning across more than 28 isolated river systems from the Sundays near Port Elizabeth to the Klein Braak which discharges into Mossel Bay (Skelton, 1988). A genetic study by Swartz et al (2007, 2009) revealed four deeply divergent taxonomic units: (i) the Mandela lineage (restricted to the Baakens, Swartkops and Sundays), (ii) the St Francis lineage (confined to the Gamtoos and adjacent river systems), (iii) the Krom lineage (endemic to the Krom River system), and, (iv) the Forest lineage (widely distributed from the Tsitsikamma to the Klein Brak River system). Recently, Chakona and Skelton (2017) demonstrated that the Mandela, Krom and St Francis (Gamtoos) lineages can be separated based on scale counts, length of oral barbels and consistent differences in body colour pattern, supporting their status as distinct species. These authors described the St Francis lineage as a new species P. swartzi, resurrected P. senticeps (Smith, 1936) as a valid species (the Krom lineage), and re-described P. afer sensu stricto (Peters, 1864) (Mandela lineage). The Forest lineage is closely related to P. phlegethon from the Olifants River system on the west coast of South Africa, suggesting that it does not belong to P. afer sensu lato (Swartz et al. 2007, 2009; Chakona and Skelton 2017). The taxonomic status of the Forest lineage will be addressed in a further study that will incorporate the more closely related P. phlegethon. Here we assess Pseudobarbus swartzi.

Redfin minnows from the Verlorenvlei River System on the west coast of South Africa were previously included within the Berg River Redfin Pseudobarbus burgi (Barnard 1943, Skelton 1988). The historical distribution of P. burgi sensu lato included the Langvlei, Verlorenvlei, Berg and Eerste River systems (Skelton 1988). A DNA based study (mitochondrial control region) by Bloomer and Impson (2000) revealed substantial genetic differentiation between redfins from the Berg and Verlorenvlei River systems, indicating existence of cryptic diversity within P. burgi. The differentiation between the Berg and Verlorenvlei lineages of P. burgi was confirmed by Swartz et al. (2009) and Chakona and Swartz (2013) based on mitochondrial cytochrome b sequences. Chakona et al. (2014) subsequently described the Verlorenvlei River Redfin as a distinct species, Pseudobarbus verloreni, and identified consistent morphological characters to separate this new species from P. burgi.

Most recently, Yang et al. (2015) proposed that the genus Pseudobarbus should be expanded to include all tetraploid cyprinines from southern Africa. This suggestion has been accepted pending a critical evaluation of the generic status of these additional tetraploid species (Skelton 2016). Barbus trevelyani is one of the species that has been transferred to the genus Pseudobarbus (Skelton 2016). Pseudobarbus trevelyani was described from the Buffalo River system, with its distribution extending into the neighbouring Keiskamma River system. However, Ellender (2013) uncovered species level genetic divergences between the Buffalo population (Pseudobarbus trevelyani sensu stricto) and the Keiskamma population (hereafter Pseudobarbus sp. nov. 'Keiskamma'). These two lineages will thus be assessed separately.

Both the provenance and the identity of three records of this species, from Woodleigh Station, have been questioned. These were reported from "limestone uplands with Acacia grasbyi scrub" in 1997 by Aplin et al. (unpublished), who noted that the specimens did not differ in size, characters or patterning from southern populations. Subsequent visits to the area have reported no limestone upland habitats in this area and tissue samples appear to have gone missing (G. Gaikhorst pers. comm. 2017). Genetic analysis is recommended should the specimens be recovered or additional records obtained from the Woodleigh locality (Alpin et al. unpublished, G. Gaikhorst and M. Cowan pers. comm. 2017).

Molecular, morphological and ecological work soon to be published has demonstrated that the Victorian and New South Wales populations of Liopholis guthega represent different species (Z. Atkins in prep.)

This species, as well as closely related ones, were formerly included in the Parathelphusidae, but have recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae, since Parathelphusidae Alcock, 1910 is now regarded a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae Rathbun, 1904 (Klaus et al. 2006, Organisms, Diversity & Evolution 6: 199–217). Occasionally, the Parathelphusinae are now used as a valid subfamily within the Gecarcinucidae (e.g. Klaus et al. 2010, BMC Evolutionary Biology 10:287).

This and related species were formerly included in the Parathelphusidae, but have recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae, since Parathelphusidae Alcock, 1910 is regarded a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae Rathbun, 1904 (Klaus et al. 2006). Occasionally, the Parathelphusinae are now used as a valid subfamily within the Gecarcinucidae (e.g. Klaus et al. 2010).

This and related species were formerly included in the Parathelphusidae, but have recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae, since Parathelphusidae Alcock, 1910 is regarded a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae Rathbun, 1904 (Klaus et al. 2006). Occasionally, the Parathelphusinae are now used as a valid subfamily within the Gecarcinucidae (e.g. Klaus et al. 2010).

This and related species were formerly included in the Parathelphusidae, but have recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae, since Parathelphusidae Alcock, 1910 is regarded a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae Rathbun, 1904 (Klaus et al. 2006). Occasionally, the Parathelphusinae are now used as a valid subfamily within the Gecarcinucidae (e.g. Klaus et al. 2010).

This and related species were formerly included in the Parathelphusidae, but have recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae, since Parathelphusidae Alcock, 1910 is regarded a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae Rathbun, 1904 (Klaus et al. 2006). Occasionally, the Parathelphusinae are now used as a valid subfamily within the Gecarcinucidae (e.g. Klaus et al. 2010).

Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

Acroteriobatus variegatus is morphologically very similar to A. zanzibarensis, with only subtle differences in mitochondrial DNA between the two species. Further work is required to clarify their relationship (Last et al. 2016b).

This species was confused with H. buergeri until Springer and D'Aubrey (1972) found it to be a different species (Compagno 1984). Previously considered to occur in the Philippines, Viet Nam and northwestern Australia but two new species recently described from Indonesia/Philippines and northwestern Australia have resulted in a more restricted range for this species (White et al. 2007). The Viet Nam populations need to be examined further as it is unsure which Halaelurus species they are (W. White pers. obs).

Previously Torpedo suessi was considered a junior synonym of T. sinuspersici (Carvalho et al. 2002). Garman (1913) considered T. suessi to be a valid species, but thought that it may be synonymous with T. panthera. However, Carvalho et al. (2002) believe that this is not possible due to the inconceivability that the ornate colour pattern of T. suessi could transform into the typical pattern of small, irregular whitish spots present in T. panthera. Rather than being a synonym of T. sinuspersici, or T. panthera, it is much more likely that T. suessi is a valid species that occurs at least in the southern Red Sea (Carvalho et al. 2002). This species may also be identifiable with the paralectotype of T. fuscomaculata, but there is some uncertainty surrounding this, and T. suessi would still prove to be a valid species even it if it was conspecific with the paralectotype (Carvalho et al. 2002).
Aetomylaeus milvus is considered to be distinct from A. maculatus (Last et al. 2016).
Groves (2011) considered that the two taxa of Ailuridae, Ailurus fulgens fulgens and A. f. styani, should be treated as two separate species.
Rhyticeros narcondami (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aceros.
Larvivora ruficeps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Luscinia following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Otus manadensis, O. mendeni and O. sulaensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. manadensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Ninox philippensis, N. spilocephala, N. leventisi, N. reyi, N. rumseyi, N. spilonotus and N. mindorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Mulleripicus funebris and M. fuliginosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. funebris following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Symposiachrus sacerdotum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha sacerdotum.
Sarcophanops samarensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Eurylaimus samarensis.
Ciconia episcopus and C. microscelis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. episcopus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

We consider this species to be separate from Hynobius leechii, following Yang et al. (1997). This is also a restricted concept of this species now that H. unisacculus has been split from it by Min et al. (2016).

Chrysocolaptes lucidus, C. guttacristatus, C. stricklandi, C. strictus, C. haematribon, C. erythrocephalus and C. xanthocephalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. lucidus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Asarcornis scutulata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Cairina.
Anas gibberifrons and A. albogularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. gibberifrons following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ramphiculus subgularis, R. epius and R. mangoliensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Ptilinopus and lumped as P. subgularis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sinosuthora zappeyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Paradoxornis zappeyi.
Symposiachrus everetti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha everetti.
Geokichla cinerea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Zoothera cinerea.
Machlolophus nuchalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus nuchalis.

Ninox philippensis, N. spilocephala, N. leventisi, N. reyi, N. rumseyi, N. spilonotus and N. mindorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: Rasmussen, Allen, Collar, de Meule Meester, Hutchinson, Jakosalem, Kennedy, Lambert & Paguntalan, 2012
taxonomicNotes: Ninox philippensis, N. spilocephala, N. leventisi, N. reyi, N. rumseyi, N. spilonotus and N. mindorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Trochalopteron yersini (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax yersini.
Clanga clanga (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aquila.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pseudobagrus but is here considered valid in the genus Tachysurus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List with the incorrect spelling of regani.

This species may represent is a local subpopulation of Kokanee (Oncorhynchus nerka). This subpopulation looks like Seton and Anderson Lakes Kokanee (Morris and Caverly 2004), and is unlikely to differ genetically (Moreira and Taylor 2015). There is no difference of morphological characters (e.g, number of gill rakers) between Kunimasu and Kokanee. However, Moreira and Taylor (2015) expressed "A diphyletic origin of black kokanee from two independent episodes of divergence on either side of the Pacific Ocean. This inference is supported by the observations that black kokanee in Japan and in the Anderson-Seton lakes system did not form a monophyletic grouping in either the mtDNA or microsatellite-based trees."
Hydrornis baudii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pitta baudii.

Species was established as Sminthus loriger Nathusius in Nordmann, 1840, but during long time was considered as subspecies of Sicista subtilis sensu lato (Sicista subtilis nordmanni). Now this taxon elevated to species level following Zagorodniuk and Selyunina (2009) and Cserkész et al. (2016). Sicista nordmanni (Keyserling & Blasius, 1840) is synonym as it was pointed at by Chaworth-Musters (1934). Nomenclature was revised by Zagorodniuk (2009), and current name “Sminthus loriger Nathusius in Nordmann, 1840” listed as synonym of “Sicista nordmanni Keyserling et Blasius, 1840. Sicista loriger is geographically separated from Sicista subtilis s. str. (Zagorodniuk 2011).

This species belongs to the subfamily Papilioninae (Tyler et al. 1994, Zakharov et al. 2004). Based on mitochondrial and nuclear DNA analysis, it has been suggested that it is closely related to the “Troilus” group (Zakharov et al. 2004).

The valid name for this species is now considered to be Sphaerium regulare Mandahl-Barth, 1954 (see Graf and Cummings, Mussel-P 2016). It was originally introduced by Mandhal-Barth as a subspecies of Sphaerium stuhlmanni and later elevated to full species.

There are four Sphaerium species listed by Graf and Cummings (2016) in their database of freshwater bivalves. It is possible that there are only three extant species, as frequently only three species are recorded.
  •  Sphaerium nyanzae Smith, 1892 - four synonyms | four specimens - Distribution: Endemic to Lake Victoria. 
  • Sphaerium regulare Mandahl-Barth, 1954 - one species-level nomen - Distribution: Lake Victoria and Edward, Africa.
  • Sphaerium stuhlmanni Martens, 1897 - two synonyms - Distribution: Lake Victoria, Africa.
  • Sphaerium victoriae Smith, 1906 - five synonyms - Distribution: Upper Nile Great Lakes, Africa.

The Afrotropical genus Ceratophallus consists of 12 small planorbid snails, most of which are restricted to rift lakes (Brown 1994). The generic position of three of these Ceratophallus species remains uncertain. The highest species diversity is found in the Victoria Basin and Lake Victoria proper. In addition to four species that are endemic to the lake and lake shore, namely C. kisumiensis, C. subtilis, C. concavus and C. crassus, the widespread C. natalensis and C. kigeziensis also occur in the Lake Victoria basin.

The Afrotropical genus Ceratophallus consists of 12 small planorbid snails, most of which are restricted to rift lakes (Brown 1994). The generic position of three of these Ceratophallus species remains uncertain. The highest species diversity is found in the Victoria Basin and Lake Victoria proper. In addition to four species that are endemic to the lake, namely C. kisumiensis, C. subtilis, C. concavus and C. crassus, the widespread C. natalensis, C. gibonsi and C. kigeziensis also do occur in the Lake Victoria basin.

Mandahl-Barth (1954) originally described C. subtilis as a subspecies of Gyraulus costulatus, endemic to Lake Victoria (G. costulatus subtilis). Brown (1994) placed it in the genus Ceratophallus while adding that the examination of the penis is desirable to confirm identification. The present generic status of this species or subspecies is hence not yet confirmed.

Edolisoma tenuirostre, E. insperatum, E. nesiotis, E. monacha, E. rostratum, E. meyerii, E. obiense, E. grayi, E. remotum and E. salomonis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Coracina tenuirostris following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Bulinus permembranaceus is a species belonging to the B. truncatus/tropicus group (not complex). The species is haploid and restricted to higher altitudes.

The Afrotropical genus Cleopatra (Paludomidae) is in need of revision. Cleopatra cridlandi is an intriguing species, that seems related to C. bulimoides, the main Cleopatra species in Africa north of the equator.
Clibanornis erythrocephalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hylocryptus erythrocephalus.
Cinclus schulzii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as C. schulzi.
Fringilla teydea and F. polatzeki (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as F. teydea following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Laniellus langbianis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Crocias langbianis.

authority: Avendaño, Cuervo, López, Gutiérrez Pinto, Cortés & Cadena, 2015
taxonomicNotes: Scytalopus perijanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Avendaño et al. (2015).

Calamonastides gracilirostris and C. bensoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Chloropeta gracilirostris following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Trochalopteron cachinnans and T. jerdoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Strophocincla cachinnans following Rasmussen and Anderton (2005).
Laticilla burnesii and L. cinerascens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Prinia burnesii following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pipilo maculatus and P. socorroensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. maculatus following AOU (1998 and supplements); Stotz et al. (1996).

Wallin (1977) documented that the Linnaean type specimen of Psammobates geometricus is actually a specimen of Geochelone elegans with the type locality of "Asia". Hoogmoed and Crumly (1984) instead assigned the animal depicted by Piso (1658) as syntypical to P. geometricus and designated it as lectotype, and the type locality was restricted to "southwestern Cape Province, South Africa" by Baard (1991). No subspecies are currently recognized. Although earlier research showed no significant genetic distance among three seemingly isolated subpopulations (Cunningham et al. 2002), the phylogeographic relationships of these should be given further attention.
Carpodacus ferreorostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Chaunoproctus following Brooks (2000); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

This species was formerly included as a subspecies of Tupaia glis (e.g., Corbet and Hill 1992), but is here treated as a distinct species following Wilson (1993) and Helgen (2005). This distinction is supported by molecular (Roberts et al. 2011) and morphological (Olson et al. 2004, Sargis et al. 2013) evidence. The Siberut population previously included within T. glis is now considered part of T. chrysogaster (Sargis et al. 2014).

Spermophilus canus and S. mollis formerly were included in S. townsendii. Baker et al. (2003) and Thorington and Hoffmann (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) recognized the three taxa as distinct species, noting their distinct cytotypes and lack of hybridization. This species is now recognized under a new genus, Urocitellus (Helgen et al. 2009).

Borges et al. (2017) redescribed Tarphius tornvalli Gillerfors, 1985.

Synonyms

Tarphius tornvalli in Gillerfors (1985, p. 5) (S. Miguel Isl.)

Tarphius tornvalli in Borges (1990, p. 112) (S. Miguel Isl.)

Tarphius tornvalli in Borges (1991, p. 2) (S. Miguel Isl.)

Tarphius tornvalli and Tarphius azoricus in Borges et al. (2005, p. 207) (S. Miguel Isl.)

Tarphius tornvalli and Tarphius azoricus in Oromí et al. (2010, p. 232) (S. Miguel Isl.)

Tarphius azoricus in Oromí et al. (2010, p. 232) (São Jorge Isl.)

Tarphius azoricus in Oromí et al. (2010, p. 232) (Faial Isl.)

Tarphius azoricus in Amorim et al. (2012, Fig. 2) (Faial Isl.)

Tarphius azoricus in Gillerfors (1986, p. 21) (Pico Isl.)
